Recreate this French bakery classic at home!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "chocolate croissants", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/chocolate-croissants-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/chocolate-croissants-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/chocolate-croissants-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/chocolate-croissants-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-croissants/", "recipeIngredient": ["1/4 cup (4 Tbsp; 56g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "4 cups (500g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more for rolling/shaping", "1/4 cup (50g) granulated sugar", "2 teaspoons salt", "1 Tablespoon active dry or instant yeast", "1 and 1/2 cups (360ml) cold whole milk", "one 4-ounce bar\u00a0(113g) semi-sweet or bittersweet chocolate, coarsely chopped", "optional: confectioners&#8217; sugar for dusting", "1 and 1/2 cups (340g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "2 Tablespoons (16g) all-purpose flour", "1 large egg", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) whole milk"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "I have lots of information to prepare you to make homemade chocolate croissants. A complete guide to making the croissant dough, with a video and step-by-step photographs, can be found in my original croissants recipe. That post will help you get through the first several steps. Additionally, you can see the post above for a visual for how the chocolate croissants are shaped, which begins in step 13 below. Make room in the refrigerator for a baking sheet. In step 6 and again in step 13, you will need room for 2 baking sheets.", "name": "Preliminary notes", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-croissants/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cut the butter in four 1-Tablespoon slices and place in the bowl of an electric stand mixer fitted with the dough hook attachment (or you can use a handheld mixer or no mixer, but a stand mixer is ideal). Add the flour, sugar, salt, and yeast. Turn the mixer on low-medium speed to gently combine the ingredients for 1 minute. With the mixer running, slowly pour in the milk. Once all of the milk is added, turn the mixer up to medium speed and begin to knead the dough.", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-croissants/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my\u00a0How to Knead Dough\u00a0video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rest. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rest. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-croissants/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove dough from the bowl and, with floured hands, work it into a ball. Place the dough on a lightly floured silicone baking mat lined, lightly floured parchment paper lined, or lightly floured baking sheet. (I recommend a silicone baking mat because you can roll the dough out in the next step directly on top and it won\u2019t slide all over the counter.) Gently flatten the dough out, and cover with plastic wrap or aluminum foil. Place the entire baking sheet in the refrigerator and allow the covered dough to rest in the refrigerator for 30 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-croissants/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the dough from the refrigerator. I like to keep the dough on the silicone baking mat when I\u2019m rolling it in this step because the mat is nonstick and it\u2019s a handy guide for the exact measurement. Begin flattening out the dough with your hands. You\u2019re rolling it out into a rectangle in this step, so shaping it with your hands first helps the stretchy dough. Roll it into a 14&#215;10-inch rectangle. The dough isn&#8217;t extremely cold after only 30 minutes in the refrigerator, so it will feel more like soft play-doh. Be precise with the measurement. The dough will want to be oval shaped, but keep working the edges with your hands and rolling pin until you have the correct size rectangle.", "name": "Shape the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-croissants/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the rolled out dough back onto the baking sheet (this is why I prefer a silicone baking mat or parchment because you can easily transfer the dough). Cover the rolled out dough with plastic wrap or aluminum foil, place the entire baking sheet in the refrigerator and allow the covered dough to rest in the refrigerator for 4 hours or overnight. (Up to 24 hours is ok.)", "name": "Long rest", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-croissants/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand-held mixer or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter and flour together until smooth and combined. Transfer the mixture to a silicone baking mat lined or parchment paper lined baking sheet. (Silicone baking mat is preferred because you can easily peel the butter off in the next step.) Using a spoon or small spatula, smooth out into a 7&#215;10-inch rectangle. Be as precise as you can with this measurement. Place the entire baking sheet in the refrigerator and chill the butter layer for 30 minutes. (No need to cover it for only 30 minutes.) You want the butter layer firm, but still pliable. If it gets too firm, let it sit out on the counter for a few minutes to gently soften. The more firm the butter layer is the more difficult it will be to laminate the dough in the next step.", "name": "Butter layer (begin this 35 minutes before the next step so the butter can chill for 30 minutes)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-croissants/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0In this next step, you will be rolling out the dough into a large rectangle. Do this on a lightly floured counter instead of rolling out on your silicone baking mat. The counter is typically a little cooler (great for keeping the dough cold) and the silicone baking mat is smaller than the measurement you need. Remove both the dough and butter layers from the refrigerator. Place the butter layer in the center of the dough and fold each end of the dough over it. If the butter wasn\u2019t an exact 7&#215;10-inch rectangle, use a pizza cutter or sharp knife to even out the edges. Seal the dough edges over the butter layer as best you can with your fingers. On a lightly floured counter, roll the dough into a 10&#215;20-inch rectangle. It\u2019s best to roll back and forth with the shorter end of the dough facing you. Use your fingers if you need to. The dough is very cold, so it will take a lot of arm muscle to roll. Again, the dough will want to be oval shaped, but keep working it with your hands and rolling pin until you have the correct size rectangle. Fold the dough lengthwise into thirds as if you were folding a letter. This was the 1st turn.", "name": "Laminate the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-croissants/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If the dough is now too warm to work with, place folded dough on the baking sheet, cover with plastic wrap or aluminum foil, and refrigerate for 30 minutes before the 2nd turn.\u00a0I usually don\u2019t have to.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-croissants/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Turn the dough so the short end is facing you. Roll the dough out once again into a 10&#215;20-inch rectangle, then fold the dough lengthwise into thirds as if you were folding a letter. The dough must be refrigerated between the 2nd\u00a0and 3rd turn because it has been worked with a lot by this point. Place the folded dough on the baking sheet, cover with plastic wrap or aluminum foil, and refrigerate for 30 minutes before the 3rd turn.", "name": "2nd turn", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-croissants/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Roll the dough out once again into a 10&#215;20-inch rectangle. Fold the dough lengthwise into thirds as if you were folding a letter.", "name": "3rd turn", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-croissants/#instruction-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the folded dough on the lined baking sheet, cover with plastic wrap or aluminum foil, and refrigerate for 4 hours or overnight.\u00a0(Up to 24 hours is ok.)", "name": "Long rest", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-croissants/#instruction-step-12"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "At the end of the next step, you\u2019ll need 2 baking sheets lined with silicone baking mats or parchment paper. The dough is currently on a lined baking sheet in the refrigerator, so you already have 1 prepared!", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-croissants/#instruction-step-13"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the dough from the refrigerator. On a lightly floured counter, roll the dough out into an 8&#215;20-inch rectangle. Use your fingers if you need to. Once again, the dough is very cold, so it will take a lot of arm muscle to roll. The dough will want to be oval shaped, but keep working it with your hands and rolling pin until you have the correct size rectangle. Using a pizza cutter or sharp knife, slice the dough in half vertically. Each skinny rectangle will be 4 inches wide. Then cut 3 even slices horizontally, yielding 8 4&#215;5-inch rectangles. See photo above for a visual. Cut each rectangle in half lengthwise so you have 16 2&#215;5-inch rectangles. Work with one rectangle at a time. Using your fingers or a rolling pin, stretch it to be about 8 inches long. Do this gently as you do not want to flatten the layers. Place a few small pieces of chocolate in a single layer at one end and tightly roll the dough up around the chocolate. Make sure the end is on the bottom. Repeat with remaining dough, placing the shaped croissants on 2 lined baking sheets, 8 per sheet. Loosely cover with plastic wrap or aluminum foil and allow to rest at room temperature (no warmer! I suggest just keeping on the counter) for 1 hour, then place in the refrigerator to rest for 1 hour or up to 12 hours. (Or freeze, see freezing instructions. I prefer the shaped croissants to be cold going into the oven.", "name": "Shape the croissants", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-croissants/#instruction-step-14"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-croissants/#instruction-step-15"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Whisk the egg wash ingredients together.\u00a0Remove the croissants from the refrigerator. You need a blender or food processor for the filling. For more information on the dried figs or for substitutions, see text above this printable recipe.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "oatmeal fig bars", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/fig-bars-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/fig-bars-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/fig-bars-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/fig-bars.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/oatmeal-fig-bars/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 1/2 cups (about 230g) chopped dried figs, stems removed", "1/2 cup (120ml) water", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) orange juice", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1/3 cup (70g) coconut oil, melted (or use melted butter)", "1/4 cup (60ml) pure maple syrup", "1/2 cup (100g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "1 and 2/3 cups (142g) old-fashioned whole rolled oats\u00a0(or quick oats)*", "1 cup (130g)\u00a0whole wheat flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon baking powder", "3/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg", "1/4 teaspoon salt"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line an 8-inch (what I use and recommend) or 9-inch square baking pan with parchment paper, leaving enough overhang on the sides to easily remove the bars when they have cooled. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/oatmeal-fig-bars/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Combine the chopped dried figs, water, and orange juice together in a medium saucepan over medium heat. Cook while stirring occasionally for 5-8 minutes or until figs are soft and have absorbed some of the liquid. Remove from heat and stir in vanilla extract. Cool for 5 minutes, and then transfer to a food processor or blender and puree until there are no more chunks (fig seeds will not break down). Set aside. Makes *about* 1 and 1/4 cups filling.", "name": "Make the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/oatmeal-fig-bars/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl, whisk the melted coconut oil, maple syrup, brown sugar, and egg together. Add the oats, flour, baking powder, cinnamon, nutmeg, and salt. Begin whisking to combine and once the mixture becomes too thick, switch to a spoon or silicone spatula to bring the ingredients together. You will have about 2 and 1/2 cups of this crust/topping mixture.", "name": "Make the crust/topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/oatmeal-fig-bars/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Take a little over 1 and 1/2 cups of the crust/topping mixture and press it evenly into the lined pan. Spread fig filling in an even layer on top. Spoon remaining crust/topping mixture evenly on top and gently press it down into the filling to ensure it&#8217;s tight and compact on top.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/oatmeal-fig-bars/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 25-30 minutes or until the top has lightly browned. Avoid over-baking. 8 inch pans take closer to 30 minutes, 9 inch pans take closer to 25 minutes. (Note: Oil/moisture will soak on the parchment paper during the baking &amp; cooling process. That&#8217;s normal with this recipe.) Remove from the oven and place the pan on a wire rack. Cool bars completely.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/oatmeal-fig-bars/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lift the bars out using the parchment paper overhang on the sides. Dough will be very soft and look greasy.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookie-bark/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Press the dough into the prepared pan, to an even thickness\u2014covering the entire parchment paper-lined baking sheet. I like to use my hands to press it down at first, and then I switch to an offset spatula to really get the dough to all edges of the pan. It will take a few minutes, but I promise eventually you will get it pressed thin enough to cover the entire pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookie-bark/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 18\u201320 minutes, or until a deep golden brown on top. Keep an eye on it after 15 minutes. If you are using a dark baking sheet, the bake time will be shorter than if you are using a light silver baking sheet, because a dark metal pan absorbs more heat. Again, keep an eye on it.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookie-bark/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove from the oven and sprinkle the chopped chocolate all over the surface of the cookie. Top with flaky sea salt or sprinkles, if using. We noticed it starts to taste a bit stale around day 4 or 5. But really, is it even possible to have any of this chocolate chip cookie bark left for that long? Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-bars-recipe/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Mix the melted butter, sugar, vanilla extract, and salt together in a medium bowl. Add the flour and stir to completely combine. The dough will be thick. Press firmly into prepared pan, making sure the layer of crust is nice and even. Bake for 20-22 minutes or until the edges are lightly browned. Remove from the oven. Using a fork, poke holes all over the top of the warm crust (not all the way through the crust). A new step I swear by, this helps the filling stick and holds the crust in place. Set aside until step 4.", "name": "Make the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-bars-recipe/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Sift the sugar and flour together in a large bowl. Whisk in the eggs, then the lemon juice until completely combined.", "name": "Make the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-bars-recipe/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour filling over warm crust. Bake the bars for 22-26 minutes or until the center is relatively set and no longer jiggles. (Give the pan a light tap with an oven mitt to test.) Remove bars from the oven and cool completely at room temperature. I usually cool them for about 2 hours at room temperature, then stick in the refrigerator for 1-2 more hours until pretty chilled. I recommend serving chilled.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-bars-recipe/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once cool,\u00a0lift the parchment paper out of the pan using the overhang on the sides. Dust with confectioners&#8217; sugar and cut into squares before serving. For neat squares, wipe the knife clean between each cut. Cover and store leftover lemon bars in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-bars-recipe/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lemon bars can be frozen for up to 3-4 months. Cut the cooled bars (without confectioners&#8217; sugar topping) into squares, then place onto a baking sheet. Freeze for 1 hour. Individually wrap each bar in aluminum foil or plastic wrap and place into a large bag or freezer container to freeze. You can use the microwave or stovetop. Pour the warm milk into the bowl of an electric stand mixer fitted with the dough hook attachment (or you can use a handheld mixer or no mixer, but a stand mixer is ideal). Manually whisk in the yeast and 2 teaspoons of the granulated sugar.\u00a0Cover the bowl with a clean towel. The mixture should be frothy and foamy after 5 minutes.", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-babka/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "On low speed, beat in\u00a0the remaining sugar and the softened butter until butter is slightly broken up. Next beat in 1 whole egg plus 1 egg yolk (reserve the egg white) and the salt. The butter won&#8217;t really be mixing in, so don&#8217;t be alarmed if it stays in pieces. On low speed, gradually add the flour.\u00a0Once it is all added, beat on\u00a0medium speed until a soft dough forms, about 1 minute.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-babka/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Knead the dough: Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 6-8 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 6-8 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-babka/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Turn it out onto a lightly floured surface and form into a ball. Place into a large greased bowl, turning once to grease the top. (I just use the same mixing bowl that I made the dough in\u2014remove the dough, grease it with nonstick spray or olive oil, put the dough back in.) Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and place it in a warm environment\u00a0to rise until doubled, about 90 minutes. For this warm environment, I preheat the oven to 200\u00b0F (93\u00b0C) then turn the oven off and place the bowl inside the\u00a0warm-ish oven. Leave the oven door cracked a bit.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-babka/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once doubled in size, punch down the dough to release any air bubbles. Remove dough from the bowl and turn it out onto a lightly floured surface. Punch down again to release any more air bubbles if needed.\u00a0Using a sharp knife or dough scraper, cut dough in half. Work with only half of the dough at a time. Place a clean towel over the dough you aren&#8217;t working with.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-babka/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Generously grease two 9&#215;5-inch loaf pans with butter or nonstick spray.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-babka/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "On slightly floured work surface, roll one dough half out into a 9&#215;13-inch rectangle (approximately). Spread with 1 cup of Nutella, leaving a 1/2 inch border uncovered.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-babka/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Tightly roll the dough into a 13-inch log. Place the log on its seam. Using a sharp knife, cut the log in half lengthwise. I find a serrated knife works best. Criss-cross one half, cut side down, on top of the other half, forming an X. Twist the two together. Place in prepared loaf pan and cover with a clean towel. Repeat with 2nd half of dough. This step can get a little messy! (If you need a visual for this step, see the video tutorial for homemade cheese bread starting at the 2:54 mark.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-babka/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Allow both shaped (and covered) loaves to rest for 20-30 minutes as you prepare the crumble topping and preheat the oven.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-babka/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to\u00a0350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-babka/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Mix the brown sugar, flour, and cinnamon together in a medium bowl.\u00a0Using a pastry cutter, cut the cold butter into the brown sugar mixture until\u00a0coarse crumbs are formed. Set aside.", "name": "Make the crumble topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-babka/#instruction-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the remaining 2 Tablespoons of milk with the leftover egg white. This is your egg wash. Using a pastry brush, brush the babka loaves with egg wash. Do the best you can as some Nutella is exposed. Top each loaf with crumble topping.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-babka/#instruction-step-12"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 45-50 minutes or until babka is golden brown on top. Gently tap the loaves\u2014if they sound hollow, the bread is done. (It won&#8217;t last that long!!) You can also freeze the baked babka for up to 3 months, then thaw overnight in the refrigerator. Bring to room temperature before serving. Have fun decorating!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "Sugar Plum Fairy Cupcakes", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/sugar-plum-fairy-cupcakes-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/sugar-plum-fairy-cupcakes-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/sugar-plum-fairy-cupcakes-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/sugar-plum-fairy-cupcakes.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sugar-plum-fairy-cupcakes/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 3/4 cups (207g) cake flour* (spooned &amp; leveled)", "3/4 teaspoon baking powder", "1/4 teaspoon baking soda", "1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg", "1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 cup (200g) granulated sugar", "3 large egg whites, at room temperature*", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1 teaspoon almond extract*", "1/2 cup (120g) sour cream or plain yogurt, at room temperature", "1/2 cup (120ml)\u00a0whole milk, at room temperature", "1/3 cup (100g)\u00a0peach jam or preserves (or your favorite flavor)", "1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "4 &#8211; 5 cups\u00a0(480-600g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1/4 cup (60ml) heavy cream or milk", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1/2 teaspoon almond extract", "salt, to taste", "optional for garnish: snowflake sugar cookies (see blog post above), gum drops, peppermint candies, sprinkles"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line a 12-cup muffin pan with cupcake liners. Line a second pan with 2-3 liners\u2014this recipe makes 14-15 cupcakes. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sugar-plum-fairy-cupcakes/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the cake flour, baking powder, baking soda, nutmeg, cinnamon, and salt together. Set aside.", "name": "Make the cupcakes:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sugar-plum-fairy-cupcakes/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on high speed until smooth and creamed, about 2 minutes. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed. Beat in the egg whites on high speed until combined, about 2 minutes. Beat in the sour cream, vanilla extract, and almond extract. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. With the mixer on low speed, add the dry ingredients until just incorporated. With the mixer still running on low, slowly pour and mix in the milk *just* until combined. Do not overmix.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sugar-plum-fairy-cupcakes/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour/spoon the batter into the liners. Fill only 2/3 full\u00a0to avoid baking over the sides. Bake for 20-22 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. For around\u00a035 mini cupcakes,\u00a0bake for about 11-13\u00a0minutes, same oven temperature. Using a sharp knife, cut a circle/hole into the center of the cooled cupcakes to create a little pocket about 1 inch deep. The piece you removed will be the shape of a cone. For other size cakes using this recipe, see Notes below.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally McKenney", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "chocolate chip layer cake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/chocolate-chip-layer-cake-ganache-chocolate-drip-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/chocolate-chip-layer-cake-ganache-chocolate-drip-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/chocolate-chip-layer-cake-ganache-chocolate-drip-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/chocolate-chip-layer-cake-ganache-chocolate-drip.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-layer-cake/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 1/2 cups (285g) cake flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 teaspoons baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda", "1 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 and 3/4 cups (350g) granulated sugar", "5 large egg whites, at room temperature", "1/2 cup (120g) sour cream, at room temperature", "1 Tablespoon pure vanilla extract (yes, Tbsp!)", "1 cup (240ml) whole milk, at room temperature", "1 and 1/4 cups (225g) mini chocolate chips tossed in 1 Tablespoon cake flour", "1 and 1/2 cups (340g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "5 and 1/2 cups (650g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1/3 cup (80ml)\u00a0heavy cream (can be cold or room temperature)", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1/8 teaspoon salt", "1 cup (180g) mini chocolate chips", "6 ounces (170g) semi-sweet chocolate, finely chopped", "3/4 cup (6 ounces or 170\u2013180g/ml) heavy cream"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Grease three 8-inch round cake pans, line with parchment paper rounds, then grease the parchment paper. Parchment paper helps the cakes seamlessly release from the pans. (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes video &amp; post.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-layer-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the cake flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together. Set aside.", "name": "Make the cake:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-layer-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on high speed until combined and creamy, about 3 minutes. Scrape down the sides of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg whites. Beat on high speed until combined, about 2 minutes. Then beat in the sour cream and vanilla extract, again on high speed, until the mixture comes together. Scrape down the sides as needed. Add the dry ingredients and turn the mixer on low speed. With the mixer running on low, slowly pour in the milk until combined. Do not overmix. You may need to whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no lumps or dry pockets at the bottom of the bowl. The batter will be slightly thick. Fold in the mini chocolate chips.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-layer-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour batter evenly into cake pans. Weigh them to ensure accuracy, if desired. Bake for 24\u201326 minutes or until the cakes are baked through. To test for doneness, insert a toothpick into the center of the cake. If it comes out clean, it&#8217;s done. Or you can lightly poke the top of the cake with your finger. If it bounces back, it&#8217;s done.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-layer-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Allow cakes to cool in the pans set on a cooling rack for 1 hour, then remove them from the pans and let the cakes finish cooling directly on the rack. The cakes must be completely cool before frosting and assembling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-layer-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "(Note that if you want to pipe plain buttercream on top of the cake like in the photos and video, set around 3/4 cup (about 180g) aside before adding the chocolate chips.) In a large bowl using a handheld mixer or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium to medium-high speed until smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Add confectioners&#8217; sugar, heavy cream, vanilla extract, and salt. Start the mixer on low speed, then gradually increase to high speed and beat until whipped and fluffy, about 4 minutes. Fold in the mini chocolate chips, either by hand with a spatula, or you can beat them in on low speed until they&#8217;re evenly dispersed throughout the frosting.", "name": "Make the buttercream", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-layer-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a large serrated knife, slice a thin layer off the tops of the cakes to create a flat surface. Discard the scraps, or you can save them to crumble on top of the finished cake. Place 1 cake layer on your cake stand, cake turntable, or serving plate. Evenly cover the top with about 1 cup of frosting. Top with 2nd cake layer, upside down, and evenly cover the top with another 1 cup of frosting. Top with the third cake layer, either right side up or upside down. Spread the remaining frosting all over the top and sides. I use and recommend a large, straight icing spatula to apply the frosting.", "name": "Assemble and decorate", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-layer-cake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Refrigerate the cake for at least 20 minutes, or up to 8 hours. The frosting must be cold when you add the chocolate drip on top.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-layer-cake/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place chopped chocolate in a medium heat-proof bowl with a pour spout (I use a 2-cup glass liquid measuring cup). Heat the cream in a small saucepan over medium heat until it begins to gently simmer. (Do not let it come to a rapid boil\u2014that\u2019s too hot!) Pour over chocolate, then let it sit for 2\u20133 minutes to gently soften the chocolate. With a metal spoon or small rubber spatula, very slowly stir until chocolate has melted and mixture is smooth. The finer you chopped the chocolate, the quicker it will melt with the cream. If it\u2019s not melting, do not microwave it. If needed, see Troubleshooting Chocolate Ganache. Once ganache mixture is smooth, transfer it into a squeeze bottle.", "name": "Make the chocolate ganache", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-layer-cake/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the cake from the refrigerator. Working in a zigzag motion, gently squeeze the warm ganache around the edge of the cake, turning the cake as you go. See video tutorial below as a visual. The ganache should drip down the sides and set as it does. When you&#8217;ve gone around the whole cake, squeeze remaining ganache on top of the cake, and smooth it into an even layer with an offset spatula. Feel free to garnish with fresh berries, chocolate chips, or leftover cake crumbles from leveling the tops of the cakes. Chill, uncovered, for at least 20 minutes, or up to 6 hours before slicing and serving. Once the ganache has chilled, if you set aside buttercream in step 6, you can pipe it on. I used Wilton 1M piping tip.", "name": "Chocolate ganache drip:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-layer-cake/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cake can be served at room temperature or chilled. I prefer it at room temperature. Leave remaining icing white. Add green icing to a piping bag fitted with round icing tip #5. Line green icing around the round bottom of each cookie. Place baking sheet in the refrigerator to set the icing for 15 minutes. Add white icing to a piping bag fitted with the same round icing tip. Line white icing right above green icing. Place baking sheet in the refrigerator to set the icing for 15 minutes. Add pink icing to a piping bag fitted with the same round icing tip. Pipe pink icing onto the rest of the watermelon slice. This recipe is also in my New York Times best-selling cookbook, Sally's Baking 101, on page 77.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "brown butter pecan pie bars, pecan pie bars", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/salted-brown-butter-pecan-pie-bars-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/salted-brown-butter-pecan-pie-bars-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/salted-brown-butter-pecan-pie-bars-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/salted-brown-butter-pecan-pie-bars.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brown-butter-pecan-pie-bars/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g) unsalted butter, cut into 16 pieces", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "2 Tablespoons water", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "2 cups (250g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 Tablespoon cornstarch", "1/2 cup (170g/120ml) pure maple syrup", "1/2 cup (100g) packed light or dark brown sugar (I prefer dark here)", "6 Tablespoons (85g) unsalted butter", "1/4 cup (60g/ml) heavy cream", "2 large eggs, beaten, at room temperature", "3 cups (360g) chopped pecans", "optional: flaky sea salt or coarse sea salt, for sprinkling"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C) and line a 9&#215;13-inch metal baking pan with parchment paper, leaving a few inches of overhang on 2 opposite sides.\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brown-butter-pecan-pie-bars/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the sliced butter in a light-colored skillet or saucepan over medium heat. (Light-colored helps you determine when the butter begins browning.) Stir or whisk the butter constantly as it melts. Once melted, the butter will begin to foam. Keep stirring. After 5\u20138 minutes, the butter will begin browning\u2014you&#8217;ll notice lightly browned specks begin to form at the bottom of the pan and it will have a nutty aroma. As soon as the butter has browned, immediately remove from heat and pour it into a large heat-safe glass bowl. Scrape up the browned solids at the bottom of the skillet and add them as well. Allow to cool for about 10 minutes. Do not rinse out the pan.", "name": "Make the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brown-butter-pecan-pie-bars/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the sugar, water, vanilla, and salt to the slightly cooled brown butter and stir until combined. Add the flour and cornstarch and mix until the flour disappears. The mixture should be slick. Press the crust evenly into the prepared baking pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brown-butter-pecan-pie-bars/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 15 minutes or until lightly browned on the edges. Place the baking pan on a cooling rack while you make the topping.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brown-butter-pecan-pie-bars/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Return the skillet/saucepan to medium heat and add the maple syrup, brown sugar, butter, and cream. Melt the butter, whisking constantly to combine the ingredients. When the butter has melted, remove the pan from heat and pour the mixture into a large heat-safe bowl. Cool for 5 minutes. Whisk in the beaten eggs, then fold in the pecans. Pour the topping over the warm crust and spread it into an even layer. Lightly sprinkle with sea salt.", "name": "Make the topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brown-butter-pecan-pie-bars/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 25 to 28 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out mostly clean. If the top is browning too quickly, loosely tent aluminum foil over the pan. I use <a href=\"https://amzn.to/4nTV5P2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener sponsored nofollow\">Reese brand</a>, which is typically available in the ice cream toppings section of the grocery store. It won\u2019t be a 1:1 swap. If you\u2019d like to experiment, start with a very small amount of the liqueur, increase the confectioners' sugar, and taste as you go. Expect the texture and flavor to be different.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/creme-de-menthe-pie/#faq-question-1763116160921", "position": 4, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/creme-de-menthe-pie/#faq-question-1763116160921", "name": "How strong is the mint flavor?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "It's refreshing, but not overpowering. ", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/creme-de-menthe-pie/#faq-question-1763116210971", "position": 5, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/creme-de-menthe-pie/#faq-question-1763116210971", "name": "Can I use mint extract instead of peppermint extract?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "I don't recommend it. Mint extract has both spearmint and peppermint flavoring. We tested it and the pie tasted like toothpaste! Peppermint extract has a sharper, cleaner flavor and is more fitting in a dessert like this.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Cr\u00e8me de Menthe Pie (Mint Chocolate)", "description": "If you\u2019re a fan of all things mint-chocolate and love the dreamy texture of a cream pie, this cr\u00e8me de menthe pie is about to become your new signature dessert. Cool, creamy mint chocolate bliss in every bite.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "creme de menthe pie", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/creme-de-menthe-pie-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/creme-de-menthe-pie-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/creme-de-menthe-pie-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/creme-de-menthe-pie.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/creme-de-menthe-pie/", "recipeIngredient": ["22 whole Oreo cookies (250g; not Double Stuf)*", "4 Tablespoons (56g)\u00a0unsalted butter, melted", "1/2 cup (120g/ml) heavy cream", "4 ounces (113g) bittersweet or semi-sweet chocolate, finely chopped*", "1/4 teaspoon peppermint extract", "1 cup (240g/ml) heavy cream, cold", "8 ounces (226g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (90g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "3 Tablespoons (45g/ml) cr\u00e8me de menthe syrup", "1/4 teaspoon peppermint extract", "2 ounces (56g) bittersweet or semi-sweet chocolate, finely chopped (or mini chocolate chips)", "optional for topping: homemade whipped cream, fresh mint leaves, chocolate curls/shavings"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/creme-de-menthe-pie/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a food processor or blender, pulse 22 Oreos (including the cream filling) into a fine crumb. You should have about 2 cups (packed) crumbs, or 250g. Pour crumbs into a large bowl. Add the melted butter and stir to combine. The mixture will be thick and quite wet. Try to smash/break up any large chunks. Pour the mixture into an ungreased 9-inch pie dish. With medium pressure using your hand, pat the crumbs down into the bottom and up the sides to make a compact, thick crust. See Oreo crust page for more success tips if needed. Bake for 10 minutes. Set the crust aside on a cooling rack to slightly cool while you continue.", "name": "Bake the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/creme-de-menthe-pie/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place chopped chocolate in a medium heatproof bowl. Heat the cream in a small saucepan over medium heat, stirring occasionally. As soon as it begins to simmer, immediately remove from heat and pour over the chocolate. Let sit for 2\u20133 minutes to soften the chocolate, then add in the peppermint extract. Stir gently until the ganache is smooth. Pour it into the baked Oreo crust and spread it across the bottom and slightly up the sides. If the crust has cooled, you can also gently tilt the pie dish to swirl the ganache around to coat the bottom and partially up the sides. Place the pie on a cooling rack in the refrigerator to cool. Black-bottom crust must be completely cool before filling.", "name": "Make the mint chocolate ganache", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/creme-de-menthe-pie/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, whip the cold heavy cream into stiff peaks on medium-high speed, about 4 minutes. Set aside. Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk or paddle attachment, beat the cream cheese on medium speed until perfectly smooth and creamy. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed. Add the confectioners&#8217; sugar, cr\u00e8me de menthe syrup, and peppermint extract and beat on medium-high speed until combined. Make sure there are no large lumps of cream cheese. If there are lumps, keep beating until smooth.", "name": "Make the filling:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/creme-de-menthe-pie/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a silicone spatula, fold the whipped cream into the cream cheese mixture until combined. This takes several turns of your spatula. Combine slowly, as you don&#8217;t want to deflate all the air in the whipped cream. Finally, fold the chopped chocolate into the filling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/creme-de-menthe-pie/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread the filling into the cooled crust. This simple mixing method produces the most beautiful and crusty cranberry nut no-knead bread with very little hands-on work! If you\u2019re new to working with yeast, reference my Baking with Yeast Guide\u00a0for answers to common yeast FAQs.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "cranberry no knead bread", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/crusty-no-knead-cranberry-nut-bread-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/crusty-no-knead-cranberry-nut-bread-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/crusty-no-knead-cranberry-nut-bread-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/crusty-no-knead-cranberry-nut-bread.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-knead-cranberry-nut-bread/", "recipeIngredient": ["3 cups + 2 Tablespoons (390g) bread flour or all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed", "2 teaspoons coarse sea salt (I find the flavor lacking with regular table salt)", "1/2 teaspoon Platinum Yeast from Red Star instant yeast", "3/4 cup (95g) chopped walnuts or pecans", "3/4 cup (105g) dried cranberries*", "1 Tablespoon (21g)\u00a0honey", "1 and 1/2 cups (360ml) warm water (about\u00a095\u00b0F (35\u00b0C))"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "*No need to grease the bowl, and do not use a mixer in this step because the dough is too sticky for a mixer.* In a large bowl using a silicone spatula, stir the first 5 ingredients together. Mix the honey and water together, then pour on top. Mix to combine. (Note that in the video below, I add the honey to the dry ingredients instead of mixing first with water, but you can do it either way.) The dough will be very sticky; don&#8217;t be tempted to add more flour, you want a sticky dough. Gently shape into a ball as best you can.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-knead-cranberry-nut-bread/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover tightly. Set on the counter at room temperature (honestly any normal room temperature is fine) and allow to rise for 12\u201318 hours. The dough will double in size, stick to the sides of the bowl, and may have air bubbles on the surface.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-knead-cranberry-nut-bread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured work surface and, using lightly floured hands, shape into a ball as best you can. It doesn&#8217;t have to be perfect. Transfer the dough to a large piece of parchment paper. (Large enough to fit inside your pot and one that is safe for high heat. I use this parchment and it&#8217;s never been an issue.) Using a very sharp knife, kitchen shears, or a bread lame, gently score an X into the top. Place the ball of dough + parchment inside a bowl so the dough doesn&#8217;t spread out as it rests. Cover dough lightly with plastic wrap or a clean kitchen towel and let it rest for 30 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-knead-cranberry-nut-bread/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "During this rest, preheat the oven to 475\u00b0F (246\u00b0C). (Yes, very hot!) Place your Dutch oven (with the lid) or heavy-duty pot in the oven for 30 minutes so that it&#8217;s extremely hot before the dough is placed inside. After 30 minutes, remove the Dutch oven and carefully place the dough inside by lifting it up with the parchment paper and placing it all\u2014the parchment paper included\u2014inside the pot. Cover with the lid.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-knead-cranberry-nut-bread/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 25 minutes with the lid on. Carefully remove the lid and continue baking for 8\u201310 more minutes until the bread is golden brown. How to test for doneness: Give the warm bread a light tap. If it sounds hollow, it\u2019s done. For a more accurate test, the bread is done when an instant-read thermometer reads the center of the loaf as 195\u00b0F (90\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-knead-cranberry-nut-bread/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove pot from the oven, carefully remove the bread from the pot, and allow to cool on a wire rack for at least 20 minutes before slicing.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-knead-cranberry-nut-bread/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store leftover bread at room temperature for up to 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-knead-cranberry-nut-bread/#instruction-step-7"}], "prepTime": "PT30M", "cookTime": "PT35M", "totalTime": "PT20H", "recipeYield": ["1", "1 loaf; 10-12 servings"], "recipeCategory": "Bread", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "396", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Cranberry Nut No Knead Bread | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "This cranberry nut bread means yeasted bread has never been easier. Spray 24-count mini muffin pan with nonstick spray. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/glazed-chocolate-donut-holes/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Sift the flour, sugar, and cocoa powder together in a large bowl. Sifting is important; you want to remove any clumps of cocoa. Mix in the baking powder, baking soda, and salt. Set aside.", "name": "Make the donuts", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/glazed-chocolate-donut-holes/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk the beaten eggs, milk, yogurt, and vanilla together until completely smooth. Whisk in the melted butter until combined. Slowly fold the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients. Careful not to overmix. Mix the two together only until no flour pockets remain. Over-handling this batter will make your donut holes dense and tough.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/glazed-chocolate-donut-holes/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon batter into the mini muffin tins, only about 3/4 of the way full. Bake for 10 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. Do not overbake them; they burn easily. Allow the donuts to cool for 5 minutes in the pan and then transfer to a wire rack to cool for 5 more minutes before glazing.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/glazed-chocolate-donut-holes/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "While the donuts are slightly cooling, make the glaze by sifting the confectioners sugar into a medium bowl. Stir in the milk, vanilla, and lemon juice until smooth and combined. Add more confectioners&#8217; sugar to make it thicker if desired; add more cream to make it thinner if desired. Dunk each slightly warm donut hole into the glaze using a fork or your fingers. Place on a wire rack on top of a large baking sheet to let the glaze drip down. Repeat dunking two to three more times if you want a thick glaze coating. I dunked mine three times. If you run out of glaze to dip each three times, make a bit more.", "name": "Make the glaze", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/glazed-chocolate-donut-holes/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Donut holes taste best served on the same day. This recipe may easily be halved. Store extras in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 3 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/glazed-chocolate-donut-holes/#instruction-step-6"}], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT10M", "totalTime": "PT45M", "recipeYield": ["36", "36 donut holes"], "recipeCategory": "Donuts", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "8", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Ulrike"}, "datePublished": "2025-04-10", "reviewBody": "Just got those out of the oven an hour ago . Did the Donut shape in a 6 donut\r\nPan and used a 6 muffin tin for the rest . Donuts 12 min muffins about 14 . Turned out great . My husband likes cake donuts and no frosting -dusting those with powdered sugar . Used Dutch processed cocoa because that is what I have in my pantry . A fun, make-ahead dessert for fall and Thanksgiving. You'll need six 8-ounce jars for this, such as these jars or these jars. You can also use smaller jars or glasses to yield more servings.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "pumpkin pie in a jar", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/11/pumpkin-pie-jar-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/11/pumpkin-pie-jar-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/11/pumpkin-pie-jar-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/11/pumpkin-pie-jar.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-pie-in-a-jar/", "recipeIngredient": ["5 large egg yolks, cold or room temperature", "3 and 1/2 Tablespoons (28g) cornstarch", "1 and 2/3 cups (400g/ml) whole milk (do not use low-fat or nondairy)", "2/3 cup (133g) granulated sugar", "2 Tablespoons (28g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 cup (226g) canned pumpkin puree", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract or vanilla bean paste", "1 and 1/4 teaspoons store-bought or homemade pumpkin pie spice", "pinch salt (less than 1/8 teaspoon)", "24\u201328 ginger snaps or Biscoff cookies (about 190g)", "1 Tablespoon (14g) unsalted butter", "1 teaspoon light or dark brown sugar", "1 cup (240g/ml) heavy cream\u00a0or\u00a0heavy whipping cream, very cold", "2 Tablespoons light or dark brown sugar or granulated sugar", "1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract or vanilla bean paste", "1/2 teaspoon pumpkin pie spice", "optional:\u00a0crushed ginger snap/Biscoff crumbs, for topping"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large heatproof bowl (preferably with a pour spout), whisk the egg yolks and cornstarch together with a fork. It may not look like it will all come together (it will be dry at first), but keep mixing until the mixture is thick and combined. If it&#8217;s not coming together at all, add a few drops of the milk you need in step 2 to bring it together. Set aside.", "name": "Make the pumpkin pastry cream", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-pie-in-a-jar/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Combine the milk and sugar in a medium saucepan over medium heat. Whisk until the sugar has dissolved, then allow to come to a simmer. If you have an instant-read thermometer, the temperature should reach 210\u00b0F (99\u00b0C). Remove from heat. Pour the warm milk and sugar mixture in a slow and steady stream into the egg yolk and cornstarch mixture, whisking the entire time. Keep those egg yolks moving so they don\u2019t scramble. Once that&#8217;s all combined, add the pumpkin and whisk to combine. Pour the mixture back into the saucepan through a sieve, to strain out any egg yolk solids that may have formed during tempering. Use a spatula or the back of a spoon to gently press any remaining pumpkin through the sieve.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-pie-in-a-jar/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Return the saucepan to medium heat, and whisk constantly until the mixture has thickened into a pudding-like consistency. This usually takes about 5 minutes. (For a more accurate test, it&#8217;s done when the temperature reaches 185\u2013190\u00b0F (85\u201388\u00b0C).) Remove from heat. Whisk in butter, vanilla, pumpkin pie spice, and a pinch of salt.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-pie-in-a-jar/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Transfer the pumpkin pastry cream to a heatproof bowl and place a piece of plastic wrap or parchment directly on the surface of the pastry cream, to prevent a skin from forming. Allow to cool at room temperature for 10 minutes, then place the bowl in the refrigerator. Refrigerate for at least 3 hours, and up to 2 days. Makes about 3 cups, around 720g. After chilling, the pumpkin pastry cream is quite thick; whisk or stir it to smooth out again before using in step 7.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-pie-in-a-jar/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the ginger snaps/Biscoff in a zipped-top bag and crush with a rolling pin until you have small crumbs with a few larger bits. Melt the butter with the brown sugar in a large nonstick skillet over medium-low heat. Add the cookie crumbs to the skillet and cook, stirring with a silicone spatula or wooden spoon, until lightly toasted, about 3 minutes. Remove from heat and allow to cool completely.", "name": "Meanwhile, make the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-pie-in-a-jar/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, whip the heavy cream, sugar, vanilla extract, and pumpkin pie spice on medium-high speed until medium peaks form, about 3 minutes. Medium peaks are between soft/loose peaks and stiff peaks, and are the perfect consistency for topping and piping on desserts. If you accidentally over-whip the cream, and it looks curdled and heavy, pour in a little bit more cold heavy cream, and fold it in gently by hand with a spatula until it smooths out.", "name": "Make the spiced whipped cream", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-pie-in-a-jar/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon 1/4 cup (about 30g) of the crust into each jar. Spoon or pipe 1/2 cup (about 120g) of the pumpkin custard on top of the crust layer. I used Wilton 2A for the custard. Spoon or pipe whipped cream on top of each. I used Wilton 8B for the whipped cream. If desired, garnish each with a sprinkle of pumpkin pie spice or crushed cookie crumbs.", "name": "Assemble &amp; serve", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-pie-in-a-jar/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Serve immediately, or loosely cover the jars and refrigerate for up to 2 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-pie-in-a-jar/#instruction-step-10"}], "prepTime": "PT45M", "cookTime": "PT20M", "totalTime": "PT4H5M", "recipeYield": ["6", "6 jars"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Cooking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "10", "ratingValue": "5"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Pumpkin Pie in a Jar", "description": "These pumpkin pies in a jar deliver all the spiced, creamy richness of the classic dessert\u2014no oven required. It's going to give you the same results. You can use it as the filling inside the cupcakes and in place of the raspberry jam in the frosting. If you decide to do this, make the raspberry filling on the stove before you begin the cupcakes so it can cool completely.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-lemon-cupcakes/#faq-question-1722870035674", "position": 2, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-lemon-cupcakes/#faq-question-1722870035674", "name": "Can I use another flavor jam?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes. Feel free to skip the jam filling and keep these cupcakes un-filled.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-lemon-cupcakes/#faq-question-1722903118801", "position": 4, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-lemon-cupcakes/#faq-question-1722903118801", "name": "Can I use freeze-dried raspberries in the frosting instead of jam?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes, you can swap the frosting below with this <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-frosting/\">strawberry buttercream</a>, using freeze-dried raspberries instead of freeze-dried strawberries.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Lemon Raspberry Jam Cupcakes", "description": "These sunshine-inspired lemon raspberry jam cupcakes combine deliciously soft and moist lemon cake, sweet raspberry jam, and creamy-rich raspberry buttercream. Every bite is bursting with bright and fruity flavor, so they're the perfect dessert in the spring and summertime. I used Wilton 1M to pipe the frosting on the pictured cupcakes.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "lemon raspberry cupcakes", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/lemon-raspberry-jam-cupcakes-3-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/lemon-raspberry-jam-cupcakes-3-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/lemon-raspberry-jam-cupcakes-3-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/lemon-raspberry-jam-cupcakes-3.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-lemon-cupcakes/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 1/2 cups (188g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 teaspoons baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 cup (200g) granulated sugar", "1 Tablespoon lemon zest", "2 large eggs, at room temperature", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons\u00a0pure vanilla extract", "1/2 cup (120ml) whole milk or buttermilk, at room temperature", "1/4 cup (60ml) fresh lemon juice\u00a0", "1/2 cup (165g) thick raspberry preserves or jam*", "3/4 cups (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3 and 1/2 cups (420g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1/2 cup (165g) thick raspberry preserves or jam*", "1 Tablespoon whole milk, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1 teaspoon fresh lemon juice", "1/8 teaspoon salt", "optional for garnish: fresh raspberries and lemon slices"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line a 12-cup muffin pan with cupcake liners.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-lemon-cupcakes/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Whisk the flour, baking powder, and salt together in a large bowl. Set aside.", "name": "Make the batter", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-lemon-cupcakes/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter, sugar, and lemon zest together on medium-high speed in a large bowl until creamed, about 3 minutes. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add eggs and vanilla extract, and then beat on medium-high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. Add the dry ingredients and then turn the mixer on low speed and slowly pour in the milk and lemon juice. Beat until just combined. Do not overmix.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-lemon-cupcakes/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour/spoon the batter evenly into the liners. Bake for 18\u201321 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. Allow the cupcakes to cool completely before filling and frosting.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-lemon-cupcakes/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a sharp knife, cut a circle into the center of the cooled cupcakes to create a little pocket about 1 inch deep. The piece you removed will be sort of cone-shaped. Spoon jam inside each carved-out cupcake\u2014use however much will fit. (I use a teaspoon for this. Usually you can fit between 1\u20132 teaspoons of filling in each.) Slice/tear off the pointy end of the \u201ccone\u201d piece of cupcake you removed, and gently press the round piece back on top of the filling. See my How to Fill Cupcakes post if you need extra visuals or help with this step.", "name": "Fill the cupcakes", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-lemon-cupcakes/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Beat softened butter on medium speed for about 3-4 minutes until completely smooth and creamy. Add the confectioners&#8217; sugar, jam, milk, vanilla extract, lemon juice, and salt. Start the mixer on low speed and beat for 30 seconds. Turn it up to high speed and beat for 1 minute or until combined. Beat in more confectioners&#8217; sugar if frosting is too thin, is separating (due to the juicy jam), or looks too wet. Taste; beat in more salt if too sweet.", "name": "Make the frosting:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-lemon-cupcakes/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Frost cooled cupcakes and top each with a fresh raspberry and lemon slice, if desired. You can swipe the frosting on with an icing knife or use a piping tip such as Wilton 1M or\u00a0Ateco 826. This is a softer-style buttercream and does not crust. If the cupcakes sit out for several hours, or are in the direct heat, the frosting will begin to lose shape. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/salted-caramel-pretzel-crunch-bars/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on high speed until smooth and creamy\u2014about 1 minute. Add the flour, sugar, salt, egg yolk, and vanilla extract and beat on high speed for 2 minutes until crumbly. Get your hands in there to make the dough come together. Press tightly into prepared pan. Press pretzel pieces evenly on top. Bake for 20 minutes. Allow to cool completely before adding the caramel (I stick it in the refrigerator to speed this up).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/salted-caramel-pretzel-crunch-bars/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Prepare the salted caramel and wait for it to cool until it slightly thickens. Pour/spoon over crust. Allow to cool and set completely before topping with chocolate. Again, I stick it in the refrigerator to speed it up.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/salted-caramel-pretzel-crunch-bars/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt the chocolate and coconut oil in the microwave in 15 second increments, stopping and stirring until completely melted. Pour over cooled caramel. Top with sea salt. Stick in the refrigerator to cool completely.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/salted-caramel-pretzel-crunch-bars/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lift the parchment paper\u00a0out of the pan using the overhang on the sides and cut into squares. It will make you a pie expert immediately! Complete with all my tips and troubleshooting, this pie crust recipe is buttery, flaky, and tender with the most incredible flavor. This recipe is also in my cookbook, Sally's Baking 101.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "pie crust", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/all-butter-pie-crust-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/all-butter-pie-crust-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/all-butter-pie-crust-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/all-butter-pie-crust-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/all-butter-pie-crust/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 1/2 cups (313g) all-purpose flour, plus more as needed\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 teaspoons granulated sugar", "1 teaspoon salt", "1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g) unsalted butter, chilled and cubed", "1/2 cup (120ml) ice water, plus more as needed"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, and salt together. Add the cold cubed butter on top. Using a pastry cutter, food processor, or two forks (pastry cutter is ideal, see post above), cut or pulse the butter into the dry ingredients until it resembles coarse meal. You&#8217;re looking for pea-sized bits of flour-coated butter. A few larger bits of butter is OK.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/all-butter-pie-crust/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Drizzle the cold water over the surface of the flour mixture, 1 Tablespoon at a time, and stir after each addition. Stop adding water when the dough comes together easily and begins to form large clumps. The dough will feel moist and a little sticky, but not feel overly wet. Do not add any more water than you need to. I always use about 1/2 cup (120ml) of ice water.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/all-butter-pie-crust/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Transfer the dough to a lightly floured work surface. Using floured hands, gently bring the dough mixture together into a ball. Avoid overworking the dough. If it feels too dry or is too crumbly to form a ball, dip your fingers in cold water and then continue bringing the dough together. If it feels too sticky, sprinkle on a little more flour and continue bringing it together. Using a sharp knife or bench scraper, divide the dough in half. Using your hands, gently flatten each half into a 1-inch-thick disc.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/all-butter-pie-crust/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Wrap each disc tightly in plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 2\u00a0hours and up to 5 days before using in a pie recipe.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/all-butter-pie-crust/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "After refrigerating, the dough is ready to roll out and use in a pie recipe. Proceed with the pie per your recipe&#8217;s instructions. TIP: When rolling out the chilled pie dough discs, use gentle force with your rolling pin. Start from the center of the disc and work your way out in all directions, turning the dough with your hands between rolls. Smooth out the edges if you notice cracks. (See video.) Keeping your work surface, rolling pin, and hands lightly floured makes rolling out easier.\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/all-butter-pie-crust/#instruction-step-5"}], "prepTime": "PT20M", "cookTime": "", "totalTime": "PT2H20M", "recipeYield": ["2", "2 pie crusts"], "recipeCategory": "Pie", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "148", "ratingValue": "4.7"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "All Butter Pie Crust | Sally's Baking Recipes", "description": "This homemade pie crust is buttery, flaky, and tender with the most incredible flavor. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) On medium speed, add the eggs one at a time, beating well after each addition. Beat in the sour cream and vanilla extract on medium speed until combined. With the mixer running on low speed, add the dry ingredients and milk into the wet ingredients and beat until combined. Batter is thick and creamy. Fold in the blueberries.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-muffins/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon the batter into liners, filling them all the way to the top. Spoon brown sugar topping on each, gently pressing it down into the surface so it sticks. Bake for 5 minutes at 425 then, keeping the muffins in the oven, reduce the oven temperature to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Bake for an additional 18\u201320 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. The total time these muffins take in the oven is about 23\u201325 minutes, give or take. The batter will be light brown and look a bit dull.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/seriously-fudgy-homemade-brownies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the cocoa powder, flour, salt, remaining 2 ounces/57g chopped chocolate, and the chocolate chips. Insert it into the center of the pan. If it comes out with wet batter, the brownies are not done. If there are only a few moist crumbs, the brownies are done. Keep checking every 2 minutes until you have moist crumbs. S'mores have never tasted so good!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "s'mores cupcakes", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Smore-Cupcakes-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Smore-Cupcakes-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Smore-Cupcakes-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Smore-Cupcakes.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/marshmallow-filled-smores-cupcakes/", "recipeIngredient": ["1/2 cup (41g) unsweetened cocoa powder*", "3/4 cup (94g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda", "3/4 teaspoon baking powder", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "2 large eggs, at room temperature*", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "1/2 cup (100g) packed\u00a0light brown sugar", "1/3 cup (80ml) vegetable oil (melted coconut oil works too)", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1/2 cup (120ml) buttermilk*", "1/4 cup (4 Tbsp; 56g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "2/3 cup JET-PUFFED marshmallow creme (Fluff)", "1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) heavy cream*", "3/4 &#8211; 1 cup (90-120g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "1 and 3/4 cups (210g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1/4 cup (21g) unsweetened cocoa powder", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) heavy cream*", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "salt, to taste", "12 JET-PUFFED marshmallows", "4 full-sheet graham crackers, crushed"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line a 12-count muffin pan with cupcake liners. Line a second pan with 2 liners\u2014this recipe makes about 14 cupcakes. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/marshmallow-filled-smores-cupcakes/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl, whisk the cocoa powder, flour, baking soda, baking powder, and salt together until thoroughly combined. Set aside. In a medium bowl, whisk the eggs, sugar, brown sugar, oil, and vanilla together until completely smooth. Pour half of the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients. Then half of the buttermilk. Gently stir\u2014about 5 stirs. Repeat with the remaining wet ingredients and buttermilk. Stir until *just* combined; do not overmix. The batter won&#8217;t be very thick.", "name": "Make the cupcakes", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/marshmallow-filled-smores-cupcakes/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour/spoon the batter into the liners\u2014fill only halfway to avoid spilling over the sides. Bake in batches for 18-19 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. Gradually add the sifted sugar/cocoa powder alternately with the heavy cream and vanilla. Beat on low speed after each addition.
