Transfer to another bowl. Using the same mixing bowl you just had the egg whites in (no need to clean it), add the egg yolks, remaining sugar, buttermilk, vanilla extract, and vanilla bean. Do not overmix.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberries-n-cream-cake-roll/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread batter evenly into prepared pan. Give the pan a shake to make sure the batter is level and reaches the corners.\u00a0Bake for 15 minutes or until the cake springs back when you poke it with a finger.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberries-n-cream-cake-roll/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "As the cake bakes, lay a thin kitchen\u00a0towel flat\u00a0on the counter. Sprinkle with 1 cup of confectioners&#8217; sugar. Once the cake comes out of the oven, immediately invert it onto the towel. Peel off the parchment paper then, starting with the narrow end, begin rolling the cake up with the towel. Do this slowly and gently. The cake will be warm as it just came out of the oven.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberries-n-cream-cake-roll/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Allow the cake to cool completely rolled up in the towel. You should have around 1/2 cup. Set aside.\u00a0In a large bowl using a hand-held or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the cream cheese\u00a0for 1 minute on high speed until completely smooth and creamy. Beat in the butter until combined. Add the confectioners&#8217; sugar, strawberry powder, and vanilla and beat on medium-high speed until combined and creamy. Taste, then add a pinch of salt if needed.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberries-n-cream-cake-roll/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Gently and slowly unroll the cake. Flatten it out and spread frosting evenly on top, leaving about a 1/2 inch border around the cake. Gently and slowly roll the cake back up, without the towel this time. Make sure you&#8217;re rolling it tightly. Some frosting may spill out the sides, that&#8217;s ok!\u00a0Loosely cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 20 minutes before slicing and serving. While that recipe was dry, this roll was delicious, properly spongy without being dry even after refrigeration. Two changes that I made: I only used 1/2 cup of confectioners sugar for rolling the cake in the towel, and I only used 2/3 cup of confectioners sugar in the filling instead of the 2.5 cups, making the tartness of the cream cheese shine through. They're delicious plain, or topped with spiced cream cheese frosting. Careful not to over-bake these; they'll still feel and look quite soft on top, but the bars set as they cool. This recipe is also in my New York Times best-selling cookbook, Sally's Baking 101.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "gingerbread cookie bars", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/gingerbread-cookie-bars-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/gingerbread-cookie-bars-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/gingerbread-cookie-bars-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/gingerbread-cookie-bars-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-cookie-bars/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 1/4 cups (281g) all-purpose flour", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons baking soda", "2 teaspoons ground ginger", "1 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1/4 teaspoon ground allspice", "1/4 teaspoon ground cloves", "1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg", "small pinch of ground black pepper", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, melted", "1/2 cup (100g) packed light or dark brown sugar (I recommend dark)", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "1/3 cup\u00a0 (113g/80ml) unsulphured molasses (do not use blackstrap; I prefer Grandma&#8217;s brand)", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "6 ounces (170g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "2 Tablespoons (28g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 and 1/2 cups (180g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "small pinch each of ground ginger, cinnamon, &amp; allspice", "optional for garnish: sprinkles"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Adjust oven rack to the center rack position. Line a 9&#215;13-inch metal or glass baking pan with parchment paper, leaving an overhang on the sides to easily lift the bars out of the pan. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-cookie-bars/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking soda, ginger, cinnamon, allspice, cloves, nutmeg, pepper, and salt together in a large bowl. Set aside.", "name": "Make the cookie bars", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-cookie-bars/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk the melted butter, brown sugar, granulated sugar, and molasses together until no lumps remain. Whisk in the egg and vanilla. Pour the butter mixture into the flour mixture and mix with a large spoon or silicone spatula until no traces of flour remain. The dough will be thick and shiny. Transfer the dough to the prepared baking pan and press it into a smooth, even layer. It may not seem like enough dough, and it will be a thin layer\u2014that&#8217;s OK.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-cookie-bars/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 23\u201326 minutes or until the top is set but still looks quite soft and a toothpick inserted in the center comes out mostly clean with only a few moist crumbs. Err on the side of under-baking. Bars puff up in the oven, but settle and firm up as they cool. Allow the bars to cool in the pan set on a cooling rack for at least 1 hour.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-cookie-bars/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the cream cheese and butter together on medium-high speed until smooth, about 2 minutes. Scrape down the sides of the bowl as needed. Add the confectioners&#8217; sugar, ginger, cinnamon, allspice, and vanilla extract. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to high speed and beat for 2 minutes until completely combined and creamy. Taste and beat in a pinch of salt if the frosting is too sweet. Spread the frosting on the cooled bars. Top with sprinkles, if desired. To help set the frosting, refrigerate for 30 minutes before slicing and serving.", "name": "Make the frosting", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-cookie-bars/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lift the bars out of the pan by gripping the parchment paper overhang; transfer to a cutting board and cut into squares. Fall breakfast has never tasted so good!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "apple cinnamon rolls", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/apple-cinnamon-rolls-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/apple-cinnamon-rolls-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/apple-cinnamon-rolls-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/apple-cinnamon-rolls.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-rolls/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (240ml) whole milk, warmed to about 100\u00b0F (38\u00b0C)", "2/3 cup (135g) granulated sugar, divided", "1 and 1/2 Tablespoons (14g) Platinum Yeast from Red Star (2 standard&#8211;size packets)*", "1/2 cup (113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature and cut into 4 pieces", "2 large eggs, at room temperature", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "4 and 1/2 cups (563g) all-purpose flour or bread flour (spoon &amp; leveled), plus more as needed", "6 Tablespoons (85g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1/2 cup (100g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1 and 1/2 Tablespoons ground cinnamon", "2 cups (250g) peeled chopped apples (about 2 medium apples)", "1 cup (120g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "2 Tablespoons milk", "2 Tablespoons warmed\u00a0salted caramel"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the warm milk, 2 Tablespoons sugar, and the yeast together in the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a dough hook or paddle attachment. Cover and allow mixture to sit for about 5 minutes or until foamy on top. *If you do not own a mixer, you can do this in a large mixing bowl and in the next step, mix the dough together with a large wooden spoon/silicone spatula. It will take a bit of arm muscle. A hand mixer works, but the sticky dough repeatedly gets stuck in the beaters. Mixing by hand with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula is a better choice.*", "name": "Prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "On medium speed, beat in the remaining sugar (which should be 1/2 cup/100g) and the softened butter until it is slightly broken up. Add the eggs and salt and beat on medium speed until combined. The butter won&#8217;t really be mixing into the mixture, so don&#8217;t be alarmed if it stays in pieces. Switch the mixer down to low speed and with it running, add 1 cup of flour at a time, making sure it&#8217;s fully incorporated before adding the next. After 4 cups have been added, add the last 1/2 cup and beat until the dough comes together and pulls away from the sides of the bowl, about 3 minutes. Dough will be soft.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or use nonstick spray. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides in the oil. Cover the bowl with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the dough to rise in a relatively warm environment for 2 hours or until double in size. (I always let it rise on the counter and it takes about 2 hours. For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to Where Should Dough Rise? in my Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "1st Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease the bottom and sides of a metal or glass 9&#215;13-inch baking dish or line with parchment paper.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Punch down the dough to release the air. Place dough on a lightly floured work surface and using a lightly floured rolling pin, roll dough into a 12&#215;18-inch rectangle. Make sure the dough is smooth and evenly thick. If the dough keeps shrinking as you roll it out, stop what you&#8217;re doing, cover it lightly, and let it rest for 10 minutes to relax the gluten. When you return to the dough, it should stretch out much easier.", "name": "Roll out the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread the softened butter all over the dough. In a small bowl, toss the brown sugar and cinnamon together until combined and then sprinkle evenly over the dough. Top evenly with chopped apples. Tightly roll up the dough to form an 18-inch-long log. Cut into 12 equal rolls. Arrange them in the prepared baking pan. Cover the rolls very tightly with aluminum foil.", "name": "Fill the rolls", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover the rolls tightly and allow to rise until puffy, about 45-60 minutes.(Or use the overnight option in the Notes below).", "name": "2nd rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 375\u00b0F (191\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for about 25 minutes or until they lightly browned on top. About halfway through baking time, tent a piece of aluminum foil over the pan to prevent the tops from browning too quickly. Remove pan from the oven and place pan on a wire rack for about 10 minutes as you make the icing.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk all of the icing ingredients together and drizzle over warm rolls. Line a 12&#215;17-inch baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/quick-easy-honey-pear-tart/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Unroll the pastry sheets on a floured work surface. Place the edge of one over the other and use a rolling pin to adhere them together. Roll the whole thing out into a 10&#215;14-inch rectangle. Fold over the edges and crimp down with a fork. Crimping is much easier the colder the pastry is, so place into the refrigerator to chill if needed. Review my how to crimp and flute pie crust tutorial if you need extra help with this step.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/quick-easy-honey-pear-tart/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Brush the entire pastry, edges included, with egg wash. The recipe yields enough dough for two small flatbreads, each perfect for 1 hungry person or 2 people to split (2-4 people total). Freezing instructions listed below. See all of my detailed topping suggestions in the blog post above or recipe notes below.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "flatbread, flatbread pizza", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/homemade-flatbread-pizza-recipe-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/homemade-flatbread-pizza-recipe-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/homemade-flatbread-pizza-recipe-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/homemade-flatbread-pizza-recipe.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-flatbread-pizza-recipe/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 teaspoon active dry or instant yeast", "1 teaspoon granulated sugar", "3/4 cup (180ml) warm water, (between 100-110\u00b0F, 38-43\u00b0C)", "2 cups (250g) all-purpose flour or bread flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more for hands and surface", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) olive oil, plus 2 teaspoons for brushing the dough", "1 teaspoon salt", "optional: 1 teaspoon garlic powder or 1 clove minced garlic and/or 1 teaspoon Italian seasoning"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the yeast, sugar, and warm water together in the bowl of your stand mixer. Loosely cover and allow to sit for 5\u201310 minutes until foamy and frothy on top. *If you do not own a stand mixer, you can do this in a large mixing bowl and in the next step, mix the dough together with a large wooden spoon/silicone spatula. It will take a bit of arm muscle. A hand mixer works, but the sticky dough repeatedly gets stuck in the beaters. Mixing by hand with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula is a better choice.*", "name": "Prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-flatbread-pizza-recipe/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the flour, olive oil, and salt (and garlic/seasoning if using). Mix on low speed with the dough hook attachment until combined, about 2 minutes. The dough should be thick, yet soft and slightly sticky. It should pull away from the sides of the bowl as it mixes. When it does, it is ready to knead. If, however, the dough is too sticky to handle, mix in more flour, 1 Tablespoon at a time. Make sure you do not add too much extra flour; you want a soft, slightly tacky dough.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-flatbread-pizza-recipe/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Keep the dough in the mixer (and switch to the dough hook if using the paddle) and beat for an additional 6-8 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 6-8 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-flatbread-pizza-recipe/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the dough in a greased bowl (I use nonstick spray to grease) and cover with plastic wrap, aluminum foil, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow to sit and rest for 45 minutes at room temperature. Once it has rested and slightly risen, you can continue with the recipe or place the covered dough in the refrigerator for up to 2 days. More instructions in the make ahead Note below.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-flatbread-pizza-recipe/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "As the dough is resting and rising, prepare your toppings. See blog post and/or recipe note below.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-flatbread-pizza-recipe/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 475\u00b0F (246\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-flatbread-pizza-recipe/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Punch the dough down to release any air. Divide the dough in half. On a lightly floured surface with floured hands and working with one dough piece at a time, begin shaping and stretching the dough until it is 1/4 inch thick. You can use a floured rolling pin for this too. Don&#8217;t worry about the shape of the dough, just make sure it&#8217;s pretty thin. Repeat with the second piece of dough. Carefully transfer both pieces of dough to a parchment paper or silicone-mat lined baking sheet, or use a pizza stone. (You can also shape/roll out the doughs directly on a silicone baking mat or a large sheet of parchment if that is easier for you and then just transfer the whole thing to the baking sheet.)", "name": "Shape the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-flatbread-pizza-recipe/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Poke your fingers all around the surface of the flatbreads or prick a few holes with a fork. Drizzle or brush each with 1 teaspoon of olive oil. Top each with your favorite toppings.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-flatbread-pizza-recipe/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 15\u201320 minutes or until the crust and toppings are browned to your liking. Remove from the oven. (454g) fresh or frozen cranberries", "1 cup (240g/ml) orange juice", "1 cup (200g) granulated sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "2 large egg yolks, at room temperature", "2 Tablespoons cornstarch", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "3 Tablespoons (43g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract\u00a0or vanilla bean paste", "1 cup (240g/ml) heavy cream, cold", "2 Tablespoons granulated or confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract or vanilla bean paste", "optional: sugared cranberries, for garnish"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Lightly grease a 9-inch tart pan with a removable base with nonstick spray.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cranberry-curd-tart/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If you\u2019re starting out with full graham crackers, use a\u00a0food processor or blender to grind them into fine crumbs. Stir the graham cracker crumbs and granulated sugar together in a medium bowl, and then stir in the melted butter. The mixture will be thick, coarse, and sandy. Try to smash/break up any large chunks. Pour the mixture into the prepared tart pan. With medium pressure using your hand, pat the crumbs down into the bottom and up the sides to make a compact crust. Do not pack down with heavy force because that makes the crust too hard. Simply pat down until the mixture is no longer crumby/crumbly. For more shaping technique tips, see the graham cracker crust recipe page.", "name": "Make the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cranberry-curd-tart/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the crust for 10 minutes. Set aside on a cooling rack.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cranberry-curd-tart/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium saucepan over medium heat, combine the cranberries, orange juice, and sugar. Bring to a boil and cook, stirring with a silicone spatula or wooden spoon, until the cranberries have all burst, about 10 minutes. You can mash them against the sides of the saucepan with your spatula to help them along. Remove from heat and allow to cool for at least 20 minutes.", "name": "Make the cranberry filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cranberry-curd-tart/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Transfer the cranberry mixture to a high-powered blender or food processor and puree until completely smooth, and no specks of cranberry skins remain. Pour the cranberry puree back into the saucepan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cranberry-curd-tart/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a small bowl or liquid measuring cup, combine the egg, egg yolks, cornstarch, and salt. Whisk or stir with a fork until completely combined and smooth. Pour and whisk the egg mixture into the cranberry puree.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cranberry-curd-tart/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Return the saucepan to the stove over medium heat and allow the cranberry curd to come to a boil, stirring constantly. Once boiling, reduce the heat to medium-low and simmer, stirring with a silicone spatula and scraping the bottom and sides of the saucepan to keep the curd from sticking, until thickened, about 5\u20137 minutes. If you\u2019d like to be precise and use a candy or instant-read thermometer, the temperature will rise to about 200\u00b0F (93\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cranberry-curd-tart/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove from heat and whisk in the butter and vanilla extract until the butter is melted and fully incorporated. Pour the filling into the crust and smooth the top (I use a small offset spatula for this). Let cool at room temperature for 30\u201345 minutes, and then place in the refrigerator and chill for at least 6 hours, or overnight.\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cranberry-curd-tart/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, whip the heavy cream, sugar, and vanilla extract on medium-high speed until medium peaks form, about 3 minutes. Medium peaks are between soft/loose peaks and stiff peaks, and are the perfect consistency for topping and piping on desserts. If you accidentally over-whip the cream, and it looks curdled and heavy, pour in a little bit more cold heavy cream, and fold it in gently by hand with a spatula until it smooths out.", "name": "Make the whipped cream", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cranberry-curd-tart/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread the whipped cream on top of the tart. Garnish with sugared cranberries, if desired. Remove the rim of the tart pan, slice, serve, and enjoy!", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cranberry-curd-tart/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store leftover tart in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cranberry-curd-tart/#instruction-step-11"}], "prepTime": "PT20M", "cookTime": "PT25M", "totalTime": "PT7H", "recipeYield": ["1", "1 9-inch tart"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Cooking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "21", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "SUSAN M WEBSTER"}, "datePublished": "2025-11-27", "reviewBody": "Our families favorite Thanksgiving dessert. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. Beat in egg, egg yolk, and vanilla extract. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. With the mixer running on low speed, slowly add dry ingredients to wet ingredients. Pour in 1 cup M&amp;Ms and beat on low speed for 20 seconds or until combined. You can also reference my Baking with Yeast Guide for answers to common yeast FAQs.\u00a0This recipe is also in my cookbook, Sally's Baking 101.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "bread, rolls, yeast rolls", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/dinner-rolls-in-pan-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/dinner-rolls-in-pan-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/dinner-rolls-in-pan-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/dinner-rolls-in-pan.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-dinner-rolls/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (240ml) whole milk, warmed to about 110\u00b0F (43\u00b0C)", "2 and 1/4 teaspoons Platinum Yeast from Red Star instant yeast (1 standard packet)", "2 Tablespoons granulated sugar, divided", "1 large egg", "1/4 cup (4 Tbsp; 56g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature and cut into 4 pieces", "1 teaspoon salt", "3 cups (390g) all-purpose flour or bread flour* (spooned &amp; leveled)", "optional topping: 2 Tablespoons (28g) melted unsalted butter mixed with 1 Tablespoon honey"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the warm milk, yeast, and 1 Tablespoon of sugar together in the bowl of your stand mixer. Cover and allow to sit for 5 minutes. *If you do not own a stand mixer, you can do this in a large mixing bowl and in the next step, mix the dough together with a large wooden spoon/silicone spatula. It will take a bit of arm muscle. A hand mixer works, but the sticky dough repeatedly gets stuck in the beaters. Mixing by hand with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula is a better choice.*", "name": "Prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-dinner-rolls/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the remaining sugar, egg, butter, salt, and 1 cup flour. With a dough hook or paddle attachment, mix/beat on low speed for 30 seconds, scrape down the sides of the bowl with a silicone spatula, then add the remaining flour. Beat on medium speed until the dough comes together and pulls away from the sides of the bowl, about 2 minutes. If the dough seems too wet to a point where kneading (next step) would be impossible, beat in more flour 1 Tablespoon at a time until you have a workable dough, similar to the photos above. Dough should be soft and a little sticky, but still manageable to knead with lightly floured hands.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-dinner-rolls/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-dinner-rolls/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or nonstick spray. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides in the oil. Cover the bowl with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the dough to rise in a relatively warm environment for 1-2 hours or until double in size. (I always let it rise on the counter. Takes about 2 hours. For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to Where Should Dough Rise? in my Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "1st Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-dinner-rolls/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease a 9&#215;13 inch baking pan or two 9-inch square or round baking pans. You can also bake the rolls in a cast iron skillet or on a lined baking sheet.*", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-dinner-rolls/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When the dough is ready, punch it down to release the air. Divide the dough into 14-16 equal pieces. (Just eyeball it\u2013 doesn\u2019t need to be perfect!) A bench scraper is always helpful for cutting dough. Shape each piece into a smooth ball. Arrange in prepared baking pan.", "name": "Shape the rolls", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-dinner-rolls/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover shaped rolls with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow to rise until puffy, about 1 hour.", "name": "2nd Rise:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-dinner-rolls/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Adjust oven rack to a lower position and preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). (It&#8217;s best to bake the rolls towards the bottom of the oven so the tops don&#8217;t burn.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-dinner-rolls/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 20-25 minutes or until golden brown on top, rotating the pan halfway through. If you notice the tops browning too quickly, loosely tent the pan with aluminum foil. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. Add the eggs, yogurt, and vanilla extract. It's basically a giant Bundt pan of gooey cinnamon rolls! Finish this fun breakfast or dessert treat with vanilla icing and serve pull apart style.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "cinnamon rolls, breakfast", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/monkey-bread-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/monkey-bread-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/monkey-bread-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/monkey-bread.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-aka-cinnamon-roll-bites/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 1/2 cups (360ml) whole milk, warmed to about 110\u00b0F (43\u00b0C)", "2 and 1/4 teaspoons\u00a0Platinum Yeast from Red Star\u00a0(1 standard packet)", "1/4 cup (50g) granulated sugar", "2 large eggs", "1/3 cup (5 Tbsp; 71g) unsalted butter, melted and slightly cooled", "1 teaspoon salt", "5 cups (625g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, divided", "1 and 1/4 cups (250g) granulated sugar", "1 Tablespoon\u00a0ground cinnamon", "2/3 cup (130g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1 cup (120g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "3 Tablespoons (45ml) whole milk", "1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the warm milk, yeast, and sugar together in the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a dough hook or paddle attachment. Cover and allow to sit for 5 minutes.", "name": "Prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-aka-cinnamon-roll-bites/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the eggs, butter, salt, and 1 cup flour. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, scrape down the sides of the bowl with a silicone spatula, then add the remaining flour. Beat on medium speed until the dough comes together and pulls away from the sides of the bowl, about 2 minutes. *If you do not own a mixer, you can mix this dough with a large wooden spoon or silicone spatula. It will take a bit of arm muscle!*", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-aka-cinnamon-roll-bites/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 5-7 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5-7 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-aka-cinnamon-roll-bites/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or nonstick spray. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides in the oil. Cover the bowl with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the dough to rise in a relatively warm environment for 1-2 hours or until double in size. (I always let it rise on the counter. Takes about 2 hours. For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to\u00a0Where Should Dough Rise?\u00a0in my\u00a0Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "1st Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-aka-cinnamon-roll-bites/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Generously grease a\u00a010-12 cup Bundt pan with butter or nonstick spray. (Nonstick spray is best for this recipe.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-aka-cinnamon-roll-bites/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt 1/2 cup (115g;1 stick) of unsalted butter in a medium bowl. Mix granulated sugar and cinnamon together in another medium bowl. You will use the rest of the butter, brown sugar, and vanilla later.", "name": "Prepare the coating", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-aka-cinnamon-roll-bites/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Use the video tutorial above as a guide for this step. When the dough is ready, punch it down to release the air. Working one at a time, take small pieces of dough and roll into balls (about 1.25 inches in diameter each). You will need 40-45 balls total, so be modest with their size. Dip each ball, one by one, in the melted butter and then generously roll in the cinnamon-sugar mixture to coat them. You may need more cinnamon-sugar depending how heavy you coat each ball. Arrange the balls in the Bundt pan as you go. Cover the pan with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel and allow the shaped monkey bread to rest for 20 minutes. The balls will slightly rise during this time.", "name": "Shape the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-aka-cinnamon-roll-bites/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Adjust oven rack to a lower position and preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).\u00a0(It\u2019s best to bake the monkey bread towards the bottom of the oven so the top doesn&#8217;t burn.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-aka-cinnamon-roll-bites/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt remaining 1/4 cup (60g; 4 Tbsp) butter, then whisk in the brown sugar and vanilla extract. Pour evenly all over the shaped monkey bread.", "name": "Finish the coating", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-aka-cinnamon-roll-bites/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 35-45 minutes or until golden brown on top. Cover loosely with foil if the top is browning too quickly. Cool for 5-10 minutes, then invert onto a large serving plate or cake stand.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-aka-cinnamon-roll-bites/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk all of the icing ingredients together. Drizzle over monkey bread. Cut the bread into generous slices or let everyone pick off the gooey pieces themselves. That&#8217;s the fun of this treat!", "name": "Make the icing", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-aka-cinnamon-roll-bites/#instruction-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Monkey bread tastes best served on the same day. Cover leftovers tightly and store at room temperature for 1 day and in the refrigerator for up to 4 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-aka-cinnamon-roll-bites/#instruction-step-12"}], "prepTime": "PT2H40M", "cookTime": "PT40M", "totalTime": "PT3H20M", "recipeYield": ["12", "12-14 servings"], "recipeCategory": "Breakfast", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "131", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Homemade Monkey Bread | Sally's Baking Recipes", "description": "Monkey bread combines several tiny balls of dough coated in butter, cinnamon, and sugar. Set aside. In a large bowl, whisk together bananas, peanut butter, oil, egg and sugars.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-swirled-peanut-butter-banana-bread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour dry ingredients into wet ingredients and stir until just combined. Batter will be very thick. Do not overmix. Fold in Reese\u2019s cups and chocolate chips. Spread batter into prepared pan. Drop 3 tablespoons of Nutella on top of bread in a row. Swirl with a knife.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-swirled-peanut-butter-banana-bread/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for about 50 minutes or until toothpick inserted into center comes out clean. Baking times may vary.\u00a0Let cool in loaf pan for 10 minutes, then loosen the edges of the pan with a knife and remove from loaf pan, transferring bread to a cooling rack. Use homemade pie crust for best flavor, or choose store-bought pie dough for a shortcut. Use the step photos above as your guide for shaping.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "pumpkin hand pies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/pumpkin-hand-pies-1-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/pumpkin-hand-pies-1-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/pumpkin-hand-pies-1-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/pumpkin-hand-pies-1.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-hand-pies/", "recipeIngredient": ["All-Butter Pie Dough (what I used) or Homemade Pie Dough", "egg wash: 1 large egg beaten with 1 Tablespoon\u00a0milk", "1 and 1/4 cups (282g) pumpkin puree*", "1 large egg", "6 Tablespoons (72g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1 Tablespoon all-purpose flour", "1 teaspoon pumpkin pie spice (store-bought or homemade pumpkin pie spice)", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "pinch of salt", "1 cup (120g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "3 Tablespoons (45ml) pure maple syrup", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) milk", "1/2 teaspoon maple extract or vanilla extract\u00a0", "pinch of salt"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Prepare either pie crust recipe through step 5. (Again, I use and recommend this all-butter pie dough.) The dough must chill for at least 2 hours in the refrigerator (or up to 5 days) before using.", "name": "Make the crust ahead", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-hand-pies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "On a lightly floured work surface, roll out one of the discs of chilled dough (keep the other one in the refrigerator). Turn the dough about a quarter turn after every few rolls. At any sign of sticking, sprinkle some flour underneath, then keep rolling. Roll out until it&#8217;s about 1/8\u20131/4-inch thick. Place a bowl that&#8217;s about 5 inches in diameter upside down on the pie dough. (If you don&#8217;t have a bowl this size, cut a 5-inch circle from a piece of paper and use that as your guide.) Using a sharp knife, cut around the outside of the bowl. You should now have a 5-inch circle of pie crust. Repeat; re-rolling scraps as needed. Place cut circles on a plate/baking sheet in the refrigerator to keep cold. The colder the shaped dough, the easier it is to work with. Repeat with 2nd disc of pie dough and refrigerate all cut circles for at least 15 minutes before filling the hand pies. You should have about 12\u201316 circles in total.", "name": "Roll out the pie dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-hand-pies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Meanwhile, preheat oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C). Line two large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-hand-pies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk together the pumpkin, egg, brown sugar, flour, pumpkin pie spice, vanilla extract, and salt until completely combined. (Makes about 1 and 1/2 cups of filling.)", "name": "Make the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-hand-pies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon and spread filling, about 1.5\u20132 Tablespoons per hand pie, onto one half of each crust circle, leaving a 1/4-inch border around the edges. Fold the bare half of the circle over top of the filling to make a half-moon shape. Press your fingers all around the edges to seal, then crimp the pie crust edges with a fork. Place the hand pies on the prepared baking sheets. Lightly brush the tops of the pies with egg wash. Using a sharp knife, cut 2\u20133 slits in the tops, to vent steam. At this point the hand pies can be baked, but if they don&#8217;t feel cool to the touch anymore, refrigerate for at least 15 minutes and up to 1 hour before baking. The colder they are going into the oven, the better they&#8217;ll hold their shape. (After 15 minutes, they may begin to leak a little pumpkin liquid out of the sides. That&#8217;s completely normal and fine. Blot it with a paper towel before baking.)", "name": "Assemble the hand pies", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-hand-pies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for about 22\u201325 minutes or until they\u2019re golden brown on top and around the edges. Halfway through baking, rotate the baking sheets from top to bottom/bottom to top. Remove from the oven and allow the hand pies to cool on the baking sheets for 5 minutes, then transfer to a cooling rack to cool until ready to handle.\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-hand-pies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk together the confectioners\u2019 sugar, maple syrup, milk, maple or vanilla extract, and salt. When the hand pies are cool enough to handle, dip the tops of each into the icing. If the flaky layers of crust get stuck in the icing, switch to drizzling the icing on top instead of dipping. Place iced hand pies on a cooling rack set over a baking sheet or piece of parchment paper to catch drips. The icing will set in about 1 hour, but you can certainly enjoy the hand pies before that! Serve warm or at room temperature.", "name": "Make the icing", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-hand-pies/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftovers and store at room temperature for up to 1 day or in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-hand-pies/#instruction-step-8"}], "prepTime": "PT3H", "cookTime": "PT25M", "totalTime": "PT3H30M", "recipeYield": ["12", "12\u201316 hand pies"], "recipeCategory": "Pastries", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "10", "ratingValue": "4.6"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Brenda M"}, "datePublished": "2024-11-12", "reviewBody": "I already tried the hand pies! My dough was way too cold after 15 mins in the freezer so folding it in half was a struggle. But I kept going because I was on a time crunch.  That led to a lot of left over filling.  But I cooked that down to dunk my handpie in. For extra mini cheesecakes baked in a mini muffin pan, see recipe note.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "mini cheesecakes", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/easy-mini-cheesecakes-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/easy-mini-cheesecakes-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/easy-mini-cheesecakes-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/easy-mini-cheesecakes.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mini-cheesecakes/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (120g) graham cracker crumbs (about 8 full sheet graham crackers)", "2 Tablespoons (25g) granulated sugar", "3 Tablespoons (43g) unsalted butter, melted", "16 ounces (452g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "1/4 cup (60g) full-fat sour cream, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1 teaspoon freshly squeezed lemon juice", "2 large eggs, at room temperature"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line a standard 12-count muffin pan with cupcake liners.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mini-cheesecakes/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Combine all of the crust ingredients in a medium bowl. Mixture will be sandy. Firmly press a heaping Tablespoon of crust mixture into each liner. Bake the crusts for 6 minutes.", "name": "Make the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mini-cheesecakes/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the cream cheese and granulated sugar together on medium-high speed in a large bowl until the mixture is completely smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Add the sour cream, lemon juice, and vanilla extract, and beat until fully combined. With the mixer running on medium speed, add the eggs 1 at a time, beating just until combined before adding the next. Do not over-mix. Divide the batter among the liners, filling each all the way to the top. (It&#8217;s OK if the crust is still warm.)", "name": "Make the filling:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mini-cheesecakes/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Optional Water Bath (prevents cheesecakes from excess sinking; skip this step if desired): Boil a pot of water. You need 1 inch of water in your roasting pan for the water bath, so make sure you boil enough. Place a large metal baking or roasting pan (I usually use a 9\u00d713-inch baking pan\u2014do not use glass) on the bottom oven rack of the preheated oven. Pour boiling water into pan, about 1 inch deep. Immediately place the cheesecakes on the center rack. Close oven to trap the steam inside. This unique water bath adds steam to the oven without having the muffin pan sit inside the water itself, which is a traditional water bath method used for full-size cheesecakes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mini-cheesecakes/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake until the edges are set and the centers slightly jiggle when you tap the pan, about 20 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mini-cheesecakes/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Set the pan on a cooling rack and allow cheesecakes to cool at room temperature for 45 minutes, then transfer to the refrigerator and chill for at least 2 hours and up to 24 hours. (Or place in the freezer for 1 hour to speed things up.) If chilling in the refrigerator for longer than 2 hours, loosely cover the cheesecakes. Even if you used the water bath method in step 4, the cheesecakes will slightly sink as they cool.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mini-cheesecakes/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "I used Wilton 1M tip for piping whipped cream on the pictured mini cheesecakes. Doing both will help get you started.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-dipped-almond-biscotti/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 300\u00b0F (149\u00b0C). Line two large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Spread almonds on one sheet (keep the other one set aside) and toast for 15 minutes, stirring twice during that time. Remove toasted almonds from the oven and turn the oven up to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Rinse/wipe off the one baking sheet so you can use it again for the biscotti.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-dipped-almond-biscotti/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pulse the toasted almonds in a food processor or blender until very coarsely chopped. Set 1 cup of\u00a0chopped toasted almonds\u00a0aside. Pulse the remaining chopped toasted almonds until they are a little more fine. These will be what you sprinkle on top of the chocolate. Set them aside too.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-dipped-almond-biscotti/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large mixing bowl, whisk flour, brown sugar, baking powder, cinnamon, and salt together. Using a pastry cutter or 2 knives, cut in the butter until the mixture is crumbly. Gently toss in the 1 cup of coarsely chopped almonds. Set aside. In a medium bowl, whisk the eggs, oil, and vanilla together. Pour into the flour/butter mixture and gently mix with a large wooden spoon or silicone spatula until everything is just barely moistened.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-dipped-almond-biscotti/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Turn dough out onto a lightly floured surface, and with floured hands, knead lightly until the dough is soft and slightly sticky, about 8-10 times. If it&#8217;s uncontrollably sticky, knead\u00a01-2 more Tablespoon(s) of flour into the dough. With\u00a0floured hands, divide the dough in two\u00a0and place each half onto a baking sheet. Shape each half\u00a0into an 8-9 inch long roll, patting down until each is about 1/2 inch thick. Using a pastry brush, lightly brush the top and sides of each biscotti slab with egg wash.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-dipped-almond-biscotti/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake in batches (or together)\u00a0for 25-26 minutes, or until the top and sides of the biscotti slabs are lightly browned.\u00a0Remove from the oven, but do not turn off the heat. Allow\u00a0to cool for 10 minutes. Once the slabs are cool enough to handle, cut each\u00a0into\u00a01 inch\u00a0thick slices. Set\u00a0slices cut sides upright, \u00bc inch apart, on the\u00a0baking\u00a0sheets.\u00a0Return to the oven to continue baking for 9 minutes.\u00a0Turn biscotti\u00a0over and bake other side for 9\u00a0minutes. The cookies will be slightly soft in the centers with harder edges. Remove from the oven and allow to cool for 5 minutes on the baking sheet. Then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely before dipping in chocolate. As the biscotti cools, it becomes crunchy.\u00a0Save the baking sheets for the next step.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-dipped-almond-biscotti/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt the chocolate in a medium bowl in the microwave (or use a double boiler). The key to melting chocolate in the microwave\u00a0is to do it in small bursts and stir frequently. Chocolate seizes\u00a0so fast, so easily. Melt in 15 second increments, stirring vigorously with a spoon\u00a0after each increment, until completely melted and smooth. Dip one side of each biscotti cookie in the melted chocolate and immediately sprinkle with the remaining toasted almond crumbs. I do this over the sink to avoid a mess!\u00a0Place the dipped biscotti back onto the baking sheets and\u00a0allow chocolate to set in the refrigerator or at room temperature, about 30-45 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-dipped-almond-biscotti/#instruction-step-7"}], "prepTime": "PT1H", "cookTime": "PT45M", "totalTime": "PT1H45M", "recipeYield": ["18", "18 cookies"], "recipeCategory": "Cookies", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "Italian", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "23", "ratingValue": "4.6"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Simon"}, "datePublished": "2024-01-14", "reviewBody": "I didn't turn them sideways and they weren't so dry and crumbly. Made from scratch and so simple!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "chocolate pudding pie, no bake chocolate pie", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/chocolate-pudding-pie-7-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/chocolate-pudding-pie-7-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/chocolate-pudding-pie-7-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/chocolate-pudding-pie-7.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-pudding-pie/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 cups (240g) graham cracker crumbs (about 16 full sheets)", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, melted", "2 large egg yolks", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) cold water", "1 teaspoon gelatin", "2 cups (480ml) whole milk", "2/3 cup (130g) granulated sugar", "3 Tablespoons (23g) all-purpose flour", "6 ounces (170g) bittersweet chocolate, coarsely chopped*", "1 cup (240ml) heavy cream/heavy whipping cream", "1/4 cup (30g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "optional: fresh berries, chocolate shavings, or fresh mint for topping"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Mix the graham cracker crumbs and melted butter together until completely combined. Press tightly into the bottom and up the sides of a 9-inch pie dish. Bake crust for 8-10 minutes and let cool completely.", "name": "Make the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-pudding-pie/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "It&#8217;s best to measure out all of the pudding ingredients before beginning because you will need to move quickly. Whisk the egg yolks together in a bowl. Set aside. Whisk the cold water and gelatin together in a medium saucepan. Allow to sit for 2 minutes to slightly thicken, then turn the stove on to medium-low heat and place the saucepan on top.\u00a0Whisk in the milk, sugar, and flour. Whisk aggressively to dissolve the sugar, then slowly whisk as the mixture heats.", "name": "Make the pudding", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-pudding-pie/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When the mixture is warm and slowly simmering (not boiling!), slowly drizzle\u00a0about 1/4 cup (60ml) of it into the beaten egg yolks while whisking it all together. The point of the slow pour and the whisking is to temper the egg yolks. Once the 1/4 cup is added, very slowly pour the egg yolk mixture into the saucepan. Whisk it all together as the mixture begins to thicken. Once bubbles begin to burst at the surface, whisk\u00a0in\u00a0the chopped chocolate until combined. Whisk for about 1 more minute\u00a0as the pudding continues to thicken and bubble. Remove the pudding from heat. If you notice lumps, you can strain the pudding through a fine sieve, but that&#8217;s optional.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-pudding-pie/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour pudding\u00a0into the prepared pie crust. Immediately cover the top of the pudding with clear plastic wrap (directly on the surface of the pudding). Allow pudding pie to cool for 1 hour at room temperature before putting into the refrigerator to chill. Refrigerate for 4 hours and up to 24 hours until the pudding has completely set.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-chocolate-pudding-pie/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the heavy cream, confectioners&#8217; sugar, and vanilla on medium-high speed until stiff peaks form, about 5 minutes. Remove plastic wrap from chilled pie and spread or pipe the whipped cream on top. Garnish with optional toppings. Line 14 cups from 2 12-count muffin pans with liners.", "name": "Make the cupcakes", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-cupcakes-with-creamy-nutella-frosting/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Over high heat, boil the water in a small saucepan. Pour the unsweetened cocoa powder into a medium sized bowl and mix with boiling water until smooth. Allow to cool to room temperature by placing in the refrigerator as you prepare the other ingredients.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-cupcakes-with-creamy-nutella-frosting/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk together the flour, baking powder, and salt in a medium sized bowl. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-cupcakes-with-creamy-nutella-frosting/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl, using an electric hand or stand mixer, cream the softened butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Add the eggs, one at a time, beating until smooth. Scrape down the sides of the bowl as needed. Beat in the vanilla extract. Slowly add the flour mixture and beat only until *just* combined. In a steady stream, add the cooled cocoa mixture and stir until smooth.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-cupcakes-with-creamy-nutella-frosting/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Fill each muffin tin 3/4 of the way full with batter. Bake for 16-19 minutes, keeping an eye on them to avoid even the slightest burning (which will lend dry cupcakes). My cupcakes took 17 minutes and a toothpick inserted in the middle came out clean. Remove from oven and place on a wire rack to cool before frosting.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-cupcakes-with-creamy-nutella-frosting/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until smooth, about 2 minutes. Stop the mixer and add confectioners&#8217; sugar, Nutella, heavy cream, and vanilla extract. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to medium-high speed and beat for 2 full minutes. Add up to 1/2 cup more confectioners\u2019 sugar if frosting is too thin or another Tablespoon of cream if frosting is too thick. Add a pinch of salt if frosting is too sweet. (I always add 1/8 teaspoon salt.)", "name": "Make the frosting", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-cupcakes-with-creamy-nutella-frosting/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Frost cooled cupcakes with a piping tip, knife, or icing spatula. Sally\u2019s work has been featured on TODAY, Good Morning America, Taste of Home, People, and more.", "sameAs": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"]}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Homemade Bagels Recipe", "description": "Make fresh bagels right at home with this tested dough recipe. Don't skip the water bath and egg wash\u2014both provide an extra chewy and golden brown crust. This recipe is also in my cookbook, Sally's Baking 101.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "Homemade Bagels Recipe", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/bagels-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/bagels-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/bagels-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/bagels.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-bagels/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 1/2 cups (360g/ml) warm water\u00a0(between 100\u2013110\u00b0F/38\u201343\u00b0C)", "1 Tablespoon barley malt syrup, granulated sugar, or brown sugar*", "2 and 3/4 teaspoons (8g) instant or active dry yeast*", "4 cups (520g) bread flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed*", "2 teaspoons salt", "for coating the bowl: nonstick spray or 2 teaspoons butter or olive oil", "2 quarts (1.9L) water", "1/4 cup (85g) barley malt syrup or honey", "egg wash: 1 egg white beaten with 1 Tablespoon water"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a dough hook attachment, whisk the warm water, barley malt syrup/sugar, and yeast together. Cover and allow to sit for 5 minutes. *If you don\u2019t have a stand mixer, use a large mixing bowl and mix the dough with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula in the next step.*", "name": "Prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-bagels/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the flour and salt, and beat on medium speed for 2 minutes, until the dough comes together and pulls away from the sides of the bowl. If it seems too sticky and clings to the sides of the bowl instead of forming a rough mass around the dough hook or spoon, add more flour, 1 tablespoon at a time, and continue to mix until the dough pulls away from the sides of the bowl. The dough should be stiff and somewhat dry. If it is crumbly and breaks off in pieces, add more water, 1 teaspoon at a time, mixing well after each addition.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-bagels/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When the dough has reached the proper consistency, beat on low speed with the dough hook for an additional 6\u20137 minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 6\u20137 minutes, until the dough feels smooth, supple, and elastic. (If you\u2019re new to bread-making, my How to Knead Dough\u00a0video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-bagels/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with nonstick spray, butter, or oil. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides in the oil. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the dough to rise at room temperature for 1.5\u20132 hours, or until doubled in size.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-bagels/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line two large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-bagels/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When the dough is risen, punch it down to release the air. On a lightly floured surface, divide the dough into 8 equal pieces, about 4 ounces (113g) each. Shape each piece into a ball. Press your index finger through the center of each ball to make a hole about 1.5\u20132 inches in diameter. Arrange the shaped bagels on the prepared baking sheets. Loosely cover the shaped bagels with a kitchen towel or plastic wrap and let them rest for 5\u201310 minutes as you prepare the water bath.", "name": "Shape the bagels", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-bagels/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 425\u00b0F (218\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-bagels/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Fill a large, wide pot with 2 quarts (1.9L) of water. Whisk in the barley malt syrup or honey. Bring to a boil over high heat, then reduce heat to medium-high. Drop 2 or 3 bagels in at a time, making sure they have enough room to float around. Boil the bagels for 1 minute, then use a spatula to flip each bagel over and boil for 1 minute more. Using a slotted metal spatula, lift the bagels out of the water, letting the excess water drain off. Place the bagels back on the lined baking sheets. Repeat with remaining bagels.", "name": "Water bath", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-bagels/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a pastry brush, brush the egg wash on top and around the sides of each bagel. If you&#8217;re adding toppings, dip the tops of the bagels into the toppings immediately after applying the egg wash.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-bagels/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 20\u201325 minutes, rotating the pans halfway through, until the bagels are dark golden brown. Allow the bagels to cool on the baking sheets for 20 minutes, then transfer to a cooling rack to cool completely.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-bagels/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Slice, toast, top, whatever you want! Cover leftover bagels tightly and store at room temperature for up to 4 days or in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-bagels/#instruction-step-11"}], "prepTime": "PT2H10M", "cookTime": "PT25M", "totalTime": "PT3H", "recipeYield": ["8", "8 bagels"], "recipeCategory": "Bread", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "720", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Homemade Bagels Recipe | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "This easy homemade bagels recipe proves that you can make deliciously chewy bagels in your own kitchen with only a few basic ingredients and baking tools!\n\nGet the full recipe: https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-bagels/\n\n\u2022 Ask your recipe question or leave a review over on the recipe page.\n\n#baking #recipes #bagels\n\n\u2022 More of our favorite recipes: https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/", "duration": "PT3M", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/CyCB5hOiMBM?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CyCB5hOiMBM", "thumbnailUrl": ["https://i.ytimg.com/vi/CyCB5hOiMBM/hqdefault.jpg"], "uploadDate": "2020-05-30T11:00:06+00:00"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Emma Daugherty"}, "datePublished": "2025-10-15", "reviewBody": "I subbed whole wheat flour for the bread flour and it turned out great!"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "peach"}, "datePublished": "2025-09-30", "reviewBody": "I've made this recipe about 5 times now and I love them. my bagel shaping has been a little wonky/lumpy the first four times but the fifth time they have turned out way more smooth and round! they puffed up enough to lose most of their holes during baking but I think I overproofed them a little (went longer than 90 mins because I got distracted). they still taste great! \r\n\r\nI wanted to make chili crisp flavoured bagels and ended up adding 1.5 tbsp to the dough during step 2, but I reduced the salt by half because I know chili crisp can be pretty salty, but I think it could have used 1.5 tsp of salt instead of just 1. next time, I'll add 2 or even 3 tbsp of chili crisp as well because the flavour was there but subtle, and the heat was very gentle (I wouldn't even call it spicy, just kind of warm lol)."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Barry"}, "datePublished": "2025-10-03", "reviewBody": "Best bagels I've made.  I added 1/2 cup of sourdough starter. Super easy and delicious!"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Linda"}, "datePublished": "2025-11-09", "reviewBody": "I am tired of spending good money on what is basically a \"white bread\" bagel from the supermarket, or ponying up two bucks for a bakery bagel. These from Sally are absolutely delicious and incredibly easy to make. Made as written, and had to add a bit more flour to get the proper consistency in dough. Shaping wasn't difficult or challenging, but I learned that \"fatter is better\". Did the water bath with honey, and baked for about 25 minutes. After they cooled, I took the \"everything\" seasoned one and made a sandwich. Then I toasted a plain one and ate it with cream cheese. Since I hadn't dumped the water bath pan, I decided to make another batch. These are going to go on regular rotation.  Going to try the Cinnamon Raisin ones once I get some raisins in the house."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "izella"}, "datePublished": "2025-11-11", "reviewBody": "best bagel recipe ever"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Natalia"}, "datePublished": "2025-11-12", "reviewBody": "Very good recipe, but had a problem with boiling part.
