Set aside.", "name": "Make the cookie dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/halloween-chocolate-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on high speed until completely smooth and creamy, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg and vanilla and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/halloween-chocolate-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix on low until combined. Dough will be soft. If the dough seems too soft and sticky for rolling, add 1 more Tablespoon of flour.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/halloween-chocolate-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Divide the dough into 2 equal parts. Dust 2 large pieces of parchment paper or 2 silicone baking mats with cocoa powder (or flour). Place a dough half on each. With a rolling pin lightly dusted with cocoa powder (or flour), roll the dough out to about 1/4-inch thickness. Use more cocoa powder/flour if the dough seems too sticky. The rolled-out dough can be any shape, as long as it is evenly 1/4-inch thick.", "name": "Roll the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/halloween-chocolate-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly dust one of the rolled-out doughs with cocoa powder or flour. Place a piece of parchment on top. (This prevents sticking.) Place the 2nd rolled-out dough on top. Cover with plastic wrap or aluminum foil, then refrigerate for at least 1-2 hours and up to 2 days.", "name": "Chill the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/halloween-chocolate-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once chilled, preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line 2-3 large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Carefully remove the top dough piece from the refrigerator. Using cookie cutters (here is a 5-piece Halloween set that includes many of the shapes you see in these photos), cut the dough into shapes. Re-roll the remaining dough, using more cocoa powder or flour to lightly dust your work surface and rolling pin, and continue cutting the dough until all is used. Work quickly so the dough doesn&#8217;t become too warm or soft. If it does, stop what you&#8217;re doing and place any unused dough back in the refrigerator for 10 minutes to stiffen up again. Repeat cutting into shapes with 2nd half of dough. (Note: It doesn\u2019t seem like a lot of dough, but you get a lot of cookies from the dough scraps you re-roll.)", "name": "Preheat oven &amp; shape cookies", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/halloween-chocolate-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Arrange shaped cookies on baking sheets 3 inches apart. Bake for 11-12 minutes or until edges are set. If your oven has hot spots, rotate the baking sheet halfway through bake time. Allow cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes and then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely before decorating.", "name": "Bake &amp; cool", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/halloween-chocolate-cookies/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Prepare the royal icing or easy cookie icing. Divide the icing into separate bowls if you wish to tint it different colors using gel food coloring. I divided the icing into 4 equal portions, left 1 portion white, and tinted the other portions of icing orange, black, and green. When tinting icing, only use 1-2 drops at first, stir it in, then add more as needed to reach your desired color. I usually need quite a few drops to make black icing. (Remember, color darkens as icing dries.)", "name": "Make either icing", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/halloween-chocolate-cookies/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Read this step completely before starting and see recipe notes for recommended decorating tools. Spoon icing into piping bags fitted with Wilton Piping Tip #4. If you kept the icing white or are only using 1 color of icing, you just need 1 piping bag. Slowly pipe icing border around the cookies, and then fill the center with more icing. Keep the icing a thin layer so it dries faster. You can also decorate the cookies how I do in the video tutorial, including sprinkle stripes on the witch hats and sprinkle body on the bat. (These looks work with royal icing or the easy glaze icing.) No need to let the sprinkle stripes/sprinkle body dry before piping icing on the other parts of the cookie. You also do not have to wait for the orange icing to dry before piping the green stem on the pumpkin. If piping green leaves and a face on the pumpkin to make a Jack-O-Lantern, use royal icing and make sure the orange icing sets before adding these additional layers. (Royal icing is best for fine detail/layers.) I did quite a few royal icing Jack-O-Lantern looks in the picture above and the easiest is slanted semi-circles for eyes, triangle nose, and a curved zig-zag smile. If you ever need to thicken royal icing because it has thinned out while you&#8217;re decorating or you want thicker icing for piping fine detail, you can beat 2-3 extra Tablespoons of confectioners&#8217; sugar into it to help it thicken up. If adding eyeballs to the cookies, pipe a tiny dot of icing on the back of the eyeball before gently pressing onto the iced cookie. As always, take your time icing the cookies and know that each and every one won&#8217;t be perfect.", "name": "Decorate the cookies", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/halloween-chocolate-cookies/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Royal icing dries in about 2 hours and easy glaze icing dries in 24 hours. No need to cover the decorated cookies as you wait for the icing to set. If it\u2019s helpful, transfer cookies to a baking sheet and place them in the refrigerator to help slightly speed up the icing setting.", "name": "Let icing dry/set", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/halloween-chocolate-cookies/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Enjoy cookies right away or wait until the icing sets to serve them. For best success, read through the recipe and notes before beginning because there are a couple chilling and shaping steps.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "cookies, icebox cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/mint-chocolate-checkerboard-cookies-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/mint-chocolate-checkerboard-cookies-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/mint-chocolate-checkerboard-cookies-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/mint-chocolate-checkerboard-cookies.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mint-chocolate-checkerboard-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 1/2 cups (313g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/2 teaspoon baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 cup (200g)\u00a0granulated sugar", "1 large egg + 1 egg yolk, at room temperature* (save extra egg white)", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "optional for topping: 1 Tablespoon (15ml) water and 1/4 cup (50g) coarse sugar", "1 teaspoon peppermint extract", "optional: 1 drop green food dye", "2 Tablespoons\u00a0(10g)\u00a0unsweetened natural or dutch-process cocoa powder", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) milk", "optional: 1 teaspoon espresso powder"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk\u00a0the flour, baking powder, and salt together in a medium bowl. Set aside.", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mint-chocolate-checkerboard-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and granulated sugar together on medium-high speed until creamed, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg, egg yolk, and vanilla extract and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mint-chocolate-checkerboard-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix on low until combined. Dough will be thick and sticky. Divide in half, a bit less than 2 cups each.", "name": "Divide the dough in half", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mint-chocolate-checkerboard-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place half of the dough back into the mixing bowl. Add the mint dough ingredients. I recommend starting with 1 small drop of green food coloring. Beat on low speed until dough is combined. Add another small drop of food coloring if desired. For the pictured cookies, I used 1 drop of leaf green gel food coloring. Remove from the mixing bowl. No need to rinse out the mixing bowl, but feel free to wipe clean.", "name": "Make the mint dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mint-chocolate-checkerboard-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place other half of dough back into the mixing bowl. Add all of the chocolate dough ingredients. Beat on low speed until dough is combined.", "name": "Make the chocolate dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mint-chocolate-checkerboard-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place doughs on a lightly floured work surface. It&#8217;s sticky, so do your best in this step. With lightly floured hands, carefully form both doughs into a 6 inch long rectangle block, 2 inches tall and 2 inches wide. Wrap both dough blocks up in plastic wrap or place on a plate and cover with aluminum foil. Refrigerate for just 1 hour. The *key* is to only refrigerate until the dough is less sticky, but still pliable enough to bend and shape. Chilling any longer will make it difficult to form a neat checkerboard pattern. If you need to chill it for longer than 1 hour, make sure you let it sit at room temperature for 15-30 minutes before continuing with the next step.", "name": "Shape &amp; chill cookie dough for just 1 hour", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mint-chocolate-checkerboard-cookies/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "See photos in the blog post above for visuals of this step. Remove doughs from refrigerator and unwrap. Using a sharp knife, cut each block lengthways into 3 even strips. Then cut each strip into thirds again. You&#8217;ll have 9 thin strips from each dough block. My strips are usually a little uneven and messy, so for a neat checkerboard pattern, I always trim off* any rounded edges. Place 1 mint dough strip on your work surface. Line up a chocolate dough strip next to it. Line up a mint dough strip next to that. Top each with a row of alternating flavored dough strips, then top that with another row of alternating dough strips. Repeat with 2nd block, starting with a chocolate dough strip this time. As you&#8217;re working, press the strips tightly together to rid any gaps. (This is why it&#8217;s important the doughs are still a bit soft and pliable.) If desired to keep the checkerboard pattern neat, trim off* any rounded edges of your blocks.", "name": "Shape the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mint-chocolate-checkerboard-cookies/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Wrap each block of dough back up or cover and refrigerate for 2 more hours and up to 4 days.", "name": "Chill for 2 more hours:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mint-chocolate-checkerboard-cookies/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).\u00a0Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. And it was a fun recipe to do."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Emily in Canada"}, "datePublished": "2025-12-08", "reviewBody": "With a few modifications, I used this to make some cute soccer ball themed cookies. Omit the green food colouring and the dough ratio should be 2/3 light dough, 1/3 chocolate. Added a bit extra cocoa to get the colour as dark as possible. Cut the light dough into 5 equal strips, and the chocolate dough into 1 strip the same size as the light strips, then 5 more smaller strips out of the remaining dough. Then one at a time, I rolled each strip in plastic wrap and rolled by hand until they were each cylindrical. Dust the light dough strips with cocoa to create the lines on the ball. Then starting with the largest chocolate strip in the centre, add all five light dough strips like flower petals around the centre chocolate strip. Then around the edge, place the small chocolate strips between each light dough strip. Wrap in plastic and press together firmly. They'll spread less and won't be as crumbly. I don't recommend crunchy peanut butter\u2014the cookies will be sandier/crumblier, will spread more, and will taste a bit dry. Natural peanut butter is OK in a pinch, but the cookies crack and crumble more.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-sweethearts/#faq-question-1738610298828", "position": 2, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-sweethearts/#faq-question-1738610298828", "name": "Can I make a nut-free version of these?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "You have a few options. For a nut-free version of this recipe, swap the peanut butter for a nut-free spread such as sunflower seed butter, or cookie butter spread. Or you can try my <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sparkle-sweetheart-cookies/\">sparkle sweetheart cookies</a> recipe instead, which uses a cream cheese sugar cookie dough. You could also take <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/red-velvet-kiss-cookies/\">red velvet blossoms</a> or <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-cherry-blossom-cookies/\">chocolate cherry blossoms</a> and use a chocolate heart candy in place of the Hershey's Kiss.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-sweethearts/#faq-question-1738611045364", "position": 3, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-sweethearts/#faq-question-1738611045364", "name": "Can I roll the cookie dough balls in sugar before baking?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes! For a little extra sweetness and some sparkle, roll the dough balls in sugar or colored sanding sprinkles before you bake them.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-sweethearts/#faq-question-1738611155808", "position": 4, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-sweethearts/#faq-question-1738611155808", "name": "What's the best type of chocolate hearts to use?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "I love these cookies with <a href=\"https://amzn.to/4aMA5Vs\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener sponsored nofollow\">Reese's peanut butter creme hearts</a>, which provide a soft, meltaway texture in addition to extra peanut butter flavor. But you can use any chocolate heart candy you like here, such as Dove or Hershey's chocolate hearts; just keep in mind those will have a harder texture to bite into, especially if you use dark chocolate hearts instead of milk chocolate.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Peanut Butter Valentine's Day Cookies", "description": "With a chocolate heart candy nestled on top, these super soft sweetheart peanut butter Valentine's Day cookies are the February version of peanut butter blossoms!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "peanut butter Valentine's Day cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/peanut-butter-valentines-day-cookies-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/peanut-butter-valentines-day-cookies-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/peanut-butter-valentines-day-cookies-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/peanut-butter-valentines-day-cookies-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-sweethearts/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 1/4 cups (156g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1/2 cup (100g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1/4 cup (50g) granulated sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "3/4 cup (about 190g) creamy peanut butter", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "26-28 chocolate heart candies, unwrapped (like these or these)", "optional: additional 1/4 cup (50g) granulated sugar for rolling"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking soda, and salt together in a medium bowl. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-sweethearts/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with paddle attachment, beat the butter for 1 minute on high speed until creamy. Switch to medium-high speed and beat in the brown sugar and 1/4 cup (50g) granulated sugar until completely creamed and smooth, about 2 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg and beat until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. Add the peanut butter and vanilla extract and beat until combined.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-sweethearts/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the flour mixture to the wet ingredients and beat on low speed until combined. The dough will be very creamy and soft. Cover and refrigerate the cookie dough for at least 1 hour, and up to 3 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-sweethearts/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line 2 large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. (Always recommended for cookies.) Set aside. Also, make sure there&#8217;s room in your freezer because the baked cookies will need to be placed inside to prevent the chocolates from melting.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-sweethearts/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Scoop and roll cookie dough, about 1 heaping Tablespoon (around 25g) of dough each. If desired, roll each ball in 1/4 cup of granulated sugar. Arrange cookie dough balls on the baking sheet about 3 inches apart. Bake for 11\u201313 minutes or until the tops begin to slightly crack.", "name": "Roll &amp; bake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-sweethearts/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove cookies from the oven and allow to cool on the baking sheets for 5 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-sweethearts/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Gently press a chocolate heart candy into the center of each, then, using a thin spatula, immediately transfer the cookies to a large plate or a few smaller plates (gently\u2014they&#8217;re soft). Grease a 12&#215;17-inch half sheet pan, then line with parchment paper. Pan size is imperative. This batter won&#8217;t fit into anything smaller. Likewise, the cake would be too thin if baked in larger pans.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-berry-petit-fours/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter on high speed until smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a rubber spatula. Add the cream cheese and beat on high speed until completely smooth and combined, about 1 minute. Add the sugar and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute, then add the sour cream and vanilla and beat on high speed until combined and creamy. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a rubber spatula.", "name": "Make the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-berry-petit-fours/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "On low speed, beat the eggs in 1 at a time allowing each to fully mix in before adding the next. Careful not to overmix after the eggs have been added. Once the 6th egg is combined, stop the mixer and add the cake flour, baking powder, and salt. Beat on medium speed *just* until combined, then beat in the lemon juice. Try not overmix. Using a rubber spatula or sturdy whisk, give the batter a final turn to make sure there are no lumps at the bottom of the bowl. The batter will be thick and creamy.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-berry-petit-fours/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour/spoon batter evenly into prepared pan. Bang the pan on the counter once or twice to bring up any air bubbles. Bake for 26-31 minutes. Use a toothpick to test for doneness. Once it comes out completely clean, the cake is done.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-berry-petit-fours/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove cake from the oven and allow to cool inside the pan. The cake will shrink down from the sides.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-berry-petit-fours/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Watch video tutorial above for a visual on the entire petit fours assembly. Once cool, invert the cake onto a cutting board or the counter with the long side facing you. With a sharp knife (I find serrated knife is best here) or pizza cutter, slice cake in half horizontally. Then cut each long rectangle into 3 smaller rectangles. You&#8217;ll now have 6 rectangles. Very carefully and slowly slice each in half as shown in the video above\u2014as if you were making a 1 layer cake a 2 layer cake. You now have 12 thin rectangles.", "name": "Cut cake into sections", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-berry-petit-fours/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until creamy, about 2 minutes. Add confectioners\u2019 sugar, heavy cream, and vanilla extract. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to high speed and beat for 3 full minutes. Add up to 1/4 cup more confectioners\u2019 sugar if frosting is too thin or another Tablespoon of cream if frosting is too thick. Add a pinch of salt if frosting is too sweet. (I always add a pinch.)", "name": "Make the vanilla buttercream:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-berry-petit-fours/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a sharp knife, trim the ends off the rectangles that touched the pan. They&#8217;re a little harder and uneven, which would create lopsided petit fours. Spread vanilla buttercream in a thick even layer on 4 rectangles. Spread both lemon curd and raspberry jam on 4 rectangles. (The remaining 4 rectangles are plain because they are the tops.) Go a little lighter on the raspberry jam and lemon curd compared to the vanilla buttercream. If there&#8217;s too much, it creates a big mess when cutting the petit fours.", "name": "Add fillings", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-berry-petit-fours/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the lemon curd/raspberry jam rectangles on top of the vanilla buttercream rectangles. Layer the plain rectangle on top. Loosely cover each and chill in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours or freeze for 1 hour. They must chill before cutting into tiny petit fours.", "name": "Layer the petit fours", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-berry-petit-fours/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once cold, slice each into 12 little squares. Arrange on a baking sheet and chill in the refrigerator or freezer as you melt the white chocolate.", "name": "Cut into tiny petit fours", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-berry-petit-fours/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt the white chocolate and oil together in a double boiler or in the microwave in 20 second increments, stopping and stirring after each until smooth and melted. If it seems too thick, add another drop of oil to thin out. Spoon or drizzle over petit fours. This apple crumble pie is the definition of fall comfort, and you don\u2019t need to fuss with a decorative pie crust on top. Make sure to chill each component as directed. Cold pie dough and a cold crumble topping hold their shape much better during baking.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "apple crumble pie", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/homemade-apple-crumble-pie-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/homemade-apple-crumble-pie-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/homemade-apple-crumble-pie-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/homemade-apple-crumble-pie.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-crumble-pie/", "recipeIngredient": ["1\u00a0and 1/2 cups (188g)\u00a0all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled), plus more for work surface", "1 Tablespoon (12g)\u00a0granulated sugar", "1/4 teaspoon\u00a0salt", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) cold unsalted butter, cubed", "1/4 cup (60g/ml) ice-cold water, plus more as needed", "egg wash: 1 large egg beaten with 1 Tablespoon (15g/ml) milk", "1/2 cup (100g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "3/4 cup (94g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "3/4 cup (95g) chopped walnuts", "5 Tablespoons (71g) unsalted butter, melted and slightly cooled", "10 cups (1.25kg) 1/4-inch-thick apple slices (about 8 large peeled and cored apples)*", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "1/4 cup (31g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 Tablespoon (15g/ml) fresh lemon juice", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon", "1/4 teaspoon ground cloves", "1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, and salt. Using a pastry cutter or 2 forks, cut in the butter until the mixture resembles coarse pea-sized crumbs. Add the water and stir until the flour is moistened. Add 1\u20132 more Tablespoons of water if the dough seems dry. Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured work surface and, using your hands, work the dough into a ball. Flatten it into a thick disc. Wrap the dough disc in plastic wrap or parchment paper and refrigerate it for at least 2 hours, and up to 3 days.", "name": "Make the pie dough for the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-crumble-pie/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, combine the brown sugar, cinnamon, flour, and walnuts. Using a silicone spatula, stir in the melted butter. The topping will be thick and crumbly. Place it in the refrigerator while you continue.", "name": "Make the crumble topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-crumble-pie/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "On a floured work surface, roll out the disc of chilled dough. Turn the dough about a quarter turn after every few rolls until you have a circle 12 inches in diameter. Carefully place the dough into a 9-inch pie dish. Tuck it in with your fingers, making sure it is smooth. Use a small paring knife to trim excess dough off the edges. Flute the pie crust edges and brush them with egg wash. Place the pie crust in the refrigerator.", "name": "Roll out the chilled pie dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-crumble-pie/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a silicone spatula or wooden spoon, combine the apples, sugar, flour, lemon juice, cinnamon, cloves, nutmeg, and vanilla extract, stirring until the apples are all coated.\u00a0", "name": "Make the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-crumble-pie/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C). Place a baking sheet on the bottom oven rack to catch any juices that may bubble over.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-crumble-pie/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon the apple filling into the crust, making sure there are no large gaps between the slices. It\u2019s a lot of filling! Sprinkle the cold crumb topping evenly over the top of the apples.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-crumble-pie/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 20 minutes. Add a pie crust shield to prevent the edges from browning too quickly, and reduce the oven temperature to 375\u00b0F (191\u00b0C). Bake for an additional 35 to 45 minutes or until the crust is golden brown and juices are bubbling around the edges. If needed toward the end of bake time, remove the pie crust shield and tent a large piece of aluminum foil over the entire pie if the crumb topping is getting too brown.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-crumble-pie/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Allow the pie to cool for at least 3 full hours at room temperature before serving. The dough is a family recipe and only needs to rest for 10 to 30 minutes before shaping. The quick baking soda boil gives the pretzels their traditional flavor, and I do not recommend skipping it. This recipe is also in my New York Times best-selling cookbook, Sally's Baking 101.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "soft pretzels", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/easy-homemade-soft-pretzels-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/easy-homemade-soft-pretzels-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/easy-homemade-soft-pretzels-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/easy-homemade-soft-pretzels.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-homemade-soft-pretzels/", "recipeIngredient": ["2\u00a0and 1/4 teaspoons (7g)\u00a0instant\u00a0or\u00a0active dry yeast\u00a0(1\u00a0standard packet)", "1 Tablespoon brown sugar or granulated sugar", "1\u00a0and 1/2 cups (360ml)\u00a0warm water (around 100\u00b0F/38\u00b0C)", "1 Tablespoon (14g) unsalted butter, melted and slightly cooled", "1 teaspoon salt", "3 and 3/4\u20134 cups (469\u2013500g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed", "coarse salt, for topping", "1/2 cup (120g) baking soda", "9 cups (2.13L) water"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the yeast and sugar into warm water. Cover and allow to sit for 1 minute.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-homemade-soft-pretzels/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk in the melted butter and salt. Add 3 cups (375g) of flour. Mix with a wooden spoon (or dough hook attachment if using a stand mixer) until combined. Add 3/4 cup (94g) more flour until the dough is slightly tacky and pulls away from the sides of the bowl. If it is still sticky, add up to 1/4 cup more (31g) flour, 1 Tablespoon at a time, as needed. Poke the dough with your finger\u2014if it bounces back, it is ready to knead.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-homemade-soft-pretzels/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 3 to 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 3 to 5 minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-homemade-soft-pretzels/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Shape the kneaded dough into a ball. Cover lightly with a towel and allow to rest for 10 to 30 minutes. (Meanwhile, I like to get the water + baking soda boiling as instructed in step 8.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-homemade-soft-pretzels/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C). Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Silicone baking mats are highly recommended over parchment paper. If using parchment paper, lightly spray with nonstick spray or grease with butter. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-homemade-soft-pretzels/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a sharp knife or pizza cutter, cut dough into 75g sections, which is about 1/3 cup of dough each.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-homemade-soft-pretzels/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Roll the dough into a 20\u201322-inch rope. Form a circle with the dough by bringing the 2 ends together at the top of the circle. Twist the ends together. Bring the twisted ends back down towards yourself and press them down to form a pretzel shape.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-homemade-soft-pretzels/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bring baking soda and 9 cups of water to a boil in a large pot. Drop 1\u20132 pretzels into the boiling water for 20\u201330 seconds. Any longer than that and your pretzels will have a metallic taste. Using a slotted spatula, lift the pretzel out of the water and allow as much of the excess water to drip off. Place pretzel onto prepared baking sheet. Repeat with remaining pretzels. If desired, cover the boiled, unbaked pretzels with lightly oiled plastic wrap and refrigerate for up to 24 hours before baking (step 9).\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-homemade-soft-pretzels/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Sprinkle the tops of the pretzels with coarse salt. I use and recommend bittersweet chocolate.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "skillet brownie", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/brownie-skillet-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/brownie-skillet-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/brownie-skillet-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/brownie-skillet-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/ultimate-skillet-brownie/", "recipeIngredient": ["3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter", "2 Tablespoons vegetable oil", "4 ounces (113g) bittersweet or semi-sweet chocolate*, coarsely chopped", "1 and 1/2 cups (300g) granulated sugar", "3 large eggs, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1/2 cup (42g) unsweetened natural or Dutch-process cocoa powder*", "1 cup (125g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1 cup + 2 Tablespoons (about 200g) semi-sweet chocolate chips, divided", "optional for serving: ice cream, salted caramel sauce, and/or hot fudge sauce"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium saucepan set over medium heat, stir the butter, oil, chocolate, and sugar until melted and smooth, about 5 minutes. Pour into a large mixing bowl and whisk to make sure it&#8217;s completely smooth and not grainy. You can scoop/slice and serve or serve with a whole bunch of spoons so everyone can dig in together. I always serve with ice cream and chocolate syrup. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg and vanilla extract and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-cookie-pizza/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the dry ingredients and beat on low speed until combined. Dough will be thick, soft, and sticky.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-cookie-pizza/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Transfer the cookie dough to the pizza pan and flatten out with your fingers until it&#8217;s around 3/4 inch thick. Santa's Whiskers Cookies are soft slice and bake cookies flavored with almond, studded with cherries, and rolled in coconut.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "Santa's whiskers cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/santas-whiskers-cookies-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/santas-whiskers-cookies-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/santas-whiskers-cookies-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/santas-whiskers-cookies.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/santas-whiskers-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "2/3 cup (133g) granulated sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1/2 teaspoon almond extract", "2 cups (250g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (63g) finely chopped maraschino cherries (I used a mix of green and red)*", "1 cup (80g) sweetened shredded coconut, for rolling", "optional: one 4-ounce white chocolate baking bar and extra coconut for topping"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld mixer or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and granulated sugar together on medium-high speed until combined and creamy, about 2 minutes. Beat in the egg, vanilla extract, and almond extract on high speed. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed, and continue to beat until fully combined. On low speed, beat in the flour and salt until combined. The cookie dough will be thick and slightly sticky. Switch to low speed and beat in the cherries *just* until combined. Too much beating will turn the cookie dough pink. (Which isn&#8217;t necessarily a bad thing!)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/santas-whiskers-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Turn the dough out onto a floured work surface and, with floured hands, divide or cut into two. Shape each half into an 8-inch log, about 2.5 inches in diameter. The measurements don&#8217;t have to be exact. Roll each log in the shredded coconut. Tightly wrap the logs in plastic wrap and chill in the refrigerator for at least 3 hours and up to 5 days. Chilling is mandatory for this cookie dough. I prefer to chill mine for 4 hours or even overnight\u2014the colder the dough, the thicker the cookies.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/santas-whiskers-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).\u00a0Line two\u00a0large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats.\u00a0(Always recommended\u00a0for cookies.)\u00a0Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/santas-whiskers-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Slice each log into 12\u00a0equally thick cookies and place cookies on baking sheets about 2 inches apart.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/santas-whiskers-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the cookies for 13-14 minutes or until brown around the edges.\u00a0Remove from the oven and allow cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/santas-whiskers-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If desired, drizzle the cooled cookies with white chocolate.\u00a0Melt the chopped white chocolate in a double boiler or in the microwave in 15-second increments, stopping and stirring after each until completely smooth. Drizzle on the cookies. Sprinkle with extra coconut, if desired. Allow chocolate to set completely in the refrigerator for 20 minutes or at room temperature for 30 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/santas-whiskers-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, Sally\u2019s work has been featured on TODAY, Good Morning America, Taste of Home, People, and more.", "sameAs": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"]}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Burnt Sugar Cake", "description": "The trick to burnt sugar cake is to use burnt sugar syrup as its main flavor. Make sure you prepare the burnt sugar syrup ahead of time so that it can properly cool and thicken. While you're at it, prepare the salted caramel ahead of time too.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "burnt sugar cake, caramel cake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/burnt-sugar-caramel-cake-7-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/burnt-sugar-caramel-cake-7-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/burnt-sugar-caramel-cake-7-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/burnt-sugar-caramel-cake-7.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/burnt-sugar-caramel-cake/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (200g) granulated sugar", "3/4 cup (180ml) boiling water", "2 and 1/2 cups (285g) cake flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 teaspoons baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda", "1 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 cup (200g) granulated sugar", "1/2 cup (120ml) cooled burnt sugar syrup", "4 egg whites, at room temperature", "1/2 cup (120g) sour cream, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1/2 cup (120ml) whole milk, at room temperature", "1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "4 cups (480g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1/2 cup (120ml) cooled burnt sugar syrup", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) whole milk or heavy cream", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "Homemade Salted Caramel, cooled", "1/2 cup (50g) chopped pecans*"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "For best success, read the recipe in full and watch the video tutorial in the post above before starting.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/burnt-sugar-caramel-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "first so it has time to cool. Make sure you have boiling water at the ready. For the burnt sugar syrup, place sugar in a medium saucepan over medium heat. Best to use a 3 quart heavy-bottomed quality saucepan. Stirring constantly with a wooden spoon, cook until the sugar has completely melted and is amber brown, about 8-10 minutes. If the sugar is clumpy, break up the lumps with your wooden spoon. A candy thermometer is not necessary, but if you&#8217;re using one, the sugar temperature should reach about 300\u00b0F (149\u00b0C) when it&#8217;s ready. Turn the heat to low and very carefully and slowly drizzle in the boiling water, a little at a time. Stir after each addition and stand back, as the mixture will rapidly sizzle and bubble. After all of the boiling water is stirred in, stir and cook the sugar syrup for 3 more minutes on low. Turn off the heat and let it cool completely, overnight preferred. It&#8217;s imperative that the sugar syrup is completely cool. You will have about 1 cup of syrup.", "name": "Prepare the burnt sugar syrup", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/burnt-sugar-caramel-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Grease two 9-inch cake pans, line with parchment paper rounds, then grease the parchment paper. Parchment paper helps the cakes seamlessly release from the pans. (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes video &amp; post.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/burnt-sugar-caramel-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the cake flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/burnt-sugar-caramel-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on high speed until creamed, about 2 minutes. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed. With the mixer running on medium speed, pour in 1/2 cup of the cooled burnt sugar syrup. Beat until combined. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. Beat in the egg whites, sour cream, and vanilla extract. With the mixer on low speed, add the dry ingredients just until combined. With the mixer still running on low, slowly pour in the milk until combined. Do not over-mix. The batter will be slightly thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/burnt-sugar-caramel-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour batter evenly into prepared cake pans. Bake for 23-25 minutes or until the cakes are baked through. As a result of the burnt sugar syrup cooking inside the cake batter, the cakes brown nicely on top and on the sides. To test for doneness, insert a toothpick into the center of the cake. If it comes out clean, it is done. Allow cakes to cool completely in the pans set on a wire rack.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/burnt-sugar-caramel-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "As the cakes cool, I suggest making the salted caramel. The salted caramel adds necessary flavor. We&#8217;ll use it as a filling and garnish. When ready to use in step 9, make sure the salted caramel isn&#8217;t too hot anymore. If it&#8217;s too hot, it will melt the frosting. If it&#8217;s too cool, it won&#8217;t drizzle. Let it cool for at least 30 minutes before using. If you prepared the salted caramel ahead of time and it became too cool or too thick, microwave it for 5-10 seconds or JUST until it&#8217;s drizzle-able again. (It won&#8217;t be too hot at this point.) You can also toast the pecans during this time, too. See recipe note.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/burnt-sugar-caramel-cake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld mixer or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until creamy, about 1-2 minutes. Add confectioners&#8217; sugar, remaining 1/2 cup of cooled burnt sugar syrup, vanilla extract, milk/cream, and salt. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to high speed and beat until completely combined, about 2 minutes. Add more confectioners&#8217; sugar if frosting is too thin or more milk/cream if frosting is too thick. Taste. Add more salt if desired. (I usually use 1/2 teaspoon of salt total. I like this frosting salty/sweet.)", "name": "Make the frosting", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/burnt-sugar-caramel-cake/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "First, using a large serrated knife or cake leveler, slice a thin layer off the tops of the cakes to create a flat surface. Discard (or crumble over ice cream!). If you have any leftover burnt sugar syrup, drizzle over leveled cakes. I usually don&#8217;t have any leftover, but this is a great place to use any last drops if you have some. Place 1 cake layer on your cake stand, cake turntable, or serving plate. Using a large icing spatula, evenly cover the top with frosting. Drizzle 1/4 cup (73g) of salted caramel on top of the frosting. Top with 2nd cake layer. Refrigerate the cake for at least 30-45 minutes before finishing the frosting and garnish. The caramel inside the cake must &#8220;set.&#8221; After chilling in the refrigerator, spread the remaining frosting all over the top and sides. Run a\u00a0bench scraper around the cake to smooth out the sides, if desired. Garnish with toasted pecans and more salted caramel. Slice and serve.", "name": "Assemble and frost:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/burnt-sugar-caramel-cake/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover cake\u00a0tightly and store in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/burnt-sugar-caramel-cake/#instruction-step-10"}], "prepTime": "PT1H", "cookTime": "PT24M", "totalTime": "PT4H30M", "recipeYield": ["10", "serves 10-12"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "80", "ratingValue": "4.7"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Burnt Sugar Caramel Cake | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "Here's how to make soft and buttery burnt sugar caramel cake. This unique and absolutely divine cake gets its flavor from burnt sugar syrup. We\u2019ll use the syrup in both the cake and frosting.\n\nGet the full recipe: https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/burnt-sugar-caramel-cake/\n\n\u2022 Ask your recipe question or leave a review over on the recipe page.\n\n#baking #recipes #cake\n\n\u2022 More of our favorite recipes: https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/", "duration": "PT4M", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/qgSj07p0b2U?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qgSj07p0b2U", "thumbnailUrl": ["https://i.ytimg.com/vi/qgSj07p0b2U/hqdefault.jpg"], "uploadDate": "2020-11-10T07:00:12+00:00"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "2"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Miranda"}, "datePublished": "2024-09-27", "reviewBody": "I grew up in an area where burnt sugar is THE cake flavor. Almost every wedding I attended had a burnt sugar cake. You could walk into the local bakery and buy a burnt sugar cake from the display. I had high hopes for this recipe but it fell short for me. \r\n\r\nThe raw batter tasted like vanilla. After baking, my husband asked if I made corn bread. After cooling we tried a small sliver and my husband once again asked if it was corn bread. It had the taste, color, and texture of boxed honey corn bread mix. \r\n\r\nI didn't use the salted carmel filling as I wanted the cake to be true to what I grew up with. The icing didn't add much to the cake. We didn't like the texture of the cake. I ended up turning the cake into cake balls and dipping them into white chocolate. I shared with family who were also big fans of burnt sugar cake and they also agreed they didn't get any burnt sugar flavors from the repurposed cake and icing. \r\n\r\nOne tip for making the syrup. The first batch I followed the recipe instructions but  my sugar clumped like wet sand. When adding the hot water it disovled most of the clumps. I made a second batch of burnt sugar syrup. I turned the heat to medium high and didn't stir the sugar. This perfectly caramelized the sugar leaving it clump free. When taste testing both syrups the tasted the same."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Donna Smith"}, "datePublished": "2024-09-27", "reviewBody": "I made this recipe last year for my daughter's birthday and it was amazing! Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/dark-chocolate-chunk-oatmeal-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a separate bowl, whisk the flour, baking soda, cinnamon, and salt together. Add to the wet ingredients and mix on low until combined. Beat in the oats and chocolate on low speed. Dough will be thick, yet very sticky. Chill the dough for 30-60 minutes in the refrigerator (I always chill this dough for only 30 minutes). If chilling for longer (up to 2 days), allow to sit at room temperature for at least 30 minutes before rolling and baking. The cookies won&#8217;t spread as much if chilled for longer than 1 hour.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/dark-chocolate-chunk-oatmeal-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). I recommend using a cookie scoop since the dough can be sticky. Bake for 11-12 minutes or until lightly browned on the sides. The centers will look soft and under-baked. Remove from the oven, immediately sprinkle each with sea salt (if using), then let cool on baking sheet for 5 minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely. Set aside. In a medium bowl, whisk the oil, brown sugar, granulated sugar, eggs, applesauce, and vanilla together until combined. Whisk in the zucchini. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients. Gently stir or whisk until *just* combined; do not overmix. Fold in any optional add-ins like chocolate chips or nuts. Batter is slightly thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/zucchini-bread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread the batter evenly into prepared loaf pan. Bake for 55-70 minutes. (I like to loosely cover the bread with aluminum foil halfway through to prevent heavy browning on top.) Baking times vary so keep an eye on yours. The bread is done when a toothpick inserted in the center comes out *mostly* clean with zero raw batter. Remove the bread from the oven and set on a wire rack. Cool in pan for 1 hour before removing from pan. You can slice the bread at this point, but it will still be warm in the center and may not slice neatly. For neat slices, continue cooling bread directly on a wire rack and then slice once cooled.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/zucchini-bread/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store leftover bread at room temperature for up to 3-4 days or in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/zucchini-bread/#instruction-step-4"}], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT55M", "totalTime": "PT3H", "recipeYield": ["1", "1 loaf"], "recipeCategory": "Bread", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "528", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Zucchini Bread | Sally's Baking Recipes", "description": "This is a family favorite recipe for homemade zucchini bread. Generously grease a 9&#215;13-inch cake pan.", "name": "Make the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-sheet-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Sift the cake flour, sugar, baking powder, baking soda, and salt in the bowl of a stand mixer. (Or if using a handheld mixer, any large mixing bowl.) With the paddle attachment, beat the ingredients together on low speed for a few seconds to gently combine. Add the butter, vanilla, and 1/2 cup of milk. Mix on medium speed until the dry ingredients are moistened, about 1 minute. Stop the mixer and scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl. The mixture will resemble a thick dough.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-sheet-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the remaining milk, the sour cream, and eggs together in a medium bowl. With the mixer running on medium speed, add the egg mixture in 3 additions, mixing for about 15 seconds after each addition. Stop the mixer and scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl, then mix for about 15 more seconds until batter is completely combined. Avoid over-mixing. Some small lumps are OK.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-sheet-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour and spread batter evenly into prepared pan. Allow cake to cool completely in the pan set on a wire rack. The cake must be completely cool before frosting.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-sheet-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until creamy, about 2 minutes. Add confectioners\u2019 sugar, heavy cream, and vanilla extract. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to medium-high speed and beat for 4 full minutes. Add up to 1/4 cup more confectioners\u2019 sugar if frosting is too thin or another Tablespoon of cream if frosting is too thick. Add a pinch of salt if frosting is too sweet. (I add 1/8 teaspoon salt.) Spread filling evenly into prepared pan.", "name": "Make the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/berry-cobbler/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt together in a large bowl. Using a pastry cutter or two forks, cut the butter into the mixture until it resembles coarse meal (pea-sized crumbs). A pastry cutter makes this step very easy and quick! You could also use a food processor. While slowly stirring, slowly drizzle in 1/2 cup buttermilk. Mix until evenly combined. Take handfuls of dough and gently flatten out. Place dough all over the top of the berry filling. There&#8217;s no special trick to this\u2014just flatten the dough in sections and cover most of the berries.", "name": "Make the topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/berry-cobbler/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Brush the top of the biscuit dough with 1 Tablespoon of buttermilk and then sprinkle with coarse sugar. These two are optional, but both help achieve a shiny, crunchy, golden brown crust.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/berry-cobbler/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 45-55 minutes, or until golden brown and biscuit topping is cooked through. Stick a toothpick into the biscuit topping, if it comes out clean, it is cooked through and the cobbler is done. Set the pan on a wire rack, then cool for 5 minutes before serving. A pretty straightforward and delicious cobbler that I was able to make even with a nearly-4 year old around. I have used only fresh blackberries and raspberries because they are on sale at our local store (and are my favorite). I used the food processor for the dough and the vinegar/milk recipe (2% today because that's what I had on hand; whole milk the two previous times). I do recommend the milk/sugar coat because I forgot it the second time -- still delicious without but a bit better with. I almost used the peach dough recipe because my husband likes the biscuit part best but I honestly forgot the first time and I am glad I did. It's the perfect amount of biscuits to berry ratio. \r\n\r\nToday's cobbler is going to a couple who just brought home their rainbow baby."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", Each ingredient serves a purpose so for best results, I don\u2019t recommend making substitutions.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "cookies & cream cake, oreo cake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/cookies-and-cream-cake-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/cookies-and-cream-cake-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/cookies-and-cream-cake-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/cookies-and-cream-cake.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-sheet-cake/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 1/2 cups (285g) cake flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 teaspoons baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda", "1 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 and 1/2 cups (300g) granulated sugar", "4 large egg whites, at room temperature", "3/4 cup (180g) sour cream, at room temperature", "1 Tablespoon pure vanilla extract", "3/4 cup (180ml) whole milk, at room temperature*", "1 and 1/4 cups chopped Oreos (110g, about 10 whole Oreos)*", "6 ounces (170g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (90g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1 and 1/2 cups (360ml) cold heavy cream or heavy whipping cream", "1 cup chopped Oreos (90g, about 8 whole regular Oreos)*", "optional: mini or regular Oreos for garnish"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Generously grease a 9\u00d713-inch cake pan.", "name": "Make the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-sheet-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the cake flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-sheet-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the butter on high speed until smooth and creamy, about 1 minute. Add the sugar and beat on high speed for 2 minutes until creamed together. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed. Add the egg whites. Beat on high speed until combined, about 2 minutes. Then beat in the sour cream and vanilla extract. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. Mixture will appear curdled and that&#8217;s ok. With the mixer on low speed, add the dry ingredients just until incorporated. With the mixer still running on low, slowly pour in the milk until combined. Do not overmix. Whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no lumps at the bottom of the bowl, then fold in the chopped Oreo pieces. Avoid over-mixing.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-sheet-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour batter into prepared cake pan. Bake for around 32\u201335 minutes or until the cake is baked through. To test for doneness, insert a toothpick into the center of the cake. If it comes out clean, it is done. Allow cake to cool completely in the pan set on a wire rack. The cake must be completely cool before frosting.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-sheet-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the cream cheese on medium-high speed until creamy, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed until creamy. Add the confectioners&#8217; sugar and vanilla extract, and then beat on medium speed until combined and completely smooth, about 2 full minutes. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl. Switch the mixer to low speed and with the mixer running, carefully pour in the cream in a slow and steady stream. After all of the cream has been added, turn the mixer up to high speed and beat until thick and stiff peaks form, about 1\u20132 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-sheet-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If you&#8217;d like to pipe any frosting on the cake like I did in the photo above, set aside about 1 cup of frosting. Fold chopped Oreos into remaining frosting (or all of the frosting if you are not piping any of it). Spread onto cooled cake\u2014it will be a thick layer of frosting. I find a small offset spatula is best for frosting 9&#215;13-inch sheet cakes. For the pictured piping, I used a Wilton 1M piping tip and piped a zigzag design around the border.", "name": "Frost the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookies-cream-sheet-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Serve immediately or cover and set aside for a few hours before serving. Or melt in a medium microwave safe bowl in 20 second increments, stirring after each, in the microwave. Remove from the heat, pour into a large mixing bowl, and allow to slightly cool for 10 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-stuffed-brownies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "While the chocolate mixture is cooling, make the peanut butter filling. In a medium bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the peanut butter, confectioners&#8217; sugar, vanilla, and milk together on medium-high speed until combined. The mixture will be very thick\u2014like a crumbly cookie dough. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-stuffed-brownies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Adjust the oven rack to the lower third position and preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line the bottom and sides of a 9-inch square baking pan with aluminum foil, leaving an overhand on all sides. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-stuffed-brownies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the granulated and brown sugars into the cooled chocolate/butter mixture. Add the eggs, one at a time, whisking until smooth after each addition. Whisk in the vanilla. Gently fold in the flour, cocoa powder, and salt.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-stuffed-brownies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour/spread half of the brownie batter into the prepared baking pan. Take large chunks of the peanut butter filling and flatten with your hands. Place flat pieces in an even layer on top of the brownie layer, as shown in the photo above. Pour/spread the remaining brownie batter on top. Top with the chocolate chips and peanut butter chips. Using the back of a spatula, gently press the chips into the brownie batter.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-stuffed-brownies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 35-36 minutes or until the brownies begin to pull away from the edges of the pan. (The brownies may slightly crack in the center\u2014that&#8217;s because air in between the peanut butter layers is trying to escape. That&#8217;s normal!) A toothpick inserted in the center should come out with only a few moist crumbs when the brownies are done. All ovens are different, so keep an eye on them after 30 minutes and use the toothpick test to see when yours are finished.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-stuffed-brownies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Allow the brownies to cool completely in the pan set on a wire rack. Add the sugar in 2 additions, beating for 30 seconds between. Once all of the sugar has been added, turn the mixer up to high speed and continue beating until glossy stiff peaks form, about 2 minutes. The peaks should be stiff enough that you can hold the whisk upright and the peaks won&#8217;t move. Add the vanilla extract and beat for 1 more minute. The peaks should still be very stiff. If not, keep on mixing on high speed. Using a rubber spatula, fold in the cream of tartar and cornstarch.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pavlova/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread the pavlova mixture into an 8-9-inch circle (see note for mini size). Bake until the pavlova is firm and dry, about 90 minutes total. Rotate the baking sheet if you notice some spots browning. No need to pre-bake the crust. You can use fresh or frozen cranberries in this pie recipe.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "apple cranberry crumble pie", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/apple-cranberry-crumble-pie-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/apple-cranberry-crumble-pie-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/apple-cranberry-crumble-pie-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/apple-cranberry-crumble-pie-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cranberry-crumble-pie/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 unbaked Flaky Pie Crust\u00a0(what I used) or\u00a0All-Butter Pie Crust*", "egg wash for pie crust: 1 large egg beaten with 1 Tablespoon milk", "1/2 cup (100g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "6 Tablespoons (46g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "5 Tablespoons (71g) unsalted butter, very cold and cubed", "1/2 cup (40g) old-fashioned whole rolled oats", "6 cups (750\u2013800g) 1/4-inch-thick apple slices (about 5 large peeled and cored apples)*", "1 and 1/4 cups (130g)\u00a0fresh or frozen cranberries (do not thaw)", "1/2 cup (100g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1/4 cup (31g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/2 teaspoon\u00a0orange zest", "1 teaspoon\u00a0ground cinnamon", "1/4 teaspoon\u00a0ground allspice", "1/4 teaspoon\u00a0ground nutmeg"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Prepare\u00a0my\u00a0pie crust\u00a0through step 5.", "name": "The crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cranberry-crumble-pie/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the brown sugar, flour, and cinnamon together in a medium bowl. Cut in the butter using a pastry cutter or forks until the mixture is crumbly. Stir in the oats. Refrigerate until ready to use.", "name": "Make the crumble topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cranberry-crumble-pie/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "After the pie dough chills, preheat oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C). Place a baking sheet on the bottom oven rack, to catch any juices that may spill over the sides of the pie.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cranberry-crumble-pie/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Roll out the chilled pie dough onto a lightly floured surface. Remember, when rolling out the pie dough, always use gentle force with your rolling pin. Start from the center and work your way out in all directions, rotating the dough with your hands as you go. Roll it out into a circle 12 inches in diameter. Carefully place the dough in a 9-inch pie dish. Tuck it in with your fingers, making sure it&#8217;s smooth. For a beautiful edge, fold the overhanging dough back over the edge and use your hands to mold the edge into a nice thick rim around the pie. Crimp the edges with a fork or use your fingers to flute the edges. For visuals and a video of this, see how to crimp and flute pie crust. Brush the edges with egg wash. Refrigerate for at least 10 minutes as you prepare the pie filling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cranberry-crumble-pie/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl, stir the apple slices, cranberries, brown sugar, flour, orange zest, cinnamon, allspice, and nutmeg together until thoroughly combined. Spoon the filling into the chilled crust. Sprinkle the cold crumble topping all over the filling.\u00a0", "name": "Make the filling and assemble", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cranberry-crumble-pie/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 20 minutes. Then, keeping the pie in the oven, reduce the oven temperature to 375\u00b0F (190\u00b0C). Place a pie crust shield (see Notes for homemade shield) on the edges to prevent them from over-browning. Continue baking the pie until the filling is bubbling around the edges, 35\u201340 more minutes. If you want to be precise, the internal temperature of the filling taken with an instant-read thermometer should be around 200\u00b0F (93\u00b0C) when done. Tip: If needed towards the end of bake time, remove the pie crust shield and tent an entire piece of foil on top of the pie if the top looks like it&#8217;s getting too brown.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cranberry-crumble-pie/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove pie from the oven, place on a cooling rack, and cool for at least 3 hours before slicing and serving. Filling will be too juicy if the pie is warm when you slice it. Serve with vanilla ice cream, if desired.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cranberry-crumble-pie/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u200b\u200bCover and store leftover pie at room temperature for up to 1 day or in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cranberry-crumble-pie/#instruction-step-8"}], "prepTime": "PT3H", "cookTime": "PT1H", "totalTime": "PT7H", "recipeYield": ["8", "serves 8-10"], "recipeCategory": "Pie", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "14", "ratingValue": "5"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Alanna"}, "datePublished": "2025-11-21", "reviewBody": "I'm making this 6 days before Thanksgiving.
