With a delicious homemade pie crust, tart and smooth lemon filling, and a fluffy toasted meringue topping, it's impossible to resist.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "Classic Lemon Meringue Pie", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/lemon-meringue-pie-recipe-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/lemon-meringue-pie-recipe-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/lemon-meringue-pie-recipe-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/lemon-meringue-pie-recipe-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-meringue-pie/", "recipeIngredient": ["Homemade Pie Crust*", "5 large egg yolks (use the whites in the meringue below)", "1 and 1/3 cups (320ml) water", "1 cup (200g) granulated sugar", "1/3 cup (38g) cornstarch", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "1/2 cup (120ml) fresh lemon juice", "1 Tablespoon lemon zest", "2 Tablespoons (28g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "5 large egg whites, at room temperature", "1/2 teaspoon cream of tartar", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "1/8 teaspoon salt"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "I like to make sure my pie dough is prepared before I begin making lemon meringue pie. I always make pie dough the night before because it needs to chill in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours before rolling out and blind baking (next step).", "name": "Pie crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-meringue-pie/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 375\u00b0F (190\u00b0C) and adjust your oven rack to the lowest position. Partially blind bake pie crust in a 9-inch pie dish. (Follow blind baking instructions through step 9. Be sure to crimp or flute the pie crust edges, too.) Tip: You can get started on the lemon meringue pie filling steps while your crust is blind baking. But making the filling is time sensitive because you will temper the egg yolks, so if multi-tasking isn&#8217;t your thing, just wait until your crust is done blind baking before beginning the filling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-meringue-pie/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Reduce oven temperature to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-meringue-pie/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Watch the video below to see how I work through each of the following steps.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-meringue-pie/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the egg yolks together in a medium bowl or liquid measuring cup. Set aside.\u00a0Whisk the water, granulated sugar, cornstarch, salt, lemon juice, and lemon zest together in a medium saucepan over medium heat. The mixture will be thin and cloudy, then eventually begin thickening and bubbling after about 6 minutes. Once thickened, give it a whisk and reduce heat to low.", "name": "Make the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-meringue-pie/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Very slowly stream a few large spoonfuls of warm lemon mixture into the beaten egg yolks. Then, also in a very slow stream, whisk the egg yolk mixture into the saucepan. Turn heat back up to medium. Cook until the mixture is thick and big bubbles begin bursting at the surface. Remove the pan from heat and whisk in the butter. Spread filling into the warm partially baked crust. Set aside as you prepare the meringue. (Don&#8217;t let the filling cool down too much as you want a warm filling when you top with the meringue in step 7. The warm filling helps seal the two layers together, preventing separation.)", "name": "Temper the egg yolks", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-meringue-pie/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a handheld mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the egg whites and cream of tartar together on medium speed for 1 minute, then increase to high speed until soft peaks form, about 4 more minutes. Add the sugar and salt, then continue beating on high speed until glossy stiff peaks form, about 2 more minutes. Spread meringue on top of filling. (I like to make decorative peaks with the back of a large spoon.) Make sure you spread the meringue all the way to the edges so that it touches the crust. This helps prevent the meringue from weeping.", "name": "Make the meringue:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-meringue-pie/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake pie on the lowest oven rack for 20-25 minutes. (If the meringue is browning too quickly, tent a piece of foil over it as best you can without the foil touching the meringue.) When pie is done, remove from the oven, place on a wire rack, and allow to cool at room temperature for 1 hour before placing in the refrigerator to chill. Chill for 4 hours before slicing and serving.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-meringue-pie/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover any leftovers and store in the refrigerator. Lemon meringue pie tastes best on day 1 because it doesn&#8217;t keep very well. No matter how hard you try to prevent it, the meringue will wilt and separate over time. Best to enjoy right away.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-meringue-pie/#instruction-step-9"}], "prepTime": "PT6H", "cookTime": "PT1H10M", "totalTime": "PT7H10M", "recipeYield": ["9", "one 9-inch pie"], "recipeCategory": "Pie", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "436", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Classic Lemon Meringue Pie | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "This is the perfect lemon meringue pie! Served with brown rice and vegetables or over a salad, this healthy dish is sure to join your regular dinner rotation.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "honey garlic shrimp", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/honey-garlic-shrimp-5-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/honey-garlic-shrimp-5-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/honey-garlic-shrimp-5-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/honey-garlic-shrimp-5.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/quick-healthy-dinner-20-minute-honey-garlic-shrimp/", "recipeIngredient": ["1/3 cup honey", "1/4 cup soy sauce (we usually use reduced sodium)", "2 garlic cloves, minced (or 1 teaspoon jarred minced garlic)", "optional: 1 teaspoon minced fresh ginger", "1 lb medium uncooked shrimp, peeled &amp; deveined", "2 teaspoons\u00a0olive oil", "optional for garnish: chopped green onion"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the honey, soy sauce, garlic, and ginger (if using) together in a medium bowl. You will use half for the marinade in step 2 and half for cooking the shrimp in step 3.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/quick-healthy-dinner-20-minute-honey-garlic-shrimp/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place shrimp in a large sealable container or zipped-top bag. Pour 1/2 of the marinade/sauce mixture on top, give it all a shake or stir, then allow shrimp to marinate in the refrigerator for 15 minutes or for up to 8-12 hours. Cover and refrigerate the rest of the marinade for step 3. (Time-saving tip: while the shrimp is marinating, we usually steam broccoli and microwave some quick brown rice.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/quick-healthy-dinner-20-minute-honey-garlic-shrimp/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Heat olive oil in a skillet over medium-high heat. First, it incorporates air into the dough, which helps keep the rolls nice and soft. It also encourages the proteins in the flour and moisture in the dough to link together, forming a strong gluten network, which is essential for retaining the gas produced by the yeast. Gluten is what makes bread deliciously chewy.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tried-true-honey-butter-rolls/#faq-question-1680859601533", "position": 2, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tried-true-honey-butter-rolls/#faq-question-1680859601533", "name": "When Do I Stop Kneading Dough?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "You know your kneaded dough is ready to rise when it stretches without immediately tearing. After kneading, the dough will be soft and supple, and a windowpane test is always helpful. You can poke the dough with your finger, too. If it slowly bounces back, it's ready to rise.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tried-true-honey-butter-rolls/#faq-question-1680859619504", "position": 3, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tried-true-honey-butter-rolls/#faq-question-1680859619504", "name": "What Is a Windowpane Test?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "After kneading, tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it's thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Honey Butter Rolls", "description": "You need just 7 ingredients to make these extra soft and flaky honey butter rolls. See recipe Notes for freezing and overnight instructions. You can also reference my Baking with Yeast Guide for answers to common yeast FAQs.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "honey butter rolls", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/homemade-honey-butter-rolls-4-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/homemade-honey-butter-rolls-4-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/homemade-honey-butter-rolls-4-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/homemade-honey-butter-rolls-4.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tried-true-honey-butter-rolls/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (240ml) whole milk, warmed to about 110\u00b0F (43\u00b0C)", "2 and 1/4 teaspoons (7g) Platinum Yeast from Red Star instant yeast\u00a0or active dry yeast\u00a0(1 standard packet)", "1/4 cup (85g) + 1 teaspoon honey, divided", "1 large egg + 1 egg yolk", "1/4 cup (4 Tbsp; 56g) unsalted butter, melted and slightly cooled", "3 and 1/2 cups (455g) bread\u00a0flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon salt", "1/4 cup (4 Tbsp; 56g) unsalted butter, very soft", "2\u00a0Tablespoons (42g) honey"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Whisk the warm milk, yeast, and 1 teaspoon honey together in the bowl of your stand mixer. Loosely cover and allow to sit for 5\u201310 minutes until foamy and frothy on top. *If you do not own a stand mixer, you can do this in a large mixing bowl and in the next step, mix the dough together with a large wooden spoon/silicone spatula. It will take a bit of arm muscle. A hand mixer works, but the sticky dough repeatedly gets stuck in the beaters. Mixing by hand with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula is a better choice.*", "name": "Prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tried-true-honey-butter-rolls/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With the stand mixer running on low speed with the dough hook attachment, add the remaining honey, egg, egg yolk, melted butter, 3 cups (about 390g) of flour, and salt. Mix on low speed for 1 minute, then add remaining 1/2 cup of flour. Mix on low speed for 1 minute as it all combines. The dough should be thick, yet soft, and just slightly sticky. It should pull away from the sides of the bowl as it mixes. When it does, it is ready to knead. If, however, the dough is too sticky to handle, mix in more flour, 1 Tablespoon at a time. Make sure you do not add too much extra flour; you want a soft, slightly sticky dough.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tried-true-honey-butter-rolls/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 8-10 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 8-10 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tried-true-honey-butter-rolls/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or nonstick spray. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides in the oil. Cover the bowl with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the dough to rise in a relatively warm environment for 1\u20132 hours or until double in size. (For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to Where Should Dough Rise? in my Baking With Yeast Guide.)", "name": "1st rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tried-true-honey-butter-rolls/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease a 9&#215;13-inch baking pan or two 9-inch square or round baking pans. You can also bake the rolls in a cast iron skillet or on a lined baking sheet.*", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tried-true-honey-butter-rolls/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When the dough is ready, punch it down to release the air. Divide the dough into 15 pieces, roughly 2 ounces or 60g each. (Just eyeball it\u2014doesn\u2019t have to be perfect!) A bench scraper is always helpful for cutting dough. Shape each piece into a smooth ball. Arrange in prepared baking pan.", "name": "Shape the rolls", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tried-true-honey-butter-rolls/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Loosely cover with plastic wrap and allow to rise until doubled in size and puffy, about 1 hour.", "name": "2nd rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tried-true-honey-butter-rolls/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Bake the rolls for 20\u201325 minutes or until golden brown on top, rotating the pan halfway through. If you notice the tops browning too quickly, loosely tent the pan with aluminum foil.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tried-true-honey-butter-rolls/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "While the rolls bake, mix the topping ingredients together to make a creamy honey butter. Their upgraded taste and texture puts them above the rest!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "pistachio chocolate chunk cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/salted-pistachio-chocolate-chunk-cookies-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/salted-pistachio-chocolate-chunk-cookies-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/salted-pistachio-chocolate-chunk-cookies-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/salted-pistachio-chocolate-chunk-cookies.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/salted-pistachio-chocolate-chunk-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "2/3 cup (133g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "2 cups (250g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "6 ounces (170g) chocolate, coarsely chopped*", "3/4 cup (75g) finely chopped pistachios, divided*", "coarse sugar for rolling (I use sugar in the raw brand)", "coarse sea salt or flaky sea salt, for sprinkling on top"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld mixer or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and brown sugar together on medium-high speed until combined and creamy, about 2 minutes. Beat in egg and vanilla extract on high speed. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed, and continue to beat until fully combined. On low speed, beat in the flour and salt until combined. The cookie dough will be thick and slightly sticky. Switch to high speed and beat in most of the chocolate (leave a few chunks aside for step 4) and 2/3 cup of the pistachios until combined.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/salted-pistachio-chocolate-chunk-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Turn the dough out onto a floured work surface and, with floured hands, divide or cut into two. Shape each half into an 8-inch log, about 2.5 inches in diameter. The measurements don&#8217;t have to be exact. Roll each log in a mix of coarse sugar and the leftover pistachios. Tightly wrap the logs in plastic wrap and chill in the refrigerator for at least 3 hours and up to 5 days. Chilling is mandatory for this cookie dough. I prefer to chill mine for 4 hours or even overnight\u2014the colder the dough, the thicker the cookies.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/salted-pistachio-chocolate-chunk-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).\u00a0Line two\u00a0large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats.\u00a0(Always recommended\u00a0for cookies.)\u00a0Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/salted-pistachio-chocolate-chunk-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Slice each log into 12\u00a0equally thick cookies and place cookies on baking sheets about 2 inches apart. (The chocolate chunks in the cookie dough will be very hard and may not slice, leaving gaps in some cookies. Press any extra chunks you set aside in step 1 into the tops, if needed.) \u00a0If desired, sprinkle each with sea salt.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/salted-pistachio-chocolate-chunk-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the cookies for 12-14 minutes or until brown around the edges.\u00a0Remove from the oven and allow cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/salted-pistachio-chocolate-chunk-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cookies will stay fresh covered at room temperature for 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/salted-pistachio-chocolate-chunk-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}], "prepTime": "PT3H30M", "cookTime": "PT14M", "totalTime": "PT4H", "recipeYield": ["2", "2 dozen cookies"], "recipeCategory": "Cookies", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "5", "ratingValue": "5"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Jennifer Crosby"}, "datePublished": "2021-03-22", "reviewBody": "I just made these, and they are phenomenal. My <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sky-high-chocolate-mousse-pie/\">Sky-High Chocolate Mousse Pie</a> is lighter and less sweet, made with an Oreo crust and an airy mousse structured with cooked egg whites and whipped cream.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "French Silk Pie", "description": "This French silk pie features my perfectly flaky pie crust, a smooth chocolate filling, and whipped cream on top. Read through the recipe and helpful notes before beginning.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "chocolate pie, chocolate", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/french-silk-pie-slice-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/french-silk-pie-slice-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/french-silk-pie-slice-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/french-silk-pie-slice-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-silk-pie/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 unbaked Flaky Pie Crust (what I used) or All Butter Pie Crust*", "egg wash for pie crust: 1 large egg beaten with 1 Tablespoon milk or heavy cream", "1 cup (240ml) heavy cream or heavy whipping cream", "two\u00a04-ounce quality bittersweet or semi-sweet chocolate\u00a0bars (113g each), finely chopped*", "4 large eggs", "1 cup (200g) granulated sugar", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1 cup\u00a0(240ml) heavy cream or heavy whipping cream", "2 Tablespoons\u00a0confectioners\u2019 sugar\u00a0or\u00a0granulated sugar*", "1/2 teaspoon\u00a0pure vanilla extract", "optional for garnish: chocolate curls*"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "I like to make sure my pie dough is prepared before I begin making this pie. Make pie dough the night before because it needs to chill in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours before rolling out and blind baking.", "name": "Pie crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-silk-pie/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "On a floured work surface, roll out one of the discs of chilled dough (use the 2nd pie crust for another recipe!). Turn the dough about a quarter turn after every few rolls until you have a circle 12 inches in diameter. Carefully place the dough into a 9-inch pie dish. Tuck it in with your fingers, making sure it is completely smooth. To make a lovely thick edge, I do not trim excess dough around the edges. Instead, fold the excess dough back over the edge and use your hands to mold the edge into a nice thick rim around the pie. Crimp the edges with a fork or use your fingers to flute the edges. (Review my how to crimp and flute pie crust tutorial if you need extra help with this step.) Chill the dough in the refrigerator or freezer for at least 30 minutes\u2014this helps prevent the crust from shrinking.", "name": "Roll out the chilled pie dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-silk-pie/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 375\u00b0F (191\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-silk-pie/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line the chilled pie crust with parchment paper. (Crunch up the parchment paper first so that you can easily shape it into the crust.) Fill with pie weights or dried beans. (Note that you will need at least 2 standard sets of pie weights to fit.) I like to push the weights up against the sides of the pie crust to help ensure the sides don&#8217;t shrink down. Bake until the edges of the crust are starting to brown, about 15\u201316 minutes. Remove pie from the oven and carefully lift the parchment paper (with the weights) out of the pie. Prick holes all over the bottom crust with a fork. If desired for a shiny golden crust, brush egg wash on edges. Return pie crust to the oven and bake for 14\u201315 minutes, or until bottom has browned. Remove from the oven, and cool on a wire rack completely before filling. You can blind bake the crust up to 3 days ahead of time. Cover cooled crust tightly and refrigerate until ready to fill. (Review this how to par-bake pie crust page if you need extra help with this blind-baking step.)", "name": "Blind bake the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-silk-pie/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, whip the heavy cream on medium-high speed until stiff peaks form, about 4 minutes. Stiff peaks hold their peak shape and do not droop. Set whipped cream in the refrigerator (covered or uncovered, doesn&#8217;t matter) until step 8. Melt the semi-sweet chocolate. You can melt it in a double boiler or the microwave. If using the microwave: place the chopped chocolate in a medium microwave-safe bowl. Microwave in 20-second increments, stopping and stirring after each increment until completely melted and smooth. Set aside until the end of the next step.", "name": "Start the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-silk-pie/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk eggs and sugar together in a heatproof bowl or the top piece of a double boiler. Place over a pot of simmering water (or the bottom part of your double boiler) on medium heat. Do not let the surface of the simmering water touch the bottom of the heatproof bowl. Whisking constantly, cook the egg mixture until it reaches 160\u00b0F (71\u00b0C) on an instant-read thermometer, about 10\u201311 minutes. If the steam gets too hot over your hand, use an oven mitt. (If you do not have an instant read thermometer, lightly and quickly dip your finger\u2014it\u2019s very hot, be careful\u2014and rub the mixture between your thumb and finger. You shouldn\u2019t feel any sugar granules.) Carefully remove from heat and allow to cool for 10 minutes. After cooling, slowly stir in the melted chocolate. To prevent curdling, cool for another 10 minutes before using in the next step.", "name": "Cook the eggs", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-silk-pie/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium-high speed until creamy, about 1\u20132 minutes. Add the vanilla and beat on medium-high speed for 30 seconds. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl. With the mixer running on low speed, pour in the chocolate/egg mixture and then increase to medium-high speed and beat for 3 minutes. With a silicone spatula, fold in the whipped cream until combined.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-silk-pie/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread filling into cooled pie crust. (A small offset spatula is helpful for this.) Cover tightly with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 4\u20136 hours or overnight, until chilled and thickened. Pie may be refrigerated for up to 2 days before serving.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-silk-pie/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, whip the heavy cream, sugar, and vanilla extract on medium-high speed until medium peaks form, about 3\u20134 minutes. Medium peaks are between soft and stiff peaks, and are the perfect consistency for topping and piping on desserts. Pipe or spread the whipped cream on top. Garnish with chocolate curls (see Notes), if desired. Serve immediately, or chill the pie uncovered for up to a few hours.", "name": "For the whipped cream topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-silk-pie/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftovers and store in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-silk-pie/#instruction-step-10"}], "prepTime": "PT4H", "cookTime": "PT40M", "totalTime": "PT8H", "recipeYield": ["9", "one 9-inch pie"], "recipeCategory": "Desserts", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "156", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "French Silk Pie | Sally's Baking Recipes", "description": "This creamy and indulgent French silk pie combines the best flaky pie crust, smooth-as-silk chocolate filling, and fresh whipped cream on top. Remove from heat and allow to cool uncovered at room temperature for 30 minutes.\u00a0You can make filling ahead, see instructions below.", "name": "The filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-hand-pies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "See my video above as a visual guide for the next few steps. On a lightly floured work surface, roll out one of the discs of chilled dough (keep the other one in the refrigerator). Turn the dough about a quarter turn after every few rolls. At any sign of sticking, sprinkle some flour underneath then keep rolling. Roll out until it&#8217;s about 12 inches in diameter and about 1/8\u20131/4-inch thick. Using your cookie cutter, cut into circles. Re-roll any scraps and cut into circles. Place cut circles in the refrigerator to keep cold. The colder the shaped dough, the easier it is to work with. Repeat with 2nd pie dough and refrigerate cut circles for at least 15 minutes before filling the hand pies.", "name": "Roll out the pie dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-hand-pies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Meanwhile, preheat oven to\u00a0375\u00b0F (191\u00b0C). Line two large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-hand-pies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Arrange half of the circles about 3 inches apart on prepared baking sheets. These are the bottom crusts. Using a sharp knife, cut slits into the remaining circles. These are the top crusts. The slits act as vents so that steam can escape as the hand pies bake. Place about 2 Tablespoons of filling in the center of each bottom crust. (Or however much fits while leaving the edges bare.) Place top crust on top. Press your fingers all around the edges to seal, then crimp the pie crust edges with a fork. If the hand pies lost some shape, use your hands to form a round circle again. It&#8217;s OK if some filling juice is leaking out. Lightly brush the top of the pie crust with egg wash mixture. Sprinkle with coarse sugar, if desired.", "name": "Fill the hand pies", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-hand-pies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "At this point the hand pies can be baked, but if they don&#8217;t feel cool to touch anymore, freeze for 10 minutes before baking. (I used my Joseph Joseph rolling pin for consistency and accuracy). The dough made 15 total hand pies (30 tops and bottoms) which was several more than Sally\u2019s because her cookie cutter was a bit larger than mine. I used 2 T of filling and I ended up running out of it after 9 pies. It's perfectly creamy and spiced with an ultra buttery flaky pie crust and a secret ingredient everyone loves!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "pumpkin slab pie, pumpkin pie", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/pumpkin-slab-pie-3-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/pumpkin-slab-pie-3-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/pumpkin-slab-pie-3-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/pumpkin-slab-pie-3.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-slab-pie/", "recipeIngredient": ["4 cups (500g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons salt", "1 teaspoon granulated sugar", "1 and 3/4 cup (396g) unsalted butter, very cold and cubed", "3/4 cup (180ml) very cold ice water", "egg wash:\u00a01 large egg, lightly beaten with 1\u00a0Tablespoon (15ml) milk", "2 (15 ounce) cans pure pumpkin (about 4 cups total; 900g)*", "2 cups (400g) light or dark brown sugar", "4 large eggs", "2 cups (480ml) heavy cream", "1/4 cup (60ml) whole milk", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "2 Tablespoons cornstarch", "2 teaspoons ground cinnamon", "3/4 teaspoon ground ginger", "1/2 teaspoon ground nutmeg", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1/8 teaspoon fresh ground pepper*", "optional: whipped cream"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Mix the flour, salt, and sugar together in a large bowl. Add the butter. Using a pastry cutter or two forks, cut the butter into the mixture until it resembles coarse meal (pea-sized bits with a few larger bits of fat is OK). A pastry cutter makes this step very easy and quick. Drizzle the cold water in, 1 Tablespoon (15ml) at a time, and stir with a silicone spatula or wooden spoon after every Tablespoon (15ml) added. Do not add any more water than you need. Stop adding water when the dough begins to form large clumps. I always use about 3/4 cup (180ml) water. Transfer the pie dough to a floured work surface. Using floured hands, fold the dough into itself until the flour is fully incorporated into the butter pieces. The dough should come together easily and should not feel overly sticky. Form dough into a ball. Cut off about 1/4 of the dough; this will be for the pie crust leaves and the rest will be for the actual pie. Flatten both into a 1-inch thick disc using your hands. Wrap each tightly in plastic wrap. Refrigerate for at least 2 hours (and up to 5 days) or freeze for up to 3 months. Thaw overnight in the fridge before using. *If not making pie crust leaves, just wrap all the dough up, chill, and use it all for the bottom crust.", "name": "Make the pie crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-slab-pie/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk all of the filling ingredients together in a large bowl. It will be a little thick. Cover and refrigerate until you need it; or refrigerate up to 3 days.", "name": "Make the filling:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-slab-pie/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 375\u00b0F (190\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-slab-pie/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove larger disc of\u00a0pie dough from the refrigerator. Keep the other in the refrigerator as you work. On a lightly floured\u00a0work surface, roll the dough out into (roughly) an\u00a018&#215;13-inch rectangle. Make sure to turn the dough about a quarter turn after every few rolls. Carefully place the dough into a 10&#215;15-inch jelly roll pan; there will be overhang on the sides.\u00a0Smooth the crust out so it fits nicely into all the corners of the pan.\u00a0Crimp or flute the pie crust edges, if desired. Brush edges lightly with the egg wash. Reserve remaining egg wash for step 6.", "name": "Roll out the chilled pie crust:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-slab-pie/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread filling evenly into the crust. Bake for 35-45 minutes or until the filling is only slightly jiggly in the very center. Remove from the oven, set on a wire rack, and allow to cool completely.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-slab-pie/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "As the pie cools, roll out remaining dough.\u00a0Roll out into any shape you really want (doesn&#8217;t matter) and 1/8 inch thickness. Using leaf cookie cutters, cut into shapes. Brush each lightly with egg wash. Cut leaf veins into leaves using a sharp knife or toothpick, if desired. Place onto a parchment paper or silicone baking mat-lined baking sheet and bake at\u00a0350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C) for 10 minutes or until lightly browned. Remove and\u00a0set aside to cool before decorating pie.", "name": "Pie crust leaves", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-slab-pie/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Decorate pie with pie crust leaves and/or whipped cream. So not quite a jelly roll pan. I used this pan for a pumpkin roll cake and it turned out great. Just wondering how much of a difference it will make with this slab pie?"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Lydia"}, "datePublished": "2023-11-27", "reviewBody": "The pie turned out great! Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/monster-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium-high speed until smooth, about 1 minute. Add the granulated sugar and brown sugar and beat on medium-high speed until creamed, about 2 minutes. Stop and scrape down the sides of the bowl as needed. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the eggs, peanut butter, and vanilla and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/monster-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the dry ingredients and oats to the wet ingredients and beat on low speed until combined. Bake for 14\u201316 minutes, or until the edges are set and lightly browned. We recommend chilling first, then shaping. If after chilling the dough is very hard and difficult to scoop, let it sit at room temperature for 15 minutes and then try again.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chewy-chocolate-chip-cookies/#faq-question-1744297150248", "position": 2, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chewy-chocolate-chip-cookies/#faq-question-1744297150248", "name": "Can I chill the dough in the freezer instead of the refrigerator to speed up the chilling process?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "We typically do not recommend jumping right to the freezer without chilling the dough first. A quick freeze like that can cause the dough to chill unevenly and then spread unevenly during the baking process. For best results, we recommend following the recipe as written. If you don't have time to wait for the dough to chill, try this recipe for 6 <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/giant-chocolate-chip-cookies/\">giant chocolate chip cookies</a> instead, which doesn't require dough chilling (see recipe Notes in that post for details on using the dough to make 24 regular-size cookies).", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Chewy Chocolate Chip Cookies", "description": "These super soft and chewy chocolate chip cookies are the most popular cookie recipe on my website for good reason. Melted butter, more brown sugar than white sugar, cornstarch, and an extra egg yolk guarantee the absolute chewiest chocolate chip cookie texture. The cookie dough is slick and requires chilling prior to shaping the cookies. This recipe is also in my New York Times best-selling cookbook, Sally's Baking 101.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "chocolate chip cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/classic-chocolate-chip-cookies-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/classic-chocolate-chip-cookies-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/classic-chocolate-chip-cookies-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/classic-chocolate-chip-cookies.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chewy-chocolate-chip-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 1/4 cups (281g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons cornstarch*", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (170g/12 Tbsp) unsalted butter, melted &amp; cooled for 5 minutes", "3/4 cup (150g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "1 large egg + 1 egg yolk, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1 and 1/4 cups (225g) semi-sweet chocolate chips or chocolate chunks"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl, whisk the flour, baking soda, cornstarch, and salt together. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chewy-chocolate-chip-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk the melted butter, brown sugar, and granulated sugar together until no lumps remain. Whisk in the egg and egg yolk until combined, then whisk in the vanilla extract. The mixture will be thin. Pour into dry ingredients and mix together with a large spoon or spatula. The dough will be very soft, thick, and shiny. Fold in the chocolate chips. The chocolate chips may not stick to the dough because of the melted butter, but do your best to combine them.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chewy-chocolate-chip-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover the dough tightly and refrigerate for at least 2 hours or up to 3 days. I highly recommend chilling the cookie dough overnight to prevent overspreading.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chewy-chocolate-chip-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 325\u00b0F (163\u00b0C). Line large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. If the dough has chilled for longer than 2 hours, let it sit at room temperature for about 15 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chewy-chocolate-chip-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a cookie scoop or Tablespoon measuring spoon, scoop the chilled cookie dough, about 3 scant Tablespoons (about 2 ounces, or 60g) of dough for XL cookies or 2 heaping Tablespoons (about 1.75 ounces, or 50g) of dough for medium-large cookies. Roll into a ball, then use your fingers to shape the cookie dough so that it&#8217;s taller rather than wide\u2014almost like a cylinder. This helps the cookies bake up thicker. Repeat with remaining dough. Arrange the cookies 3 inches apart on the prepared baking sheets.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chewy-chocolate-chip-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the cookies for 13\u201314 minutes or until the edges are very lightly browned. The centers will look very soft, but the cookies will continue to set as they cool. Cool on the baking sheet for 10 minutes before transferring to a cooling rack to cool completely. While the cookies are still warm, I like to press a few more chocolate chips into the tops\u2014this is optional and only for looks!\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chewy-chocolate-chip-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Store tightly covered at room temperature for up to 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chewy-chocolate-chip-cookies/#instruction-step-7"}], "prepTime": "PT15M", "cookTime": "PT13M", "totalTime": "PT2H45M", "recipeYield": ["16", "16 XL cookies or 20 medium/large cookies"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "1755", "ratingValue": "4.7"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Chewy Chocolate Chip Cookies | Sally's Baking Recipes", "description": "These super soft and chewy chocolate chip cookies are the most popular cookie recipe on my website for good reason. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed.", "name": "For the cookies", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/funfetti-cookies-supreme/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk the flour, baking soda, cream of tartar, cornstarch, and salt together\u00a0until combined.\u00a0With the mixer running on low speed, slowly add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients in 3 different parts. The dough is quite thick and will be a little crumbly at first. But if you keep mixing, the dough will come together. Once combined, gently beat in the\u00a0sprinkles\u00a0on low speed until evenly disbursed. Cover the cookie dough tightly and chill in the refrigerator for at least 3 hours and up to 3 days. Chilling is mandatory. Alternatively, you can roll the cookie dough into 1.5 Tablespoon balls and chill on a cookie sheet (covered) and then bake as directed in the next step.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/funfetti-cookies-supreme/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove cookie dough from the refrigerator and let sit out at room temperature for at least 15 minutes. If the cookie dough chilled longer than 3 hours, allow to sit at room temperature for 30-40 minutes. This makes it easy to handle, while still keeping a firm texture from chilling. Preheat oven to 325\u00b0F (163\u00b0C) and line 2 large cookie sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Roll cookie dough into balls, about 1.5 Tablespoons of dough in each ball (a medium cookie scoop is helpful for this), and set on cookie sheet\u2014about 8-9 cookies per sheet. Bake in batches for 11-12 minutes or until the edges are slightly browned. The cookies will still appear very soft in the centers. That&#8217;s ok; they&#8217;ll set up and become firmer as they cool. Allow the cookies to cool on the cookie sheets for 3 minutes, then move to a wire rack to cool completely.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/funfetti-cookies-supreme/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld mixer or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until creamy\u2014about 2 minutes. Add confectioners&#8217; sugar, cream, vanilla extract, and salt with the mixer running on low. Increase to high speed and beat for 3 full minutes. Add more confectioners&#8217; sugar if frosting is too thin, more cream if frosting is too thick, or a pinch more of salt if frosting is way too sweet.", "name": "For the frosting", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/funfetti-cookies-supreme/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Frost the cooled cookies as desired and decorate with more sprinkles. I love your site so far.\r\n\r\nFor anyone interested in alternative dough chilling time in the freezer, I experimented with the following:\r\n1. I chilled all of the dough in the refrigerator for 1 hour. \r\n2. After an hour, I wanted to speed up the baking time so I took some of the dough out of the fridge and chilled it for 45 minutes. I baked these cookies as instructed and they came out perfect!\r\n3. For the remaining dough, I let it chill for an additional 2 hours in the fridge (total 3 hours). Before starting, review the helpful video tutorial below and the success tips above.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "stained glass window cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/stained-glass-window-cookies-with-candy-centers-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/stained-glass-window-cookies-with-candy-centers-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/stained-glass-window-cookies-with-candy-centers-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/stained-glass-window-cookies-with-candy-centers.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/stained-glass-window-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 1/4 cups (281g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed for rolling and work surface", "1/2 teaspoon baking powder", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (150g) granulated sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "15-20 unwrapped hard candies, such as Jolly Ranchers or Life Savers", "1 large egg white OR 2 Tablespoons (30ml) water", "1/3 cup (65g) coarse sugar or sprinkles"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking powder, and salt together in a medium bowl. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/stained-glass-window-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on high speed until completely smooth and creamy, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg and vanilla and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/stained-glass-window-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix on low until combined. Dough will be a bit soft. If the dough seems too soft and sticky for rolling, add 1 more Tablespoon of flour.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/stained-glass-window-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Divide the dough into 2 equal parts. Place each portion onto a piece of lightly floured parchment paper or a lightly floured silicone baking mat. With a lightly floured rolling pin, roll the dough out to about 1/4-inch thickness or slightly thinner (anywhere between 1/8 &#8211; 1/4 inch is fine). Use more flour if the dough seems too sticky. The rolled-out dough can be any shape, as long as it is evenly thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/stained-glass-window-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly dust one of the rolled-out doughs with flour. Place a piece of parchment on top. (This prevents sticking.) Place the 2nd rolled-out dough on top. Cover with plastic wrap or aluminum foil, then refrigerate for at least 1-2 hours and up to 2 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/stained-glass-window-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "As the cookie dough chills, begin crushing the candies. The best way to crush the hard candies is to separate them by color, place each color in plastic bags, and crush them with a rolling pin or meat mallet. Don&#8217;t crush the candies into a fine powder\u2014crush them into fine pebble-sized bits. The crushed candies will pierce the bag no matter how careful you are. Some candy dust will escape, so just know that this step is messy. If you don&#8217;t want to use plastic, use a paper bag or paper plate. (A bag is preferred so candy doesn&#8217;t go flying everywhere.) Set crushed candy aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/stained-glass-window-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once cookie dough has chilled, preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line 2-3 large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Carefully remove the top dough piece from the refrigerator. If it&#8217;s sticking to the bottom, run your hand under it to help remove it\u2014see me do this in the video above. Using your large cookie cutter, cut the dough into shapes. Using your small cookie cutter, cut out the center shape. (You don&#8217;t need the center piece\u2014re-roll it!) Re-roll all the remaining dough and continue cutting until all is used. Repeat with 2nd piece of dough. Note: It doesn&#8217;t seem like a lot of dough, but you get a lot of cookies from the dough scraps you re-roll.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/stained-glass-window-cookies/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Carefully arrange cookies on baking sheets 3 inches apart. If your cookies are intricately shaped, use two hands to transfer them to the lined baking sheet.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/stained-glass-window-cookies/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If using an egg white, beat it lightly with a fork or small whisk for 10 seconds. It&#8217;s easier to brush onto tops of cookies if it&#8217;s beaten first. Brush tops of shaped cookies with egg white or water. Sprinkle coarse sugar/sprinkles on top.", "name": "Optional Topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/stained-glass-window-cookies/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Fill the cut-out centers about 3/4 full with crushed candies. The candy pieces melt and expand, so you don&#8217;t need to over-fill. I use and recommend 1 color per cookie, but feel free to mix for a spotty multicolor look. The candies are sticky, so wipe off your fingers as needed.", "name": "Fill Cookie Centers", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/stained-glass-window-cookies/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 12-13 minutes or until candies have melted and the cookies are lightly browned around the edges. If your oven has hot spots, rotate the baking sheet halfway through bake time. Allow cookies to cool on the baking sheet until the melted candy center sets, about 15 minutes. Once melted candy center has set, transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/stained-glass-window-cookies/#instruction-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store cookies at room temperature for up to 1 week. For longer storage, cover and refrigerate for up to 10 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/stained-glass-window-cookies/#instruction-step-12"}], "prepTime": "PT2H30M", "cookTime": "PT13M", "totalTime": "PT3H", "recipeYield": "24", "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "173", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Stained Glass Cookies | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "Learn how to make stained glass window cookies using my favorite sugar cookie recipe. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the eggs and vanilla extract, and beat on high speed for 2 full minutes. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl, then beat on high for 1 more minute. Pour in the slightly cooled melted chocolate and mix on medium-high speed for 2 full minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour in the the dry ingredients and beat on low speed until combined. This quick chill time helps slightly solidify the chocolate and butter in the dough, which gives the cookies a nice spread (not over-spread). Chilling for longer creates thicker cookies where, in some cases, they may not spread at all. If chilling for longer than 20 minutes, allow the dough to sit at room temperature for 15 minutes before rolling and baking.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brownie-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Roll or scoop the dough into balls, 1.5 Tablespoons of dough each. The egg yolks are gently cooked on the stovetop, but the egg whites are raw. Purchase pasteurized eggs because they are safe to consume raw. If you can't find pasteurized eggs, you can omit the egg whites entirely. Set aside and have ready to go!", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tiramisu/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "You will form 2 layers each of dipped ladyfingers and mascarpone cream. Let&#8217;s begin with the 1st layer of ladyfingers. Whisk the espresso and Grand Marnier together in a shallow bowl. One at a time, quickly dip each side of the ladyfinger into the espresso mixture. You don&#8217;t want to over-saturate the ladyfinger with liquid because then the ladyfingers will taste soggy. Just a quick dip on each side. Arrange the dipped ladyfingers in the baking pan to make one solid layer. If needed, cut some ladyfingers to fill in any empty spaces. Reserve remaining espresso mixture and ladyfingers for another layer.", "name": "Dip half of the ladyfingers", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tiramisu/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the mascarpone and rum together on medium speed in a large bowl for a few seconds, just to combine. Do not overmix. Set aside.", "name": "Begin the mascarpone cream", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tiramisu/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If you have a double boiler, use it in this step. If you don&#8217;t, place a heatproof bowl over a small pot of simmering water over medium-low heat. Don&#8217;t let the water touch the bottom of the bowl.\u00a0 Using a whisk or eggbeater (I simply use a whisk), whisk the egg yolks and 1/4 cup (50g) of granulated sugar together until light and foamy, about 5 minutes. Remove from the heat and immediately pour into the mascarpone mixture. Beat on medium speed until combined.", "name": "Prepare a double boiler for the egg yolks", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tiramisu/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the heavy cream and vanilla extract together on medium-high speed until medium peaks form, about 3 minutes. Medium peaks are between soft/loose peaks and stiff peaks and are the perfect consistency for the tiramisu cream. Fold the whipped cream into the mascarpone mixture.", "name": "Whip the heavy cream", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tiramisu/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a *clean* whisk attachment, beat the egg whites and salt together on medium-high speed until foamy, about 1 minute. Increase to high speed and slowly pour in the remaining 1/4 cup (50g) of sugar. Beat until stiff peaks form, about 4-5 minutes. (Do not over-beat as the egg whites will become dry.) Fold into the mascarpone cream.", "name": "\u00a0Beat the egg whites", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tiramisu/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread half of the mascarpone cream evenly over bottom layer of ladyfingers. Gently press each down so they are nice and compact. Using an offset spatula, spread remaining mascarpone mixture evenly on top. If you&#8217;re using a large enough pan, it should all fit (but it will definitely tower high!). As instructed in step 1, be sure to cool the brown butter used for the batter until it's no longer warm.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "brown butter berry tea cakes", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/brown-butter-berry-tea-cakes-3-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/brown-butter-berry-tea-cakes-3-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/brown-butter-berry-tea-cakes-3-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/brown-butter-berry-tea-cakes-3.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brown-butter-berry-tea-cakes/", "recipeIngredient": ["10 Tablespoons (142g) unsalted butter", "4 large egg whites (140g), at room temperature", "1 cup (105g) almond flour", "2/3 cup (85g) all-purpose flour", "3/4 cup (150g) granulated sugar", "1/2 teaspoon baking powder", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "1 teaspoon lemon zest", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1 cup (130g) fresh blackberries, raspberries, or blueberries (see note)", "optional: 1/4 cup (30g) confectioners&#8217; sugar for dusting on top"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Set out a medium heat-proof bowl because you\u2019ll need it at the end of this step. Slice the butter into Tablespoon-size pieces and place in a light-colored skillet or saucepan. A light-colored interior is crucial for determining when the butter begins to brown. (See Notes if using a dark skillet or pan.) Melt the butter over medium heat and stir or whisk constantly. Once melted, the butter will begin to foam. Continue stirring/whisking, keeping a close eye on it. After about 5\u20137 minutes, the butter will begin browning and you\u2019ll notice lightly browned specks forming at the bottom of the pan. The butter will have a nutty aroma. The color will gradually deepen, from yellow to golden to golden-brown; once it&#8217;s a light caramel-brown color, remove from heat immediately and pour into the bowl, including any brown solids that have formed on the bottom of the pan. Separate out 2 Tablespoons of brown butter\u2014we&#8217;ll brush that in the muffin pans in step 2. Cool the remaining brown butter (about 1/2 cup) for 30 minutes in the refrigerator, or until room temperature and no longer warm. Don\u2019t cool longer than that because the butter will begin to solidify.", "name": "Brown the butter", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brown-butter-berry-tea-cakes/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Using a pastry brush, brush the cups of a 24-count mini muffin pan with the 2 Tablespoons of browned butter. This recipe yields 30\u201336 tea cakes, so grease a 2nd pan or bake the batter in batches. If using mini muffin liners, brush the liners with the brown butter.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brown-butter-berry-tea-cakes/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, whip the egg whites on high speed in a large bowl until soft peaks form, about 2\u20133 minutes. Add the almond flour, all-purpose flour, granulated sugar, baking powder, salt, and lemon zest. Beat on low speed until combined and don&#8217;t worry that the egg whites deflate, you&#8217;ll still taste their fluffy goodness in the cakes! Mixture will be sticky, lumpy, and thick. Pour in the vanilla extract and cooled brown butter and beat on low speed until combined.", "name": "Make the tea cakes", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brown-butter-berry-tea-cakes/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon 2 teaspoons of batter into each greased muffin cup. Lightly poke a berry into the center of each. No need to submerge the berry, just stick it on top.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/brown-butter-berry-tea-cakes/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 14\u201316 minutes or until the edges are golden brown. Do not bring to a rapid boil\u2014that&#8217;s too hot. After 1 minute of simmering, remove from heat.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/scotcheroos/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Stir in the peanut butter and vanilla extract until combined, then stir in the crispy rice cereal until it&#8217;s all completely coated.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/scotcheroos/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Transfer mixture to prepared pan. Using a silicone spatula, gently spread mixture to fit the pan. Very gently press the mixture down into the pan. Do not pack it down with force, just lightly press down so it\u2019s secure in the pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/scotcheroos/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Combine chopped chocolate, butterscotch morsels, and coconut oil in a small saucepan over medium-low heat. Stir constantly until it&#8217;s melted together. Mixture will be thick. Spread evenly over bars. A small offset spatula is helpful for this. Meanwhile, pat your diced strawberries dry with a paper towel. You don&#8217;t want them too wet. (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes video &amp; post.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the cake flour, salt, baking powder, and baking soda together. Set aside.", "name": "Make the cake:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on high speed until smooth and creamy, about 3 minutes. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed. Beat in the 3 eggs, 2 egg whites, and vanilla extract on high speed until combined, about 2 minutes. (Mixture will look curdled as a result of the egg liquid and solid butter combining.) Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. With the mixer on low speed, add the dry ingredients just until combined. With the mixer still running on low, pour in the buttermilk and mix just until combined. You may need to whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no lumps at the bottom of the bowl. The batter will be slightly thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour batter evenly into cake pans. Weigh them to ensure accuracy, if desired. Bake for around 23-26 minutes or until the cakes are baked through. To test for doneness, insert a toothpick into the center of the cake. If it comes out clean, it&#8217;s done. Allow cakes to cool completely in the pans set on a wire cooling rack. The cakes must be completely cool before frosting and assembling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld mixer or stand mixer fitted with a whisk or paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until creamy, about 2 minutes. Add confectioners&#8217; sugar, milk, vanilla extract, and salt with the mixer running on low. Increase to high speed and beat for 2 minutes. Add more confectioners&#8217; sugar if frosting is too thin, more milk if frosting is too thick, or an extra pinch of salt if frosting is too sweet.", "name": "Make the frosting:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a large serrated knife,\u00a0slice\u00a0a thin layer off the tops of the cakes\u00a0to create a flat surface. Discard (or crumble over ice cream!).\u00a0Place 1 cake layer on your cake stand, cake turntable, or serving plate.\u00a0Evenly cover the top with about 1 and 1/2 cups of frosting. Top with 2nd cake layer and\u00a0evenly cover the top with about 1 and 1/2 cups of frosting. Top with the third cake layer.\u00a0Spread the remaining frosting all over the top and sides. You should have about 3 cups crumbs, or 330g. Pour crumbs into a large bowl. Add the melted butter and stir to combine. The mixture will be thick and quite wet. Try to smash/break up any large chunks. Pour the mixture into an ungreased 9&#215;13-inch pan. With medium pressure using your hand, pat the crumbs down into the bottom to make a compact, thick crust. (Closer to 30 minutes is ideal.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-5-layer-ice-cream-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "During that time, place the 2nd ice cream flavor into a bowl and stir it until it is smooth and very soft. You may have to slightly heat it if using store-bought. Spread it on top of the ice cream as best you can. Because it is not as cold as the ice cream layer, the two will slightly mix together as you spread. That&#8217;s ok. Freeze for 15\u201330 minutes. (Closer to 30 minutes is ideal.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-5-layer-ice-cream-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the heavy cream, confectioners&#8217; sugar, and vanilla on medium-high speed until stiff peaks form, about 4\u20135 minutes.
