Roll into a ball. Measure about 2 Tablespoons (40g) of peanut butter cookie dough. Roll into a ball. Press the 2 balls together between your hands and roll them into 1 large ball. Repeat for each cookie. The chocolate cookie dough is particularly sticky, so wipe your hands clean after every few balls of dough you shape.\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-baked-peanut-butter-chocolate-swirl-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the cookies for 12\u201314 minutes or until the edges appear set and the centers still look soft. See video tutorial in the recipe for inspiration.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "cookie decorating buttercream", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/sugar-cookies-with-buttercream-decoration-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/sugar-cookies-with-buttercream-decoration-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/sugar-cookies-with-buttercream-decoration-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/sugar-cookies-with-buttercream-decoration.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookie-decorating-buttercream/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 batch sugar cookies, baked &amp; cooled completely", "1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "4 cups (480g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) heavy cream, half-and-half, or whole milk, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1/8 teaspoon salt", "optional: gel food coloring, for tinting"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Have your cookies baked and cooled completely. You can use this recipe, or your favorite recipe for cookies.\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookie-decorating-buttercream/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until creamy, about 2 minutes. Add the confectioners&#8217; sugar, heavy cream, vanilla extract, and salt. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to medium-high speed and beat for 2 full minutes. Taste. To thicken the buttercream, beat in more confectioners&#8217; sugar. To thin out the buttercream, beat in more heavy cream. To help offset more sweetness, beat in an extra pinch of salt.", "name": "Make the buttercream", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookie-decorating-buttercream/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Color the icing: If you\u2019d like to tint the frosting, divide it into separate bowls for each color, or tint the entire batch one color. A little gel food coloring goes a long way, so use a toothpick to dot the gel into the icing. Stir it in, and then add more to deepen the color if desired.\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookie-decorating-buttercream/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Use piping tips or knife/icing spatula: You can use a\u00a0knife or icing spatula to frost the cookies. Or, if using piping tips, fit a piping/pastry bag with a piping tip (and use a coupler if you plan to switch frosting colors and/or piping tips). Spoon the buttercream into the bag, making sure to leave a few inches of space at the top of the bag. Twist the end of the bag or use a clip to seal it shut. You can pipe zig-zags, swirls, lines, dots, or whatever your heart desires! A tired teacher thanks you for the help!"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "3"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sara Brown"}, "datePublished": "2025-12-08", "reviewBody": "Points off for specifying milliliters instead of grams for the cream: Sally, why do you do this for liquid measurements? Doing so makes no sense: a milliliter is a unit of volume, not weight, so specifying \"2 Tablespoons (30ml) heavy cream\" is just giving two volume measurements, one of which is impossible to measure accurately as 30 milliliters is not a measurement that is readily available in a spoon or a cup in the US, not sure about elsewhere. (Pyrex measuring cups do offer milliliter lines, but the common ones measure 50 milliliters as the smallest amount.) Please note that, unlike with water, 30 milliliters of heavy cream is not equal to 30 grams of heavy cream -- 30 milliliters of heavy cream would weigh less than 30 grams, as it is lighter than water. \r\n\r\nI like to use weight measurements because I can tare the bowl on a scale and add the ingredient right into the bowl. It is easy, accurate, and requires fewer utensils that have to be washed. Specifying liquids in milliliters rather than grams is an annoying obstacle to accurate, efficient baking. \r\n\r\nP.S. Sally, I think I saw that you are collaborating with Bake from Scratch? Their recipes always specify grams for liquids, never milliliters."}], "datePublished": "2024-12-01", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookie-decorating-buttercream/#recipe", "isPartOf": There is so much texture in every bite of these holiday cookies!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "white chocolate cranberry pistachio cookies, white chocolate cranberry cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/white-chocolate-cranberry-pistachio-cookies-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/white-chocolate-cranberry-pistachio-cookies-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/white-chocolate-cranberry-pistachio-cookies-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/white-chocolate-cranberry-pistachio-cookies.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/white-chocolate-cranberry-pistachio-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (150g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1/4 cup (50g) granulated sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature*", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "2 cups (250g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 teaspoons cornstarch\u00a0(aka cornflour)", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (135g) white chocolate\u00a0morsels or chopped white chocolate", "3/4\u00a0cup (75g) dried cranberries", "1/2 cup (62g) salted pistachios, shells removed"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld mixer or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter for 1 minute on medium speed in a large bowl until completely smooth and creamy. Add the brown sugar and granulated sugar and mix on medium high speed until fluffy and light in color. Beat in egg and vanilla on high speed. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/white-chocolate-cranberry-pistachio-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a separate bowl,\u00a0whisk the\u00a0flour, cornstarch, baking soda and salt together until combined. On low speed, slowly mix into the wet ingredients until combined. The cookie dough will be quite thick. Add the white chocolate chips, dried cranberries, and pistachios, mix on low for about 5-10 seconds until evenly disbursed. Cover dough tightly with aluminum foil or plastic wrap and chill in the refrigerator for at least 2\u00a0hours and up to 2 days. Chilling is mandatory for this cookie dough.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/white-chocolate-cranberry-pistachio-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove cookie dough from the refrigerator and allow to sit at room temperature for 10 minutes\u2014if the cookie dough chilled longer than 2 hours, let it sit at room temperature for about 30 minutes. This makes the cookie dough easier to scoop and roll. Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line two large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/white-chocolate-cranberry-pistachio-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once chilled, the dough will be slightly crumbly, but will come together if you work the dough with your hands as you roll into individual balls. Scoop and roll balls of dough, about 1 Tablespoon of dough each, into balls. Bake for 8-10 minutes, until barely golden brown around the edges. They will look extremely soft when you remove them from the oven. Allow to cool for 5 minutes on the cookie sheet. If the cookies are too puffy, try gently pressing down on them with the back of a spoon. They will slightly deflate as you let them cool. Transfer to cooling rack to cool completely.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/white-chocolate-cranberry-pistachio-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}], "prepTime": "PT2H15M", "cookTime": "PT10M", "totalTime": "PT2H45M", "recipeYield": ["24", "24 cookies"], "recipeCategory": "Cookies", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "10", "ratingValue": "4.7"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Stacey"}, "datePublished": "2025-01-04", "reviewBody": "So good! Set aside. In another medium bowl, beat the eggs and sugar with a stand mixer (with paddle attachment) or electric handheld mixer until light and foamy, about 2 minutes. While beating, slowly pour in the butter and then the vanilla. While mixing, add half the dry ingredients, then add all the milk, and follow with the rest of the dry ingredients. Do NOT overmix the batter. I chose this recipe because I didn't have cake flour on hand, and I'm glad I did. They took me back to my childhood. I was not a fan of the frosting - too much butter for me. So, I scraped it off and mixed up a batch using about 2TButter and then added cocoa (more than you called for), vanilla, powdered sugar and milk until the texture was what I wanted. Whisk in the egg, then the peanut butter until combined. Finally, whisk in the vanilla. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and mix together with a large spoon or silicone spatula. The dough will be very soft and slick. Fold in the oats and the M&amp;Ms. Allow the cookie dough to sit for 15 minutes\u2014the oats will absorb some moisture, making the dough easier to work with.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-cup-surprise-monster-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "You can use the photos above as visuals for this step.\u00a0Take 1 Tablespoon of dough and slightly flatten out on the prepared baking sheet. Stick a peanut butter cup on top, as shown above. Top the peanut butter cup with 1.5 Tablespoons of cookie dough\u00a0and seal down the sides so that the peanut butter cup is securely stuffed inside. You can pick it up and roll into a smooth ball if needed. Slightly flatten down the top as best you can (it can&#8217;t be totally flat because of the peanut butter cup inside).\u00a0Repeat with the rest of the dough and peanut butter cups.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-cup-surprise-monster-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the cookies for 12-13\u00a0minutes. Add up to 1/2 cup more confectioners\u2019 sugar if frosting is too thin or another Tablespoon of cream if frosting is too thick. Add a pinch of salt if frosting is too sweet. Sprinkle lightly with cornmeal, which gives the crust extra crunch and flavor.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/spinach-artichoke-white-cheese-pizza/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When the homemade dough is ready, punch it down to release any air bubbles. Divide the dough in half and freeze half the dough for another time\u2014see freezing instructions in the pizza dough recipe. On a lightly floured work surface using lightly floured hands or rolling pin, gently flatten the dough into a disc. Place on prepared pan and, using lightly floured hands, stretch and flatten the disc into a 12-inch circle, about 1/2-inch thick. If the dough keeps shrinking back as you try to stretch it, stop what you&#8217;re doing, cover it lightly and let it rest for 5\u201310 minutes, then try again. Once shaped into a 12-inch circle, lift the edge of the dough up to create a lip around the edges. I simply pinch the edges up to create the rim. If using a pizza stone, place the dough directly on a baker\u2019s peel dusted with cornmeal. Cover dough lightly with plastic wrap or a clean kitchen towel and allow to rest for a few minutes as you gather the pizza toppings.", "name": "Shape the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/spinach-artichoke-white-cheese-pizza/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using your fingers, push dents into the surface of the dough to prevent bubbling. This takes at least 5 minutes of cutting in with a pastry cutter.", "name": "Make the crumble mixture for the crust and topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-rhubarb-crumb-bars/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the egg, milk, and vanilla together in a small bowl. See photo above for a visual.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-rhubarb-crumb-bars/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "You will have about 6 cups of the crust/crumble mixture. Set 2 cups aside. Pour the remaining into the prepared pan and flatten down with your hands or a flat spatula to form an even crust. It will be a little crumbly\u2014that&#8217;s ok. Set aside. (Oats will be used in the topping in the next step.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-rhubarb-crumb-bars/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Gently mix all of the filling ingredients together. With the back of a large spoon or flat spatula, lightly press the topping down so it\u2019s a bit snug on the strawberry rhubarb layer.", "name": "Strawberry Rhubarb Filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-rhubarb-crumb-bars/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for about 42-50 minutes or until the top is lightly browned and a toothpick comes out *mostly* clean (with a few jammy strawberry/rhubarb specks!). Mine take about 45 minutes. Remove from the oven and allow the bars to cool completely in the pan set on a wire rack. Cover and allow to sit for 5 minutes.", "name": "Prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-berry-fritters/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the remaining 7 Tablespoons of sugar, eggs, butter, vanilla extract, salt, nutmeg, and 1 cup flour. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, scrape down the sides of the bowl with a silicone spatula, then add the remaining flour. Beat on medium speed until the dough comes together and pulls away from the sides of the bowl, about 2 minutes. If needed, add more flour, 1 Tablespoon at a time, until the dough pulls away from the sides of the bowl. Don&#8217;t add too much flour, though. You want a slightly sticky dough. *If you do not own a mixer, you can mix this dough with a large wooden spoon or silicone spatula. It will take a bit of arm muscle!*", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-berry-fritters/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 5-7 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5-7 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-berry-fritters/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or nonstick spray. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides in the oil. Cover the bowl with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the dough to rise in a relatively warm environment for 1-2 hours or until double in size. (I always let it rise on the counter. Takes about 2 hours. For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to Where Should Dough Rise? in my Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-berry-fritters/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When the dough is ready, punch it down to release the air. Turn it out onto a lightly floured work surface and with lightly floured hands, flatten the dough into a long oval about 1/2 inch thick. You can use a rolling pin if needed, but your hands should be able to stretch it out just fine. Spread blueberries onto half of the dough, as pictured above. Fold the dough over the blueberries, then seal the edges. Using your hands, work the dough into an even log, making sure the edges are totally sealed. Using a sharp knife or bench scraper, cut the dough into about 12 even strips, then cut 4-5 perpendicular strips to make a cross pattern of sorts. This is NOT an exact process, so don&#8217;t stress. You really just need a bunch of small pieces of blueberry-filled dough! Divide the cut-up dough into 12 even pieces. Mold each into a round shape and try to &#8220;enclose&#8221; the blueberries inside the dough as much as you can. (They&#8217;ll fall out of the fritters otherwise.) Place the shaped fritters on a lined baking sheet, then cover and allow to rest as you heat the oil. They will rise a bit as they rest.", "name": "Shape the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-berry-fritters/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place a cooling rack on a large baking sheet. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-berry-fritters/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour oil into a large heavy-bottomed pot set over medium heat. Using a candy/oil thermometer, heat the oil to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). This will take several minutes. Add 2 fritters at a time and fry for 1-2 minutes on each side or until golden brown. Wear kitchen gloves if oil is splashing. Carefully remove with a metal spatula or metal slotted spoon. Place fritters onto prepared rack. Repeat with remaining fritters, then turn off the heat.* Some blueberries may come loose in the oil. Discard those since they&#8217;ll taste burnt.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-berry-fritters/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Let the fritters cool for a few minutes as you prepare the glaze.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-berry-fritters/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place confectioners&#8217; sugar in a medium bowl. Set aside. Pur\u00e9e the strawberries in a food processor. Scrape down the sides if needed. If they aren&#8217;t pureeing into a liquid, add 1 Tablespoon of the heavy cream, half-and-half, or milk you are using in the glaze. Once liquefied, pour over confectioners&#8217; sugar, then add the cream/milk, and vanilla extract. Whisk until smooth. If needed, add more cream/milk to thin out or more confectioners&#8217; sugar to thicken.", "name": "Strawberry Glaze:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-berry-fritters/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Dunk each fritter into glaze. Place back onto prepared rack for excess glaze to drip down. The glaze will eventually set on the fritters after about 20-30 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-berry-fritters/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Fritters are best enjoyed the same day. A generous drizzle of creamy vanilla icing seeps into every delicious pocket.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "raspberry twist bread", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/08/raspberry-danish-twist-bread-4-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/08/raspberry-danish-twist-bread-4-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/08/raspberry-danish-twist-bread-4-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/08/raspberry-danish-twist-bread-4.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-danish-twist-bread/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 1/4 teaspoons\u00a0Platinum Yeast from Red Star instant yeast* (1 standard packet)", "3 Tablespoons granulated sugar", "3/4 cup (180ml) whole milk", "1/4 cup (4 Tablespoons; 56g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "2 large eggs", "3 and 1/2 cups (438g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed", "1 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (240g)\u00a0raspberry preserves/jam", "optional: 1/2 cup (80g) fresh or frozen raspberries", "1 cup (120g) confectioners&#8217;\u00a0sugar", "3 Tablespoons (45ml) heavy cream\u00a0(or half-and-half or milk)", "1/4 teaspoon pure vanilla extract"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Place the yeast and sugar in the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a dough hook or paddle attachment. Or, if you do not own a stand mixer, a regular large mixing bowl. Heat the milk on the stove or in the microwave until warm to touch, about 110\u00b0F (43\u00b0C). Pour warm milk on top of yeast/sugar. Whisk gently to combine, then loosely cover with a clean kitchen towel and allow to sit for 5-10 minutes. The mixture will be frothy after 5-10 minutes.", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-danish-twist-bread/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Add the butter, egg, flour, and salt. Beat on low speed for 4 minutes. Dough will be soft.", "name": "If you do not have a mixer, you can mix by hand in this step", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-danish-twist-bread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-danish-twist-bread/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the dough in a greased bowl (I use nonstick spray to grease) and cover\u00a0with plastic wrap or aluminum foil. Place in a slightly warm environment to rise until doubled in size, about 90 minutes. For this warm spot, I suggest using the oven. Preheat to 200\u00b0F (93\u00b0C), then turn the oven off after preheating. Place the covered bowl inside and shut the oven door. This is your warm environment.", "name": "1st rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-danish-twist-bread/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease a 9-inch springform pan.\u00a0Turn the risen dough out onto a lightly floured work surface, punch it down to release the air.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-danish-twist-bread/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a rolling pin, roll into a 12&#215;16 inch rectangle. Spread jam evenly on top. If desired, dot randomly with raspberries. Tightly roll up the dough to form a 16-inch long log. Place the log on its seam. Using a sharp knife, cut the log in half lengthwise. I find a serrated knife works best. Criss-cross one half on top of the other half\u2014forming an X. Twist the two together then coil into a circle. Carefully transfer to prepared springform pan. (I carefully pick it up using two flat spatulas!) Cover the twist with plastic wrap or aluminum foil, then allow to rise once again in a slightly warm environment until puffy, about 45 minutes.", "name": "Shape the twist &amp; 2nd rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-danish-twist-bread/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Adjust the oven rack to the lower third position then preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-danish-twist-bread/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake until golden brown, about 40-45 minutes. If you find the top is browning too quickly, tent with aluminum foil. Remove from the oven and allow to cool for 5 minutes. Meanwhile, make the vanilla icing by whisking the icing ingredients together until smooth.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-danish-twist-bread/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Carefully remove the rim of the springform pan. Drizzle with vanilla icing. Slice and serve.\u00a0Cover and store leftovers in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-danish-twist-bread/#instruction-step-9"}], "prepTime": "PT3H15M", "cookTime": "PT45M", "totalTime": "PT4H", "recipeYield": ["8", "serves 8-10"], "recipeCategory": "Breakfast", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "28", "ratingValue": "4.5"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Raspberry Danish Twist Bread | Sally's Baking Recipes", "description": "This raspberry twist bread comes together with a rich brioche style dough, raspberry jam, and sweet vanilla icing. I always prefer recipes with weight measurements.  They are accurate.  \r\nOne simple error in my opinion   in the instructions.  A contradiction of terms possibly. \"...Beat on low speed.\"  Beat is usually a term in mixers as a higher speed than \"Low\".  I was a bit confused on using pe paddle or dough hook during the \"Beating\".  I used the paddle during the \"Beating\", and the dough hook forr the \"Kneading:\r\nThe dough,  was spot on for this type of pastry.\r\nI did not add the optional whole raspberries.  Kind of wished I would have to add a touch more raspberry taste.\r\nA tip.  When rolling the dough to form the 16\" log, Try lifting the back of the roll more than just rolling to avoid squeezing out the raspberry jam.  I used a pastry scrapper-cutter to lift it into the pan.\r\nWell worth trying."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Emma"}, "datePublished": "2025-04-18", "reviewBody": "Very good. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-macadamia-nut-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the melted butter, brown sugar, granulated sugar, egg, egg yolk, and vanilla extract together until combined. Pour into dry ingredients and mix everything together until completely combined. Fold in the macadamia nuts and coconut. (You can use a mixer for this step if needed.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-macadamia-nut-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and chill the dough in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours and up to 4 days. It's dense, yet soft and has the most incredible crusty exterior.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "Irish soda bread", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/irish-soda-bread-loaf-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/irish-soda-bread-loaf-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/irish-soda-bread-loaf-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/irish-soda-bread-loaf.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/grandmas-irish-soda-bread/", "recipeIngredient": ["\u00a01 and 3/4 cups (420ml) buttermilk*", "1 large egg (optional, see note)", "4 and 1/4 cups (531g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more for your hands and counter", "3 Tablespoons (38g) granulated sugar", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "1 teaspoon salt", "5 Tablespoons (71g) unsalted butter, cold and cubed*", "optional: 1 cup (150g) raisins"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C). There are options for the baking pan. Use a regular baking sheet and line with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat (bread spreads a bit more on a baking sheet), or use a seasoned 10-12 inch cast iron skillet (no need to preheat the cast iron unless you want to), or grease a 9-10 inch cake pan or pie dish. You can also use a 5 quart (or higher) dutch oven. Grease or line with parchment paper. If using a dutch oven, bake the bread with the lid off.", "name": "Preheat oven &amp; pan options", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/grandmas-irish-soda-bread/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the buttermilk and egg together. Set aside. Whisk the flour, granulated sugar, baking soda, and salt together in a large bowl. Cut in the butter using a pastry cutter, a fork, or your fingers. Mixture is very heavy on the flour, but do your best to cut in the butter until the butter is pea-sized crumbs. Stir in the raisins. Pour in the buttermilk/egg mixture. Gently fold the dough together until dough it is too stiff to stir. Pour crumbly dough onto a lightly floured work surface. With floured hands, work the dough into a ball as best you can, then knead for about 30 seconds or until all the flour is moistened. If the dough is too sticky, add a little more flour.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/grandmas-irish-soda-bread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Transfer the dough to the prepared skillet/pan. (&#8220;Score&#8221; = shallow cut.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/grandmas-irish-soda-bread/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake until the bread is golden brown and center appears cooked through, about 45-55 minutes. Bakery cruffins are usually taller than this homemade version because they\u2019re baked in deeper pans, such as popover pans. Since many home bakers don\u2019t have popover pans, this recipe is designed for a standard muffin pan.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally McKenney", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "cruffins", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/cruffins-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/cruffins-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/cruffins-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/cruffins.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cruffins/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup\u00a0(240ml)\u00a0whole milk, warmed to about\u00a0110\u00b0F (43\u00b0C)", "2\u00a0and 1/4 teaspoons (7g)\u00a0instant\u00a0or\u00a0active dry yeast\u00a0(1 standard packet)", "3 Tablespoons (38g)\u00a0granulated sugar", "3 Tablespoons (43g) unsalted or salted butter, softened to room temperature and cut into 3 pieces", "3 cups (375g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed", "1 and 1/4 teaspoons salt", "1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g) salted butter, slightly softened (see Note)", "1 Tablespoon all-purpose flour", "3/4 cup (150g) granulated sugar", "1 Tablespoon ground cinnamon", "optional fillings: 6 Tablespoons Nutella, jam, lemon curd, or pastry cream"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Use the step-by-step photos as visuals before you begin. Read the recipe instructions and notes before beginning. Make room in the refrigerator for your baking sheet for steps 6\u201310.", "name": "Preliminary notes", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cruffins/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the warm milk, yeast, and sugar together in the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a dough hook attachment. Cover and allow mixture to sit for about 5 minutes or until foamy on top. *If you do not own a mixer, you can do this in a large mixing bowl and in the next step, mix the dough together with a large wooden spoon/silicone spatula. A hand mixer works, but the sticky dough repeatedly gets stuck in the beaters. Mixing by hand with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula is a better choice.*", "name": "Prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cruffins/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the butter, 2 cups (250g) of flour, and the salt. Beat on medium speed for 2 minutes, stopping and scraping down the bowl as needed to help the mixture combine. There may still be chunks of butter\u2014that&#8217;s ok. Add the remaining 1 cup (125g) of flour, scrape down the bowl as needed, and beat on low speed until a soft dough forms and pulls away from the sides of the bowl. Dough will be soft, but not overly sticky. Beat in 2 more Tablespoons of flour if dough seems very sticky. Avoid adding more flour than you need.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cruffins/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cruffins/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or use nonstick spray. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides of the dough in the oil. Tightly cover the bowl and allow the dough to rise in a relatively warm environment for around 2 hours or until nearly double in size. (For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to Where Should Dough Rise?\u00a0in my\u00a0Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "1st rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cruffins/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Gently punch down the dough to release the air. Place dough on a lightly floured silicone baking mat&#8211; or parchment paper-lined baking sheet. (I highly recommend a silicone baking mat because you can roll the dough out in the next steps directly on top and it won\u2019t slide all over the counter.) Gently flatten the dough out into a 10&#215;14-inch (25x36cm) rectangle using lightly floured hands to carefully stretch, but not tear, the dough. (You could also use a floured rolling pin.) Lightly cover and place the entire baking sheet in the refrigerator, and allow the covered dough to rest and chill for 20 minutes. Do not extend this time.", "name": "Flatten dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cruffins/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Make sure the butter is slightly softened but still cool\u2014between 60\u201364\u00b0F (15\u201318\u00b0C) is ideal. Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and 1 Tablespoon flour together until completely combined. It&#8217;s important to note the following 3 tips before you begin laminating: (1) Have a bowl of flour at hand to continually flour your surface and rolling pin as needed. If the dough tears and butter is exposed, sprinkle the exposed butter with flour. (2) If the dough is impossible to roll, try flipping it over. If it&#8217;s still impossible to roll, cover and let it rest for 5 minutes before trying again, to let the gluten relax. (3) Do not extend the refrigeration times, because the folded dough will begin to over-expand, and it will also become very difficult to roll out.", "name": "Meanwhile, prepare for lamination", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cruffins/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove dough from the refrigerator and set the baking sheet aside. I like to keep the dough on the silicone baking mat when I\u2019m rolling it because the mat is nonstick. Working with the longer (14-inch) edge in front of you, spread the beaten butter down the center of the dough, covering the center third of the dough. Fold one dough edge over on top of butter, and fold other edge on top of that (like folding a business letter). Pinch/seal the two short ends to enclose butter inside. Rotate dough so the long edge is horizontally in front of you. Lightly flour the top of the folded dough and, using a lightly floured rolling pin, roll out to a 9&#215;12-inch (23x30cm) rectangle. Fold dough edges over on top like folding a business letter. Cover dough, place back on baking sheet, and refrigerate 20 minutes. Do not extend this time.", "name": "1st lamination", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cruffins/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove dough from the refrigerator and set baking sheet aside. Rotate dough so the long edge is horizontally in front of you. Lightly flour the top of the folded dough and, using a lightly floured rolling pin, roll out to a 9&#215;12-inch (23x30cm) rectangle. Fold dough edges over on top like folding a business letter. Rotate dough horizontally and repeat rolling out to 9&#215;12 inches and folding like a business letter. Cover dough, place back on baking sheet, and refrigerate 20 minutes.\u00a0", "name": "2nd lamination", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cruffins/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Remove dough from the refrigerator and set baking sheet aside. Rotate dough so the long edge is horizontally in front of you. Lightly flour the top of the folded dough and, using a lightly floured rolling pin, roll out to a 9&#215;12-inch (23x30cm) rectangle. Fold dough edges over on top like folding a business letter. Rotate dough horizontally and repeat rolling out to 9&#215;12 inches and folding like a business letter. Cover dough, place back on baking sheet, and refrigerate 20 minutes.\u00a0", "name": "3rd lamination", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cruffins/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a standard 12-cup muffin pan. In a medium bowl, mix together the sugar and cinnamon. Remove dough from the refrigerator and set baking sheet aside. Place the chilled dough on a cutting board and cut into 3 even rolls. (You can also cut the dough into thirds right on the silicone baking mat, but make sure you are not using a super sharp knife on your baking mat\u2014I use a bench scraper.)", "name": "Shape &amp; fill", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cruffins/#instruction-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "(Note: this step can get messy!) Lightly flour your work surface and rolling pin. Working with one portion of dough at a time, roll out to an 8&#215;12-inch rectangle. If it keeps shrinking back as you try to roll it out, let it rest for 5 minutes and then try again. It will eventually relax enough to get to 12 inches in length. Sprinkle evenly with 2 Tablespoons of cinnamon-sugar, and use the back of a spoon or a spatula to press it down into the dough. With a pizza cutter or sharp knife, cut 12 1-inch strips of dough. You can mark them out first with a ruler/measuring tape and a knife. Working with 3 strips at a time, layer them on top of one another. Roll them up together in a spiral and tuck the ends underneath. Place in one cup of the prepared muffin pan. Repeat this step with the remaining 2 portions of dough to get 12 cruffins.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cruffins/#instruction-step-12", "image": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/shaping-cruffins-dough-3.jpg", "height": "800", "width": "1200"}}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover cruffins lightly and allow to rise for 1 hour, until puffy.\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cruffins/#instruction-step-13", "image": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/unbaked-cruffins.jpg", "height": "800", "width": "1200"}}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to\u00a0350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cruffins/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 25\u201328 minutes, or until the internal temperature reaches 200\u00b0F (93\u00b0C). Remove from the oven and let the cruffins slightly cool in the pan set on a cooling rack.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cruffins/#instruction-step-15"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once cool enough to handle, roll each cruffin in the remaining cinnamon-sugar.\u00a0At this point you can enjoy the cruffins plain, or fill them with your filling of choice. Fill a piping bag (reusable or disposable) fitted with a long, skinny filling tip, such as Wilton 230, with the filling. Poke a hole 3/4 of the way down into the cruffin with a skewer (or just insert the long piping tip) and squeeze to fill the cruffin.", "name": "Coat the cruffins and fill, if desired", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cruffins/#instruction-step-16"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store leftover cruffins at room temperature for up to 3 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cruffins/#instruction-step-17"}], "prepTime": "PT4H45M", "cookTime": "PT25M", "totalTime": "PT5H45M", "recipeYield": ["12", "12 cruffins"], "recipeCategory": "Pastries", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "French", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "405", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Cruffins | Sally's Baking", "description": "Buttery and flaky croissant dough gets twisted up with a generous dose of cinnamon-sugar and baked in a muffin pan, combining two tasty treats into one: croissants + muffins = cruffins. A four layered bar with a brown sugar and oat crust, topped with a creamy peach filling, pecan streusel, and finished off with luscious vanilla icing.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "peaches n cream bars, peach streusel bars", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/Peaches-n-Cream-Bars-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/Peaches-n-Cream-Bars-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/Peaches-n-Cream-Bars-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/Peaches-n-Cream-Bars.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peaches-cream-bars/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (125g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/2 cup (43g) old-fashioned whole rolled oats (or quick oats)", "1/3 cup (67g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "10 Tablespoons (142g) unsalted butter, cold and cubed", "optional: 1/2 cup (70g) chopped pecans", "1 large egg", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "1 Tablespoon (8g) all-purpose flour", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "2 medium peaches, peeled and chopped (about 1.5 cups)", "1/2 cup (60g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) milk", "1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C) degrees. Line the bottom and sides of an 8-inch or 9-inch square baking pan with aluminum foil or parchment, leaving an overhang on all sides to easily lift the bars out of the pan before cutting. Spray with nonstick spray or grease with butter. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peaches-cream-bars/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl, whisk the flour, oats, brown sugar, and cinnamon together until combined. Cut in the cold butter using a pastry blender or two forks until it reaches coarse, pea-sized crumbs. See photo above. Remove 3/4 cup of the mixture, put in a small bowl and mix with pecans. This will be set aside for the topping.", "name": "Make the crust/topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peaches-cream-bars/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Evenly press the remaining oat mixture into the bottom of the prepared baking pan. Bake for 15 minutes as you prepare the filling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peaches-cream-bars/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the egg and sugar together until smooth and creamy. Add the flour and salt. Whisk until combined. Fold in the peaches. Remove crust from the oven after 15 minutes and pour the filling over hot crust. Sprinkle with reserved oat/pecan mixture.", "name": "Make the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peaches-cream-bars/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 30-32 minutes or until golden brown on top. Allow to cool in the pan on a wire rack for 30 minutes. Transfer to the refrigerator and allow to chill for 2 hours.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peaches-cream-bars/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once chilled, lift the foil out of the pan using the overhang on the sides and cut into squares. Soft and buttery with a chewy/crisp crust, this fresh loaf of bread will quickly become a staple in your kitchen. See recipe notes for freezing and overnight instructions. You can also reference my Baking with Yeast Guide for answers to common yeast FAQs.\u00a0", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "bread, loaf, sandwich, white bread", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/homemade-sandwich-bread-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/homemade-sandwich-bread-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/homemade-sandwich-bread-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/homemade-sandwich-bread.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sandwich-bread/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (240ml) water, warmed to about 110\u00b0F (43\u00b0C)", "1/4 cup (60ml) whole milk, warmed to about 110\u00b0F (43\u00b0C)", "2 and 1/4 teaspoons (7g) Platinum Yeast from Red Star instant yeast (1 standard packet)", "2 Tablespoons (25g) granulated sugar", "4 Tablespoons (1/4 cup; 56g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons salt", "3 and 1/3 cups (about 420\u2013430g) all-purpose flour or bread flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the warm water, warm milk, yeast, and sugar together in the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a dough hook attachment. Cover and allow to sit for 5 minutes.", "name": "Prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sandwich-bread/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the butter, salt, and 1 cup flour. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, scrape down the sides of the bowl with a silicone spatula, then add another cup of flour. Beat on medium speed until relatively incorporated (there may still be chunks of butter). Add the remaining flour and beat on medium speed until the dough comes together and pulls away from the sides of the bowl, about 2 minutes. *If you do not own a mixer, you can mix this dough with a large wooden spoon or silicone spatula. It will take a bit of arm muscle!*", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sandwich-bread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 5\u20138 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5\u20138 full minutes. (If you&#8217;re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need; you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a &#8220;windowpane test&#8221; to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it&#8217;s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sandwich-bread/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with olive oil or nonstick spray. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides in the oil. Cover the bowl and allow the dough to rise in a relatively warm environment for 1-2 hours or until double in size. (I always let it rise on the counter. Takes about 2 hours. For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to Where Should Dough Rise? in my Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "1st Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sandwich-bread/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease a 9&#215;5-inch loaf pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sandwich-bread/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When the dough is ready, punch it down to release the air. Lightly flour a work surface, your hands, and a rolling pin. Roll the dough out into a large rectangle, about 8&#215;15 inches. It does not have to be perfect\u2014in fact, it will probably be rounded on the edges. That&#8217;s ok! Roll it up into an 8 inch log and place in the prepared loaf pan.", "name": "Shape the bread", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sandwich-bread/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover shaped loaf with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow to rise until it&#8217;s about 1 inch above the top of the loaf pan, about 1 hour. Have fun with fillings! I provide some filling ideas in the recipe notes. We strongly recommend using gram measurements, but see recipe note if you do not have a kitchen scale.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "macarons, French macarons", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/french-macarons-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/french-macarons-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/french-macarons-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/french-macarons.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-macarons/", "recipeIngredient": ["100g egg whites (usually between 3\u20134 large egg whites)", "1/4 teaspoon (1g) cream of tartar", "1/2 teaspoon extract such as vanilla, almond, coconut, etc. (optional)", "80g superfine sugar (aka caster sugar, see note)", "1\u20132 drops gel food coloring (optional)", "125g almond flour", "125g confectioners&#8217; sugar\u00a0", "desired macaron filling (some options listed in notes)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Wipe down a large glass or metal mixing bowl with lemon juice or vinegar. Add egg whites. Cover and refrigerate for 24 hours, then bring to room temperature.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-macarons/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line 3 large baking sheets with silicone baking mats or parchment paper. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-macarons/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add cream of tartar and extract (if using) to egg whites. Using a handheld mixer or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat together on medium speed until very soft peaks form. This takes a few minutes of beating. At first the egg white and cream of tartar mixture will be foamy, then the bubbles will begin to tighten and the beaters will leave tracks as the egg whites build volume. Once they begin leaving tracks, you likely have soft peaks. Stop beating. Add about 1/3 of the superfine sugar. Beat on medium-high speed for 5 seconds, then with the mixer continuing to run, add another 1/3 of the sugar. Beat for 5 seconds, then with the mixer continuing to run, add the remaining sugar. Beat on medium-high speed until stiff glossy peaks form. (This means the whites have stiff, smooth, and sharp points in the bowl or on the lifted whisk attachment/beaters. Stiff peaks do not droop down. You can turn the bowl upside down and the egg whites will not move or spill out.)\u00a0Using a rubber spatula, slowly and gently fold the food coloring (if using) into the egg whites.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-macarons/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Sift the almond flour and confectioners&#8217; sugar together in a large glass or metal mixing bowl. Use a spoon to help work any larger pieces through the sieve. You don&#8217;t want to discard a lot of that because then you won&#8217;t have enough dry ingredients in the batter.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-macarons/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Slowly fold the beaten egg whites into the almond flour mixture in 3 separate additions, folding until combined before adding the next addition. After you add all of the egg whites, pay very close attention to the consistency of your macaron batter. Continue folding the batter (which deflates air) until it thins out into the consistency of honey. What&#8217;s a more helpful cue is the figure 8 test. Drop the macaron batter off of your spatula in the form of a figure 8. The figure 8 should take no more than 10 seconds to sink back into itself. If it takes less, your batter was overmixed and is too thin. If it takes longer, continue slowly folding the batter to deflate more air, then perform the figure 8 test again. It&#8217;s best to go very slow so you don&#8217;t accidentally overmix.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-macarons/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon the macaron batter into a piping bag fitted with a medium round piping tip, such as Wilton 12, Wilton 1A, or even Ateco 806. The macaron batter is very drippy, so transferring to the piping bag can be messy.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-macarons/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Holding the piping bag at a 90 degree angle over the baking sheet, pipe batter in 1.5 &#8211; 2 inch rounds about 1-2 inches apart on prepared baking sheets. I usually pipe little mounds\u2014see video tutorial above. The piped macaron batter flattens out. Bang the pan a couple times on the counter to pop any air bubbles, then use a toothpick to pop any remaining air bubbles.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-macarons/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Let the piped macarons sit out until they are dry and no longer tacky on top, usually 30-60 minutes. This time allows the top to firm up and form a skin, which helps the macarons rise UP and form their trademark ruffly &#8220;feet.&#8221; Do not let them sit out for longer than they need to because they could begin to deflate.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-macarons/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Meanwhile, preheat the oven to 325\u00b0F (163\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-macarons/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 13 minutes. As the macaron shells bake, they should form feet. To test for doneness, lightly touch the top of a macaron with a spoon or your finger (careful, it&#8217;s hot). If the macaron seems wobbly, it&#8217;s not done and needs another 1-2 minutes. If it seems set, it&#8217;s done. Basically, bake until the macarons don&#8217;t move around when touched.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-macarons/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Let the shells cool on the baking sheet for 15 minutes, then transfer to a cooling rack to continue cooling. The macaron shells may stick to the parchment paper/baking sheet if you try to remove them too early. If this is happening, let them cool on the baking sheet a little longer before removing.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-macarons/#instruction-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "After cooling, the shells are ready to fill and sandwich together. I have plenty of filling suggestions in the recipe notes below. You can spread filling with a knife or pipe it using\u00a0the same round tip you used for the macaron batter.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-macarons/#instruction-step-12"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "You can eat right away or, as some professionals prefer, cover and refrigerate them 12-24 hours so the macarons and flavors can mature. Bring to room temperature before serving. (I usually just serve them right away!)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-macarons/#instruction-step-13"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover macarons and refrigerate for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/french-macarons/#instruction-step-14"}], "prepTime": "PT1H", "cookTime": "PT13M", "totalTime": "PT1H30M", "recipeYield": ["40", "about 40 shells; 20 sandwiched macarons"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "French", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "578", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "French Macarons | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "This French macarons video shows you each step to help guarantee success on your first batch. See recipe notes below.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "peach bread", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/peach-bread-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/peach-bread-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/peach-bread-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/peach-bread.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-quick-bread/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 Tablespoons\u00a0(25g) packed light or dark\u00a0brown sugar", "3 Tablespoons (24g) all-purpose flour", "1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "2 Tablespoons (28g)\u00a0unsalted butter, cold and cubed", "2 cups (250g)\u00a0all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon\u00a0baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon\u00a0salt", "1\u00a0large\u00a0egg, at room temperature", "3/4 cup\u00a0(150g)\u00a0granulated sugar", "1/3 cup\u00a0(80ml)\u00a0vegetable oil", "1/2 cup (120g)\u00a0sour cream\u00a0(or plain yogurt/Greek yogurt), at room temperature*", "1/2 cup (120ml) whole milk, at room temperature*", "1 teaspoon\u00a0pure vanilla extract", "1/2 teaspoon almond extract", "1 and 1/2 cups (about 260g) peeled and chopped peaches (about 2 medium-large peaches)", "1 Tablespoon (12g) granulated sugar", "1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Spray a 9&#215;5-inch loaf pan with nonstick spray.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-quick-bread/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Make the crumb topping first. Mix the brown sugar, flour, and cinnamon together. Add the cold butter and using a pastry cutter or fork, cut butter into the brown sugar mixture until pea-size crumbles form. You can also use your hands to mix it together. Refrigerate (or freeze) until ready to use in step 5. (The colder it is, the less likely it will sink down into the bread and lose its crumbly texture.)", "name": "Crumb Topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-quick-bread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together in a large bowl. In a medium bowl, whisk the egg and granulated sugar together until combined. Whisk in the oil, sour cream, milk, vanilla extract, and almond extract. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients, then whisk to completely combine. Avoid over-mixing. You will have about 3 cups of batter.", "name": "Bread", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-quick-bread/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Mix the peach layer ingredients together.", "name": "Peaches", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-quick-bread/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour/spread half of the batter into prepared loaf pan. Spoon/spread the peaches (and any juices) evenly on top. Carefully pour/spread remaining batter evenly on top. Using a knife, swirl the batter down the center of the loaf pan. Evenly sprinkle crumb topping on top.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peach-quick-bread/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the bread for 60-65 minutes, covering loosely with foil about halfway through to prevent the top from over-browning. Poke the center of the bread with a toothpick. If it comes out clean, the bread is done. Oven times will vary between ovens. My bread usually takes 1 hour. The recipe below includes both. For all make-ahead instructions, see recipe notes. I recommend watching the video tutorial above and reading the full recipe below before beginning. There's a lot of cooling down, chilling, and other moving parts here!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "yule log, Christmas cake, chocolate, hazelnut", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/buche-de-noel-yule-log-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/buche-de-noel-yule-log-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/buche-de-noel-yule-log-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/buche-de-noel-yule-log.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buche-de-noel-yule-log/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (100g) fresh cranberries (do not use frozen)", "4-5 rosemary sprigs", "3/4 cup (180ml) water", "1 and 1/4 cups (250g) granulated sugar, divided", "1 and 1/3 cups (157g) cake flour", "2 Tablespoons (10g) unsweetened natural or dutch-process cocoa powder", "1 teaspoon baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "6 large eggs, separated and at room temperature", "1 cup (200g) granulated sugar, divided", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) vegetable\u00a0oil, canola oil, or melted coconut oil", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "3 Tablespoons (15g) unsweetened natural or dutch-process cocoa powder", "1 large egg white, at room temperature", "less than 1/8 teaspoon cream of tartar (about 1/16 teaspoon)", "pinch salt", "2 Tablespoons (25g) granulated sugar", "1/2 teaspoon unsweetened natural or dutch-process cocoa powder (optional for dusting)", "1 ounces (28g) semi-sweet chocolate, finely chopped", "1 and 1/2 cups (360ml) cold heavy cream", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) Frangelico liqueur", "1/4 cup (30g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1 Tablespoon (5g) unsweetened natural or dutch-process cocoa powder", "1/2 cup (60g) finely chopped hazelnuts (optional)", "6 ounces (170g) semi-sweet chocolate, finely chopped", "3/4 cup (180ml) heavy cream"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If you want to decorate the cake with sugared cranberries and rosemary, start them the night before because they need to sit for several hours.\u00a0 Place cranberries and rosemary in a large heatproof bowl. Set aside. In a medium saucepan set over medium heat, bring the water and 3/4 cup (150g) of sugar to a simmer, whisking until the sugar has dissolved. Remove the pan from heat and allow to cool for 5 minutes. Pour the sugar syrup over the cranberries and rosemary and stir. Cover the bowl and set aside for 15 minutes. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat. Using a slotted spoon, transfer the cranberries and rosemary from the sugar syrup and place them on the prepared baking sheet. Allow to dry, uncovered, for 1 hour. Pour remaining 1/2 cup (100g) sugar into a large bowl. Toss the cranberries and rosemary in the sugar, coating them all the way around. Place on a parchment paper\u2014or silicone baking mat-lined baking sheet and let them dry uncovered for at least 1 hour at room temperature or in the refrigerator. Cover tightly and store in the refrigerator for up to 3 days. For more uses, see how to make sugared cranberries.", "name": "Make the sugared cranberries and rosemary", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buche-de-noel-yule-log/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Spray\u00a0a\u00a012&#215;17-inch baking pan with nonstick spray or grease with butter, so the parchment paper sticks. Then line it with parchment paper so the cake seamlessly releases. Spray or grease the parchment paper too. We want an extremely nonstick surface for this cake roll.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buche-de-noel-yule-log/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the cake flour, cocoa powder, baking powder, and salt together in a medium bowl. Set aside until the next step. Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with whisk attachment, beat the egg whites and 1/2 cup (100g) sugar together on high speed for 4-5 minutes or until stiff peaks form. Transfer to another bowl. Using the same mixing bowl you just had the egg whites in (no need to clean it), add the egg yolks, remaining sugar, oil, and vanilla extract. Beat together on high speed for 3-4 minutes or until thickened and light in color.", "name": "Make the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buche-de-noel-yule-log/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add half of the whipped egg whites into the egg yolk mixture. Beat on low speed for 10 seconds. Repeat with remaining egg whites and beat on low for 10 seconds. Add half of the flour mixture and beat on low or fold with a silicone spatula until combined. Repeat with remaining flour mixture. Avoid over-mixing and deflating those egg whites. Batter will be very light.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buche-de-noel-yule-log/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread batter evenly into prepared pan. Gently bang the pan on the counter a couple times to pop any air bubbles. Bake for 15-16 minutes or until the cake springs back when lightly poked with your finger. Cake will look a little bubbly on top when it&#8217;s done. That&#8217;s ok. Avoid over-baking cake because it will crack if over-baked. As the cake bakes, get started on the next step.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buche-de-noel-yule-log/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "As the cake bakes, place a piece of parchment paper (larger than the cake) or a thin kitchen/tea towel flat on the counter. (Note: I find a kitchen towel is better to help prevent cracking.) Using a fine mesh sieve, dust parchment/towel with 3 Tablespoons (15g) of cocoa powder. Once the cake comes out of the oven, quickly run a knife around the edges to loosen it. Immediately invert it onto the parchment/towel. Peel off the parchment paper that was on the bottom of the cake as it baked. Starting with the narrow end, begin tightly rolling the hot cake up with the parchment/towel. Do this slowly and gently. The cake will be warm. Allow the cake to cool completely rolled up in the parchment/towel. Feel free to place it in the refrigerator to speed it up, about 3 hours and up to 1 day.", "name": "Prepare to roll", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buche-de-noel-yule-log/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 200\u00b0F (93\u00b0C). Line a large baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat. In a completely clean residue-free large glass or metal mixing bowl, using a handheld mixer or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the egg white, cream of tartar, and salt together on high speed until foamy, about 2 minutes\u2014this is a small amount and the whisk on a stand mixer might not reach it, so whisk by hand until foamy if needed. With the mixer running on high speed, slowly add the sugar and beat until stiff glossy peaks form, about 2 more minutes. Snip off the end of a plastic bag or fit a round piping tip in a piping bag. I use and recommend Wilton 2A piping tip or any tip with around a 1/2 inch opening. Pipe quarter-sized circles (these will be the round mushroom tops) and 1-inch tall cones (these will be the stems). You will have enough meringue batter for about 16 mushrooms. I usually only make 8-12 and discard leftovers, but feel free to make all 16. Using a moistened finger (just a dab of water is fine), smooth down any peaks. If desired, lightly dust mushroom tops with cocoa powder using a fine mesh sieve. Bake for 2 hours. Do not open the oven as the meringues bake. Turn off the oven after 2 hours and let the meringues sit inside the cooling oven for 20 minutes. Remove meringues from the oven and cool completely. When they&#8217;re just about cool, melt the 1 ounce of chocolate in a double boiler or use the microwave. If using the microwave, melt in 15 second increments, stopping and stirring between each until melted and smooth. Cool for 5-10 minutes. (Easier to adhere mushrooms if the melted chocolate is a bit cool.) Once meringues have cooled, use a flat spatula to remove them from the baking sheets. Dot a bit of chocolate onto the center of the bottom of a mushroom top. Adhere a mushroom stem to it. Place back on the baking sheet to set. If stems or tops still have a little peak, scrape off with a knife or your spatula, as you see me do in the video above. Leaning them against the rim is helpful if they keep toppling over. Repeat with remaining tops and stems to form mushrooms. Let chocolate cool and harden, about 1 hour.", "name": "During this time, make the meringue mushrooms", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buche-de-noel-yule-log/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the cake roll from the refrigerator and allow to sit on the counter for a few minutes to warm up as you prepare the whipped cream.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buche-de-noel-yule-log/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, whip the heavy cream, Frangelico, confectioners\u2019 sugar, and cocoa powder on medium-high speed until medium to stiff peaks form, about 2-3 minutes.", "name": "Make the whipped cream", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buche-de-noel-yule-log/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Gently and very slowly unroll the cake. Spread whipped cream evenly on top, leaving about a 1/2 inch border around the cake. I like using a large or\u00a0small offset spatula to spread. Sprinkle chopped hazelnuts on top. Gently roll the cake back up, without the parchment/towel this time. Roll it slowly. This part is messy. Carefully place on a cutting board. If the exterior of the cake looks moist, dust with a little cocoa powder. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes and up to 2 days before shaping and topping with ganache.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buche-de-noel-yule-log/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place chopped chocolate in a medium bowl. Heat the cream in a small saucepan until it begins to simmer. (Do not let it come to a rapid boil\u2014that\u2019s too hot.) Pour over chocolate, then let it sit for 2-3 minutes to gently soften the chocolate. Slowly stir until completely combined and chocolate has melted. Ganache will be thin, so it has to thicken before using. Refrigerate, uncovered, for at least 30 minutes and up to 1 hour to thicken.", "name": "Make the ganache topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buche-de-noel-yule-log/#instruction-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove rolled cake from the refrigerator. Diagonally slice a 3-4 inch section off one end. At this point, I usually place the cake on a serving platter. Place the angled side against a side of the roll, forming a branch. Slowly pour and spread thickened ganache all over the top and sides of cake. Feel free to leave the cut ends exposed (as you see in these photos) or spread ganache over the ends\u2014there should be plenty of ganache to use. Use a fork to make textured lines resembling tree bark. Feel free to wipe the serving plate if ganache dripped all over.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buche-de-noel-yule-log/#instruction-step-12"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Decorate with meringue mushrooms, sugared cranberries and rosemary, and a dusting of confectioners&#8217; sugar just before serving.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buche-de-noel-yule-log/#instruction-step-13"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover cake and store in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buche-de-noel-yule-log/#instruction-step-11"}], "prepTime": "PT8H", "cookTime": "PT2H20M", "totalTime": "PT10H", "recipeYield": ["10", "10-12 slices"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "French", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "241", "ratingValue": "4.6"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Yule Log Christmas Cake | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "Learn how to make a lovely from-scratch yule log-- a traditional Christmas cake decorated to resemble a log. You can mix up the garlic butter and store it tightly covered in the refrigerator for up to a few weeks, then soften it to a spreadable consistency and spread it on fresh bread when you're ready to bake. (Warning: Your refrigerator will smell garlicky!) You can also freeze it for up to 3 months. Spread the garlic butter on the two halves of the loaf of bread, then place a piece of parchment paper on top of one and lay the other half on top of it, so you have a whole loaf again. The parchment will keep the garlic butter on both sides of the bread when you take the halves apart again. Wrap the loaf in plastic wrap or foil, and then place it in a freezer-safe container or bag. Freeze for up to 3 months. When you're ready to bake, unwrap the loaf and separate the halves. Remove the parchment and place the garlic bread on a baking sheet and bake as directed. You'll need to add a little extra time to the bake time if you bake from frozen.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Homemade Garlic Bread", "description": "Buttery, herby, and loaded with garlic, this homemade garlic bread is perfectly crisp on the outside, soft on the inside, and incredibly simple to whip up. You can use bakery-fresh bread or homemade, such as ciabatta bread or artisan bread.
