Feel free to skip the cookie stamp and bake them as round cookie dough balls.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "stamped cookies, cookie stamp, spice cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/stamped-cookies-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/stamped-cookies-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/stamped-cookies-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/stamped-cookies.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-brown-sugar-stamped-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 cups (250g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled), plus extra as needed for stamping", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "2 and 1/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon", "1/2 teaspoon ground nutmeg", "1/2 teaspoon ground ginger", "1/4 teaspoon ground cardamom", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (150g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1/3 cup (65g) granulated sugar", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) unsulphured or dark molasses (do not use blackstrap; I prefer Grandma&#8217;s brand), maple syrup, or honey", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, nutmeg, ginger, and cardamom together in a medium bowl. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-brown-sugar-stamped-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with paddle attachment, beat the softened butter, brown sugar, and granulated sugar together on medium-high speed until creamy, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. Add the molasses, egg, and vanilla extract and mix on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl again as needed.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-brown-sugar-stamped-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the flour mixture to the wet ingredients, then mix on low speed until combined. Cover and chill the dough in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours (and up to 4 days). If chilling for longer than a few hours, allow to sit at room temperature for at least 15 minutes before rolling because the dough will be quite hard.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-brown-sugar-stamped-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-brown-sugar-stamped-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Measure 1 Tablespoon (20g) of chilled cookie dough per cookie and roll into balls. The dough may seem crumbly, but will come together as you roll. Arrange dough balls 3 inches apart on the baking sheets. Place the cookie stamp directly on top of each cookie dough ball, centering the ball as best as you can, then firmly press down until the dough extends nearly to the edges of the cookie stamp. Lift straight up. If your cookie dough is sticking to the cookie stamp (mine does!), lightly dip the cookie stamp in a bowl of flour before stamping the cookie dough ball. If dipped lightly, the flour bakes right off the cookie.", "name": "Roll and stamp", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-brown-sugar-stamped-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake cookies until the edges are set, about 13 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-brown-sugar-stamped-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove from the oven and allow cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-brown-sugar-stamped-cookies/#instruction-step-13"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover cookies tightly and store at room temperature for up to 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-brown-sugar-stamped-cookies/#instruction-step-8"}], "prepTime": "PT2H30M", "cookTime": "PT13M", "totalTime": "PT3H", "recipeYield": ["32", "32 cookies"], "recipeCategory": "Cookies", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "57", "ratingValue": "4.5"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sami"}, "datePublished": "2025-06-01", "reviewBody": "The crumbly cookie texture came out a bit dry without being crisp. See recipe notes for make ahead and freezing instructions.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "cheese, bread, yeast", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/cheese-loaf-bread-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/cheese-loaf-bread-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/cheese-loaf-bread-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/cheese-loaf-bread.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cheese-bread/", "recipeIngredient": ["1/2 cup (120ml) buttermilk, warmed to about 110\u00b0F", "1/3 cup (80ml) water, warmed to about 110\u00b0F", "2 and 1/4 teaspoons Platinum Yeast from Red Star (1\u00a0standard packet)", "2 Tablespoons (25g) granulated sugar", "5 Tablespoons (71g) unsalted butter, melted + slightly cooled", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon salt", "3/4 teaspoon garlic powder", "3 cups (390g) bread flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed and for hands/work surface*", "2 cups (250g; 8 ounces) shredded cheddar cheese (see note)", "2 Tablespoons (28g) unsalted butter, melted", "2 teaspoons chopped fresh parsley (or your favorite dried or fresh herb)*", "1/4 teaspoon garlic powder"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the warm buttermilk, warm water, yeast, and sugar together in the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a dough hook or paddle attachment. Cover and allow to sit for 5 minutes.", "name": "Prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cheese-bread/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the butter, egg, salt, garlic powder, and 1 cup flour. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, scrape down the sides of the bowl with a silicone spatula, then add the remaining flour. Beat on low speed until the dough comes together and pulls away from the sides of the bowl, about 2 minutes. *If you do not own a mixer, you can mix this dough with a large wooden spoon or silicone spatula. It will take a bit of arm muscle!*", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cheese-bread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cheese-bread/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or nonstick spray. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides in the oil. Cover the bowl with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the dough to rise in a relatively warm environment for 1.5-2 hours or until double in size. (I always let it rise on the counter. Takes about 2 hours. For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to Where Should Dough Rise?\u00a0in my\u00a0Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "1st Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cheese-bread/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease a 9\u00d75-inch loaf pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cheese-bread/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Punch down the dough to release the air. Place dough on a lightly floured work surface and with a floured rolling pin, roll the dough out into a 9\u00d715-inch rectangle (approximately). Sprinkle cheese all over the top, leaving a 1/2 inch border uncovered.", "name": "Shape the bread", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cheese-bread/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Watch the video above to see exactly how I do this step. Tightly roll the dough into a 15-inch log. Place the log on its seam. Using a sharp knife, cut the log in half lengthwise. I find a serrated knife works best. Criss-cross one half, cut side down, on top of the other half\u2014forming an X. Tightly twist the two together. Pinch the outer edges to seal as best you can. If you have any leftover cheese, cut a few small squares and tuck into the dough as shown in the video above. This is optional and simply for extra cheesy pockets! Place in prepared loaf pan and cover with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. (This step can get a little messy.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-cheese-bread/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Allow the covered loaf to rest for 30 minutes. Grease three 9-inch round cake pans, line with parchment paper rounds, then grease the parchment paper. Parchment paper helps the cakes seamlessly release from the pans. (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes video &amp; post.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-naked-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together in a large bowl. Set aside. Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on high speed until smooth and creamy, about 3 minutes. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed. On medium-high speed, add 1 egg at a time, beating well after each addition. Beat in the vanilla extract. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed.", "name": "Make the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-naked-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With the mixer on low speed, add the dry ingredients in three additions alternating with the buttermilk, beginning and ending with the dry ingredients, and mixing each addition just until incorporated. Do not overmix this batter. The batter will be smooth, velvety, and slightly thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-naked-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "There is about 8 cups of batter total, so each layer will be 2 and 2/3 cups. Pour/spread batter evenly into prepared cake pans. If you&#8217;re worried about uneven cake layers, you can use a kitchen scale and weigh the cake pans for accuracy. (The weight of just the batter in my cake pans was about 1 lb 6 ounces.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-naked-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for around 25-26 minutes or until the cakes are baked through.\u00a0To test for doneness, insert a toothpick into the center of the cake. If it comes out clean, it is done. Allow cakes to cool completely in the pans set on a wire rack. The cakes must be completely cool before frosting and assembling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-naked-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld mixer or stand mixer fitted with a whisk or paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until creamy\u2014about 2 minutes. Add 5 and 1/2 cups confectioners&#8217; sugar, 5 Tablespoons heavy cream, the vanilla extract, and salt with the mixer running on low. Increase to high speed and beat for 3 full minutes. Add 1/2 cup more confectioners&#8217; sugar if frosting is too thin, 1 more Tablespoon cream if frosting is too thick, or a pinch more of salt if frosting is way too sweet. Yields about 4.5 cups of frosting.", "name": "Make the frosting", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-naked-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Watch the video above for a tutorial on assembling and decorating this naked cake.\u00a0First, using a large serrated knife,\u00a0slice\u00a0a thin layer off the tops of the cakes\u00a0to create a flat surface. Discard (or crumble over ice cream!).\u00a0Place 1 cake layer on your cake stand, cake turntable, or serving plate. Spread 1 and 1/2 cups of frosting evenly on top. If using, dot half of the raspberries around the rim. Flatten them down into the frosting as best you can so the cake layer on top is sturdy.\u00a0Top with 2nd cake layer and\u00a0evenly cover the top with another 1 and 1/2 cups of frosting and more (flattened!) raspberries around the rim. You can sprinkle a few leftover raspberries in the center, too. (Like I did in the video.) Top with the third cake layer. Spread the remaining frosting on top and all around the sides using an icing spatula. Use a bench scraper to smooth out the frosting on the sides of the cake. If you&#8217;re making a full naked cake, just spread the remaining frosting on top of the cake. If you have leftover frosting, you\u00a0can\u00a0freeze it for up to 3 months and thaw in the refrigerator for next time.", "name": "Assemble and decorate the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-naked-cake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Decorate the cake with garnishes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-naked-cake/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Refrigerate the cake for 2-3 hours or up to 1 day before slicing and serving. If chilling for more than a few hours, loosely cover with plastic wrap after 1 hour of refrigeration. (The frosting will &#8220;set&#8221; after about 1 hour and the plastic wrap won&#8217;t really ruin your frosting at that point.) And if you&#8217;re chilling for more than a few hours, I suggest decorating with garnishes right before serving (so as not to wilt the flowers, etc).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-naked-cake/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store leftover cake at room temperature for 1-2 days or in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/vanilla-naked-cake/#instruction-step-10"}], "prepTime": "PT45M", "cookTime": "PT25M", "totalTime": "PT6H", "recipeYield": ["12", "12 servings"], "recipeCategory": "Cake", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "51", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Vanilla Naked Cake | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "Learn how to make a beautiful naked cake with fresh berries and vanilla buttercream. Spread the bread chunks on a lined baking sheet and toast in a 300\u00b0F (149\u00b0C) oven for 10 minutes. Your bread is now slightly dried out and ready to soak up all that egg custard. P.S. This trick works for my <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sausage-herb-thanksgiving-stuffing/\">sausage &amp; herb stuffing</a>, too.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/unbelievable-blueberry-french-toast-casserole/#faq-question-1681579767480", "position": 2, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/unbelievable-blueberry-french-toast-casserole/#faq-question-1681579767480", "name": "Can I Use Other Berries?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes. You really want it packed in tight\u2014as tight as possible. Bake for 25-28 minutes or until top appears set and it&#8217;s golden brown around the edges. Remove from the oven and allow to cool completely in the pan set on a wire rack for 1 hour, then transfer to the refrigerator to chill for 1 more hour. This firms up the bars which helps them stay compact. Also 1/4 cup maple syrup instead of honey (1/4 c maple syrup = 79g, not the same as honey). My 1 cup of oats = 110g, not 85g as per the recipe. I also added 1/4 cup hemp seeds instead of nuts. They turned out great. \r\n\r\nOther experiements: The first time they weren't as good. That time I used a GF flour mix and I weighed all the ingredients per the recipe, instead of volume measures. They were too liquidy. The second time I used volume measures and weights to see if there was a discrepancy. The only big difference was in the oats. My 1 cup of oats weighed 110g instead of 85g, but I think that and the different flour was enough to make them really different."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Megan"}, "datePublished": "2025-06-06", "reviewBody": "These are so good! Add beaten egg, vanilla extract, and peanut butter then beat on medium-high speed until combined. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. Beat in the flour, oats, baking soda, and salt on low speed, then beat in the M&amp;Ms and chocolate chips until combined. The dough will be sticky. If it&#8217;s too sticky to handle, chill in the refrigerator for 5-10 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/one-giant-monster-mm-cookie/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Shape into a mound in the center of the lined baking sheet. Though if eating on a particularly humid day, keep your frosted confections in the refrigerator as close to serving as you can. You can use SMBC under fondant-topped cakes and confections, too.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/swiss-meringue-buttercream/#faq-question-1708030032275", "position": 4, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/swiss-meringue-buttercream/#faq-question-1708030032275", "name": "Can I add food coloring?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes and it's best to tint SMBC with <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2tkNsfs\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener sponsored nofollow\">gel food coloring</a> so you aren't adding a lot of extra liquid. Beat food coloring into the frosting on low speed after you add the vanilla extract and salt.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/swiss-meringue-buttercream/#faq-question-1708030053608", "position": 5, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/swiss-meringue-buttercream/#faq-question-1708030053608", "name": "Can you freeze Swiss meringue buttercream or make it ahead?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes. Swiss meringue buttercream is great left covered at room temperature for 1-2 days, but after that, refrigerate it for up to 5 days or freeze up to 3 months. If freezing, store in an airtight container, then thaw it at room temperature on the counter. Once completely at room temperature, about 72\u00b0F (22\u00b0C), place into the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment and beat for 2-3 minutes until creamy again. If it separates or curdles, see troubleshooting tips below.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/swiss-meringue-buttercream/#faq-question-1708030020725", "position": 6, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/swiss-meringue-buttercream/#faq-question-1708030020725", "name": "Can I add flavors?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Replace some (about 1 teaspoon) of vanilla extract with 1 teaspoon of another flavor extract such as lemon, coconut, orange, maple, or even 1 teaspoon of espresso powder. Taste, then add a touch more if desired. For potent extracts, like peppermint or almond, replace 1 teaspoon of the vanilla with just 1/2 teaspoon. For <strong>chocolate Swiss meringue buttercream</strong>, beat 8 ounces of pure melted and slightly cooled chocolate into the buttercream when you add the vanilla and salt. Make sure you're using pure baking chocolate (the 4 ounce bars) like Baker's or Ghirardelli brands found in the baking aisle.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/swiss-meringue-buttercream/#faq-question-1749983237114", "position": 7, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/swiss-meringue-buttercream/#faq-question-1749983237114", "name": "Can I make strawberry Swiss meringue buttercream?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes! Using a <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3xPO7my\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\">food processor</a> or blender, process 1 cup (about 25g) freeze-dried strawberries into a powdery crumb. You should have around 1/2 cup. If it's not grinding down fine enough, you can sift it with a <a href=\"https://amzn.to/3F1eHMf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\">fine mesh sieve</a> to rid larger seeds/pieces. Add the strawberry crumb powder when you add the vanilla.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Swiss Meringue Buttercream", "description": "This is vanilla Swiss Meringue Buttercream perfection. It's the ideal balance of sweet and creamy, without being as cloyingly sugary as American buttercream. (This is a far cry from how sweet that is!) Thick, sturdy, and perfectly pipe-able. This in-depth recipe sets you up for success on your 1st try.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "Swiss meringue buttercream, meringue, frosting", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/swiss-meringue-buttercream-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/swiss-meringue-buttercream-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/swiss-meringue-buttercream-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/swiss-meringue-buttercream-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/swiss-meringue-buttercream/", "recipeIngredient": ["6 large egg whites (approximately 180g)", "2 cups (400g) granulated sugar", "1 and 1/2 cups (340g) unsalted butter, softened but still cool and cut into Tbsp size pieces (*see note*)", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1/8 teaspoon salt"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Watch the video tutorial above, review the troubleshooting tips, and read the recipe in full before beginning. Make sure all the tools you are using are completely cleaned, dried, and grease-free. A quick wipe with a little lemon juice or white vinegar is very helpful.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/swiss-meringue-buttercream/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If you haven&#8217;t done so yet, separate the eggs first. Separate 1 egg white in a small bowl, then place the egg white in your heatproof mixing bowl. Repeat with the remaining egg whites. This way, if a yolk breaks in one of them, you don\u2019t waste the whole batch.", "name": "Separate the eggs", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/swiss-meringue-buttercream/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk sugar into the egg whites, then set the bowl over a saucepan filled with just two inches of simmering water over medium heat. Do not let the bottom of the egg whites bowl touch the water. Whisk the whites and sugar constantly until sugar is dissolved and mixture has thinned out, about 4 minutes. The mixture will be thick and tacky at first, then thin out and be frothy white on top. To test that it&#8217;s ready, you can use your finger or an instant read thermometer. Lightly and quickly dip your finger (it&#8217;s very hot, be careful) and rub the mixture between your thumb and finger. You shouldn&#8217;t feel any sugar granules. If using a thermometer, the temperature should read 160\u00b0F (71\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/swiss-meringue-buttercream/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "No need to let it cool down to start this next step\u2014it&#8217;s important to begin mixing while it is still warm. Transfer mixture to the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment (if you aren&#8217;t already using the metal bowl that comes with it). You can use a hand mixer instead, but this step takes awhile and your arm tires quickly. On medium-high speed, beat the mixture until stiff glossy peaks form and the meringue is no longer warm to the touch, at least 10-15 minutes. On particularly humid days, this has taken me up to 17-18 minutes. If it&#8217;s still not reaching stiff peaks, stop the mixer, place the bowl\u2014uncovered\u2014in the refrigerator for 10 minutes, then return to the mixer and continue beating until stiff peaks form. (This has always worked for me when it&#8217;s taking forever to reach stiff peaks.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/swiss-meringue-buttercream/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If the bowl and meringue still feel warm, wait until both cool to room temperature (around 70\u00b0F (21\u00b0C)) before adding the butter in the next step. Feel free to place it in the refrigerator. A warm bowl and meringue will melt the butter.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/swiss-meringue-buttercream/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Switch the stand mixer to the paddle attachment. On medium-high speed, add the butter 1 Tablespoon at a time. Wait for the butter to fully mix in before adding the next Tablespoon. After all the butter has been added, turn the mixer down to medium speed and fully beat in the vanilla and salt, about 30 seconds.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/swiss-meringue-buttercream/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Your Swiss meringue buttercream should be thick, creamy, and silky smooth and is ready to use on any cake, cupcake, or other confection.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/swiss-meringue-buttercream/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If your meringue has separated, curdled, or is too thick at any point after you mix in all of the butter, place the mixture in your heat-proof bowl back over a pot of 2 inches of simmering water. Without stirring, let the edges of the meringue warm up and become liquid (the center of the meringue will still be solid), about 1-2 minutes. Remove from heat and return to the mixer. Beat meringue on low speed for 30 seconds, then switch to medium-high speed and beat until smooth, about 2 minutes. Works every time. If your mixture has become too thin and soupy after you add the butter, place the entire bowl in the refrigerator (covered or uncovered, doesn&#8217;t matter) for 20 minutes to cool down, then return it to the mixer and beat on medium-high speed until thickened. Any longer than this will solidify the butter, so only refrigerate in 20 minute spurts. If it&#8217;s still soupy, place back in the refrigerator for longer before re-whipping again. More troubleshooting tips in the post above.", "name": "Too Thick or Too Thin", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/swiss-meringue-buttercream/#instruction-step-8"}], "prepTime": "PT25M", "cookTime": "PT5M", "totalTime": "PT30M", "recipeYield": ["5", "5 cups"], "recipeCategory": "Frosting", "cookingMethod": "Whipping", "recipeCuisine": "European", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "483", "ratingValue": "4.7"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Swiss Meringue Buttercream | Sally's Baking Recipes", "description": "Made from 5 ingredients, this is perfect Swiss meringue buttercream. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pistachio-cupcakes-with-creamy-strawberry-frosting/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the cake flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and 3/4 cup of pistachio crumbs together. Reserve the rest of the pistachio crumbs for garnish.", "name": "Make\u00a0the cupcakes", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pistachio-cupcakes-with-creamy-strawberry-frosting/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on high speed until smooth and creamy, about 3 minutes. Stop and scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg whites, vanilla extract, and almond extract. Beat on medium-high speed until combined, then beat in the sour cream. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. Add the dry ingredients and then, with the mixer running on low speed, slowly pour in the milk (and the food coloring, if using). Beat until just combined\u2014do not over-mix. You may need to whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no lumps at the bottom of the bowl. The batter will be slightly thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pistachio-cupcakes-with-creamy-strawberry-frosting/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour/spoon the batter into the liners, filling only 2/3 full to avoid spilling over the sides.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pistachio-cupcakes-with-creamy-strawberry-frosting/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 19\u201322 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. For about 36 mini cupcakes, bake for about 11\u201313\u00a0minutes, same oven temperature.\u00a0Allow the cupcakes to cool completely before frosting.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pistachio-cupcakes-with-creamy-strawberry-frosting/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a blender or food processor, process the freeze-dried strawberries into a powdery crumb. You should have about 1/2 cup. In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter on medium-high speed until creamy, about 2 minutes. Add confectioners&#8217; sugar, strawberry powder, cream, and vanilla. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to high speed and beat for 2 minutes. Taste. leveled), plus more for work surface + hands", "1 cup (200g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1 teaspoon baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "zest from 1 orange (about 2 scant Tbsp)", "1/4 cup (4 Tbsp; 56g) unsalted butter, cold and cubed", "3/4 cup (95g) chopped walnuts*", "3 large eggs", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) fresh orange juice", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) canola or vegetable oil\u00a0(or melted coconut oil)", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "egg wash:\u00a01 large egg beaten\u00a0with 1 Tablespoon (15ml) milk or water", "two 4 ounce (226g) semi-sweet or bittersweet chocolate bars, coarsely chopped*"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).\u00a0Line two\u00a0large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats.\u00a0(Always recommended\u00a0for cookies.)\u00a0Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/dark-chocolate-orange-biscotti/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, brown sugar, baking powder, cinnamon, salt, and orange zest together in a large bowl until combined. Using a pastry cutter or 2 forks, cut in the butter until the mixture is crumbly. Stir in the walnuts. Set aside. In a medium bowl, whisk the eggs, orange juice, oil, and vanilla extract together. Pour into the flour/butter mixture and gently mix together until everything is\u00a0just barely moistened.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/dark-chocolate-orange-biscotti/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Turn dough out onto a lightly floured surface and with floured hands, knead lightly until the dough is soft and slightly sticky, about 8-10 times. If it&#8217;s uncontrollably sticky, knead\u00a01-2 more Tablespoon(s) of flour into the dough. Divide the dough in two and place each half onto a baking sheet. Shape each half\u00a0into an 8&#215;4-inch long rectangle, patting down until each is about 1/2 inch thick. Using a pastry brush, lightly brush the top and sides of each biscotti slab with egg wash.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/dark-chocolate-orange-biscotti/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 25-26 minutes, or until the top and sides of the biscotti slabs are lightly browned.\u00a0Remove from the oven, but do not turn off the heat. Allow\u00a0to cool for 10 minutes. Once the slabs are cool enough to handle, cut each\u00a0into\u00a01 inch\u00a0thick slices. Set\u00a0slices cut sides upright, \u00bc inch apart, on the\u00a0baking\u00a0sheets.\u00a0Return to the oven to continue baking for 8 minutes.\u00a0Turn biscotti\u00a0over and bake other side for 8 minutes. The cookies will be slightly soft in the centers with harder edges. Remove from the oven and allow to cool for 5 minutes on the baking sheet. Transfer to a wire rack to cool completely before dipping in chocolate. The biscotti becomes crunchy as it cools.\u00a0Save the baking sheets for the next step.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/dark-chocolate-orange-biscotti/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt the chopped chocolate in a double boiler or (carefully!) use the microwave. For the microwave, place the chocolate in a medium heat-proof bowl.\u00a0Melt in 15 second increments, stirring after each increment until completely melted and smooth. Dip each biscotti cookie in the melted chocolate and place back onto the baking sheets. Sprinkle with any additional orange zest if desired. Made with blueberries, oats, and zero refined sugar, you can feel good eating one or two, or three!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "blueberry oatmeal muffins", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/blueberry-oatmeal-muffins-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/blueberry-oatmeal-muffins-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/blueberry-oatmeal-muffins-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/blueberry-oatmeal-muffins.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-oatmeal-muffins/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (240ml) milk", "1 cup (85g) old-fashioned whole rolled oats", "1 and 1/4 cups (156g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, melted and slightly cooled", "1/2 cup (170g) honey", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1 cup (140g) fresh or frozen blueberries (see note if using frozen)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Combine milk and oats. Set aside for 20 minutes so the oats puff up and soak up some moisture. This is crucial to the recipe! (I usually melt the butter now so it has a few minutes to cool.) Don&#8217;t do this the night before as that&#8217;s too long for soaking. If you find the oats haven&#8217;t soaked up any moisture after 20 minutes, give it a stir and wait 10 more minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-oatmeal-muffins/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 425\u00b0F (218\u00b0C). Spray a 12-count muffin pan with nonstick spray or use cupcake liners.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-oatmeal-muffins/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking powder, baking soda, cinnamon, and salt together in a large bowl until combined. Set aside. Whisk the melted butter, honey, egg, and vanilla extract together in a medium bowl until combined. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients, stir a few times, then add the soaked oats (milk included, do not drain) and blueberries. Fold everything together gently just until combined.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/blueberry-oatmeal-muffins/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon the batter into liners, filling them all the way to the top. Top with oats and a light sprinkle of coconut sugar, if desired. Bake for 5 minutes at 425 then, keeping the muffins in the oven, reduce the oven temperature to\u00a0350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Bake for an additional\u00a016-17 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. The total time these muffins take in the oven is about 22-23 minutes, give or take. (For mini muffins, bake 11-13 minutes at 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).) Make pie dough the night before because it needs to chill in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours before rolling out and par-baking.", "name": "Prepare pie crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cheesy-spinach-quiche/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "On a floured work surface, roll out one of the discs of chilled dough (save the second pie crust for another recipe). Turn the dough about a quarter turn after every few rolls until you have a circle 12 inches (30cm) in diameter. Carefully place the dough into a 9-inch (23cm) pie dish. Tuck it in with your fingers, making sure it is completely smooth. To make a lovely edge, I do not trim excess dough around the edges. Instead, fold the excess dough back over the edge and use your hands to mold the edge into a rim around the pie. Crimp the pie crust edges with a fork or use your fingers to flute the edges. Chill the pie crust in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes and up to 5 days. Cover the pie crust with plastic wrap if chilling for longer than 30 minutes.", "name": "Roll out the chilled pie dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cheesy-spinach-quiche/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 375\u00b0F (190\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cheesy-spinach-quiche/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line the chilled pie crust with parchment paper. Fill with 2 packs of pie weights, or use dried beans. Make sure the weights are evenly distributed around the pie dish. Bake until the edges of the crust are starting to brown, about 15\u201316 minutes. Remove from the oven and carefully lift the parchment paper (with the weights) out of the pie. Prick holes all over the bottom crust with a fork. Return the pie crust to the oven. Bake until the bottom crust is just beginning to brown, about 7\u20138 minutes. Remove from the oven and set aside. (Crust can still be warm when you pour in the filling, or you can par-bake the crust up to 3 days ahead of time. Cover cooled par-baked crust tightly and refrigerate until ready to fill.)", "name": "Par-bake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cheesy-spinach-quiche/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Reduce oven temperature to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cheesy-spinach-quiche/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If your frozen spinach is not already thawed, thaw it in the microwave per package directions. leveled)*", "2 and 1/2 teaspoons baking powder", "1/4 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature*", "1 and 3/4 cups (350g) granulated sugar", "4 large egg yolks, room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1 cup (240ml) buttermilk, at room temperature*", "2 large egg whites, room temperature", "1/8 teaspoon cream of tartar*", "1 and 1/4 cups (282g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3 and 1/2 cups (420g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "3/4 cup (65g) unsweetened cocoa powder (natural or dutch process)", "3-5 Tablespoons (45-75ml) heavy cream (or half-and-half or milk), at room temperature", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "optional for decoration: sprinkles"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Grease two 9-inch round cake pans, line with parchment paper rounds, then grease the parchment paper. Parchment paper helps the cakes seamlessly release from the pans. (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes video &amp; post.) I recommend using nonstick spray for greasing.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/yellow-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the cake flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together in a large bowl. Set aside.", "name": "Start the cake batter with the dry ingredients", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/yellow-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on high speed for 3 full minutes. The creamed butter and sugar will be extra creamy. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed. Turn the mixer down to medium-high speed and beat in the 4 egg yolks one at a time, letting each egg yolk fully mix into the batter before adding the next. Beat in the vanilla extract until combined.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/yellow-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add about 1/3 of the dry ingredients and 1/2 of the buttermilk and beat on low speed until combined. Add 1/3 more of the dry ingredients and the rest of the buttermilk and beat on low speed until combined. Add the rest of the dry ingredients and beat on low speed until combined. The batter is very thick. You may need to whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no lumps at the bottom of the bowl.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/yellow-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the egg whites and cream of tartar together on high speed until fluffy peaks form, about 3 minutes. See photo and video above for a visual. Slowly and gently fold the egg whites into the thick cake batter. Avoid over-mixing as you don&#8217;t want to deflate the egg whites.", "name": "Whip the egg whites", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/yellow-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour/spoon batter evenly into cake pans.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/yellow-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for around 27-31 minutes or until the cakes are baked through. After about 18 minutes, tent the cakes with aluminum foil to prevent the tops and sides from over-browning. To test the cakes for doneness, insert a toothpick into the center of the cake. If it comes out clean, it\u2019s done. The cakes may look a little spongey on top as a result of the whipped egg whites. (That&#8217;s normal!)", "name": "Bake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/yellow-cake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Allow cakes to cool completely in the pans set on a wire rack. The cakes must be completely cool before frosting and assembling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/yellow-cake/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until creamy, about 2 minutes. Add confectioners\u2019 sugar, cocoa powder, 3 Tablespoons heavy cream, salt, and vanilla extract. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to high speed and beat for 1 full minute. Do not over-whip. Add 1/4 cup more confectioners\u2019 sugar or cocoa powder if frosting is too thin or 1-2 more Tablespoons of cream if frosting is too thick. (I usually add 1 more.) Taste. Add another pinch of salt if desired.", "name": "Make the buttercream", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/yellow-cake/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If cooled cakes are domed on top, use a large serrated knife to slice a thin layer off the tops to create a flat surface. This is called &#8220;leveling&#8221; the cakes. Discard or crumble over finished cake (or on ice cream!). Place 1 cake layer on your cake turntable, cake stand, or serving plate. Evenly cover the top with frosting. Top with 2nd layer. (If desired, if the edges seem extra crumbly, apply a crumb coat which is a thin layer of frosting all over the cake. You can see I did this in the video tutorial above. Refrigerate the crumb coated cake for 15 minutes before adding the rest of the frosting.) Spread remaining frosting all over the top and sides. I always use an icing spatula and/or a bench scraper for the frosting. Garnish with sprinkles, if desired.", "name": "Assemble and frost", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/yellow-cake/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "For extra neat slices, refrigerate cake for 30-60 minutes before slicing. Feel free to use the homemade brownie batter below or prepare your favorite boxed brownie batter.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "brookie bars, chocolate chip cookie brownie bars", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/brownie-cookie-bars-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/brownie-cookie-bars-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/brownie-cookie-bars-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/brownie-cookie-bars-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-cookie-brownie-bars/", "recipeIngredient": ["3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (150g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1/4 cup (50g) granulated sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "2 cups (250g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 teaspoons cornstarch", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1 and 1/2 cups (270g) semi-sweet chocolate chips", "48 unwrapped miniature peanut butter cups (or 2 cups chopped peanut butter cups)", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter", "two 4 ounce (226g) semi-sweet chocolate bars, coarsely chopped*", "1 cup (200g) granulated sugar", "3 large eggs, at room temperature", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1/2 cup (63g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/4 teaspoon salt"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line the bottom and sides of a 9\u00d713-inch baking pan with parchment paper, leaving an overhang on the sides to lift the finished brownies out (makes cutting easier!). Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-cookie-brownie-bars/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt the butter and semi-sweet chocolate together in a medium saucepan on medium heat, stirring constantly (about 5 minutes). Remove from heat and let cool to room temperature. This takes about 15 minutes. Use this 15 minutes to make the chocolate chip cookie layer! Whisk sugar into cooled chocolate/butter mixture until combined. Add in the eggs one at a time, whisking until smooth after each addition. Whisk in the vanilla extract, then use a silicone spatula or wooden spoon to fold in the flour and salt until combined.", "name": "Make the brownie layer first, even though it will go on top", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-cookie-brownie-bars/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld mixer or stand mixer fitted with paddle attachment, cream the butter and sugars together on medium speed until combined and creamy. Beat in the egg and vanilla extract until combined. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. Add the flour, cornstarch, baking soda, and salt. Beat on low speed until combined, then beat in the chocolate chips. Dough will be thick and sticky. Using a silicone spatula sprayed with cooking spray (to reduce sticking), spread the cookie dough all over the prepared baking pan. The layer will be thin, but will puff up as it bakes. Top with peanut butter cups, then pour the brownie batter on top and smooth with a knife or rubber spatula.", "name": "Make the cookie layer", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-cookie-brownie-bars/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the bars for 40-45 minutes, or until the center no longer jiggles and a toothpick inserted in the middle comes out relatively clean (a few brownie crumbs are OK). I usually just use my mixer for this! Set mashed bananas aside.", "name": "Make\u00a0the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/best-banana-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking powder, baking soda, cinnamon, and salt together. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/best-banana-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on high speed until smooth and creamy\u2014about 1 minute. Add both sugars and beat on high speed for 2 minutes until creamed together. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed. Add the eggs and the vanilla. Beat on medium-high speed until combined, then beat in the mashed bananas. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. With the mixer on low speed, add the dry ingredients in three additions alternating with the buttermilk and mixing each addition just until incorporated. Do not overmix. The batter will be slightly thick and a few lumps is OK.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/best-banana-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread batter into the prepared pan. Bake for 45\u201350 minutes. Baking times vary, so keep an eye on yours. The cake is done when a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. If you find the top of the cake is browning too quickly in the oven, loosely cover it with aluminum foil.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/best-banana-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the cake from the oven and set on a wire rack.\u00a0Allow to cool completely. After about 45 minutes, I usually place it in the refrigerator to speed things up.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/best-banana-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0In a large\u00a0bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the cream cheese and butter together on high\u00a0speed until smooth and creamy. Add 3 cups confectioners&#8217; sugar, vanilla, and salt. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then switch to high speed and beat for 2 minutes. If you want the frosting a little thicker, add the extra 1/4 cup of confectioners sugar (I add it). Spread the frosting on the cooled cake. Refrigerate for 30 minutes before serving. Microwave in 20 second increments, stirring after each until completely melted and combined. Slightly cool for 3-5 minutes.", "name": "For the batter", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-souffle/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk egg yolks, vanilla extract, and salt into chocolate mixture. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-souffle/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a completely clean residue-free medium glass or metal mixing bowl, using a handheld mixer or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the egg whites and cream of tartar together on high speed until soft peaks form, about 2 minutes. With the mixer running on high speed, slowly add the sugar in 3 additions about 1 Tablespoon at a time, beating for 5 seconds before adding the next Tablespoon. After all 3 Tablespoons of sugar have been added, beat until stiff glossy peaks form, about 2 more minutes. Do not over-beat.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-souffle/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Slowly and gently fold the egg whites into the chocolate mixture. It&#8217;s best to do this in 3 separate additions, combining each addition completely before folding in more.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-souffle/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Refrigerate the batter for 5-10 minutes as you preheat the oven and prepare the ramekins. (No need to cover the batter unless you are refrigerating it for longer than 1 hour. Can be made up to 2 days in advance, see make ahead instructions below.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-souffle/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Adjust the oven rack to the lower third position and preheat to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-souffle/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Brush four 6-ounce oven-safe straight sided ramekins with a generous coating of the softened butter. Sprinkle in the granulated sugar, then shake/rotate each to ensure every spot of the ramekin has a sugar coating. Place ramekins on a baking sheet. Discard excess sugar.", "name": "Prepare the ramekins", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-souffle/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon batter evenly into ramekins. Using a knife or icing spatula, smooth down the surface. Run a knife, icing spatula, or your thumb around the rim at the top, creating a &#8220;channel&#8221; between the batter and the rim of your pan. Feel free to wipe the edges clean with a towel, though I don&#8217;t always do that and don&#8217;t notice a difference in appearance or rise.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-souffle/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place baking sheet with ramekins on top in the oven. Immediately reduce oven temperature to 375\u00b0F (191\u00b0C). Bake for 13-14 minutes or until the edges are set and the center just barely jiggles when you give the pan a light tap. Avoid opening/closing the oven too much.", "name": "Bake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-souffle/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove from the oven and serve immediately plain or with optional toppings. Souffl\u00e9s begin to fall within minutes. You&#8217;ll still have that sponge-like texture underneath a crackly top, though it settles into a denser texture as time passes. I used plain unsweetened fat free Greek yogurt, and sweetened Mott's applesauce (all I had on hand). I think the sweetened applesauce balanced out the unsweetened yogurt.  I added extra vanilla as well. \r\nTo avoid the egginess I used 1 large egg instead of two egg whites but with fat free yogurt I thought it was a nice trade.  \r\nI made mini muffins also (don't have a regular size muffin pan). In a silicone mini muffin pan I sprayed lightly with non stick spray, baked at 425 for 4 minutes to rise, then dropped the temp to 325 for 8 minutes more.  \r\nThey are fantastic!  Very soft, satisfy the chocolate craving, and low calorie.  They are a *tad* spongey but I actually like that.  \r\n\r\nTips: be sure to sift or at least whisk the dry ingredients together before combining with the wet, don't scoop your flour with the measuring cup, and don't overmix the batter.  Just fold gently until there aren't anymore dry spots. Built on an Oreo cookie crust, it's layered with a rich peanut butter filling, a smooth 2-ingredient chocolate ganache, and fresh whipped cream. Finish it off with chopped peanuts and Reese's Pieces for an unbelievable dessert no one will forget.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "peanut butter pie", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/peanut-butter-pie-picture-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/peanut-butter-pie-picture-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/peanut-butter-pie-picture-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/peanut-butter-pie-picture.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/unbelievable-peanut-butter-pie/", "recipeIngredient": ["22 whole Oreo cookies (250g; regular, not Double Stuf)", "5 Tablespoons (71g)\u00a0unsalted butter, melted", "3/4 cup (180ml) heavy cream", "6 ounces (170g) semi-sweet chocolate, finely chopped", "1 cup (240ml) heavy cream, cold", "8 ounces (226g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "1 and 1/2 cups (375g) creamy peanut butter", "3/4 cup (90g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "Whipped Cream", "1/4 cup (50g) Reese&#8217;s Pieces, crushed", "1/4 cup (30g) chopped peanuts"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/unbelievable-peanut-butter-pie/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a food processor or blender, pulse 22 Oreos (including the cream filling) into a fine crumb. You should have about 2 cups (packed) crumbs, or 250g. Pour crumbs into a large bowl. Add the melted butter and stir to combine. The mixture will be thick and quite wet. Try to smash/break up any large chunks. Pour the mixture into an ungreased 9-inch pie dish. With medium pressure using your hand, pat the crumbs down into the bottom and up the sides to make a compact, thick crust. See this Oreo crust\u00a0page for more success tips if needed. Bake for 10 minutes. Allow to cool as you prepare the filling.", "name": "Bake the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/unbelievable-peanut-butter-pie/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place chopped chocolate in a medium heat-proof bowl. Heat the cream in a small saucepan over medium heat, stirring occasionally. Once it comes to a simmer, immediately remove from heat and pour over the chocolate. Let sit for 2\u20133 minutes to soften the chocolate, then stir gently until the ganache is smooth. Set aside at room temperature and allow to slightly cool. During this time, it will gradually thicken as well.", "name": "Make the ganache", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/unbelievable-peanut-butter-pie/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the heavy cream on medium-high speed until stiff peaks form, about 3 minutes. Spoon the whipped cream into a bowl and set aside. Using the same mixing bowl (no need to rinse it out), beat the cream cheese on medium-high speed until smooth. Then add the peanut butter, confectioners&#8217; sugar, and vanilla extract, and beat until combined. Mixture will be thick. Fold in the whipped cream until smooth. Be gentle, you don&#8217;t want to deflate that cream.", "name": "Make the filling:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/unbelievable-peanut-butter-pie/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread peanut butter filling into the cooled crust; I use a small offset spatula for this.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/unbelievable-peanut-butter-pie/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread the chocolate ganache on top of the filling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/unbelievable-peanut-butter-pie/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Note: If you don&#8217;t plan to serve the pie with whipped cream, you can add chopped peanuts and/or Reese&#8217;s Pieces on top of the wet ganache before chilling the pie (so they stick). Otherwise, wait until you garnish with whipped cream (step 9).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/unbelievable-peanut-butter-pie/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Chill the pie in the refrigerator for at least 6 hours and up to 48 hours. Cover leftover pie and store in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/unbelievable-peanut-butter-pie/#instruction-step-10"}], "prepTime": "PT1H", "cookTime": "PT10M", "totalTime": "PT7H", "recipeYield": ["1", "1 9-inch pie"], "recipeCategory": "Pie", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "57", "ratingValue": "4.6"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Peanut Butter Pie.mov", "description": "In this mega rich and indulgent peanut butter pie, every bite bursts with creamy peanut butter and sweet chocolate\u2014the ultimate flavor combo.", "contentUrl": "https://content.jwplatform.com/videos/33y1FsGf.mp4", "thumbnailUrl": ["https://content.jwplatform.com/thumbs/33y1FsGf-720.jpg"], "uploadDate": "2025-09-17T13:00:28+00:00"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Pam"}, "datePublished": "2025-07-13", "reviewBody": "Oreo cookies . Used regular 9 inch pie plate.  I did have leftover ganache, so would make less next time.  \r\nDid make a few changes:  I don't like Oreos so I substituted chocolate graham crackers for crust.  (measured about 2 1/4 cups crushed crackers and added extra melted butter (about 3 tablespoons) to compensate for lack of oreo filling.)  Also did not add any Reese's pieces or other candy, pie didn't need them, just put whipped cream on top for serving.   Pie was a hit, and will make again."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "3"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Tif"}, "datePublished": "2025-08-21", "reviewBody": "I made this for a friend\u2019s bday and had high hopes. \r\n\r\nFollowing others, I used a springform pan, which does make for a really nice presentation. I added some chopped Reeces cups on top of the crust and added some more on top\r\nof the ganache. Other than that, I followed the recipe absolutely to a T. \r\n\r\nFor me, the peanut butter filling was disappointing. As soon as I whipped up the cream cheese, peanut butter portion I know there was no way I could get a silky mousse without adding the whipped cream back into my mixer. Even with the mixer, I had to beat on high to get the mixture light enough. Beyond that however, the taste was just too peanut butter heavy for me. I know, I know, it\u2019s a peanut butter pie - but the peanut flavor is just off. It\u2019s overwhelming in a way we didn\u2019t enjoy. I was really hoping that combined with the crust, ganache, etc in final form it would improve, but sadly it did not. \r\n\r\nThis one wasn\u2019t for us."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "3"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "kavita"}, "datePublished": "2025-08-29", "reviewBody": "My mother used to make a similar peanut butter pie but I lost the hand written recipe when we last moved. It wasn't as creamy as other peanut butter pies I've had in the past. I agree with Carie McCowen that there is way too much filling and ganache for a normal sized pie. I made the mistake of not reading the comments before I made this pie. From now on I will always read the comments before trying a new recipe. The chocolate batter is made from the vanilla, so you don\u2019t have to prepare 2 separate cake batters from scratch.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "marble loaf cake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/chocolate-vanilla-marble-loaf-cake-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/chocolate-vanilla-marble-loaf-cake-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/chocolate-vanilla-marble-loaf-cake-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/chocolate-vanilla-marble-loaf-cake.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/marble-loaf-cake/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 cups (250g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 and 1/4 cups (250g) granulated sugar", "3 large eggs, at room temperature", "1 Tablespoon pure vanilla extract (yes, 1 Tbsp!)", "1 cup (240g/ml) buttermilk, at room temperature and divided", "1/2 teaspoon espresso powder", "1/4 cup (21g) Dutch-process cocoa powder", "4-ounce (113g) quality\u00a0semi-sweet chocolate bar, finely chopped*", "6 Tablespoons (90g/ml) heavy cream\u00a0or\u00a0heavy whipping cream\u00a0", "optional: fresh raspberries and mint sprigs, for garnish"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C) and generously grease a 9\u00d75-inch loaf pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/marble-loaf-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt. Set aside.", "name": "Make the cake batter", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/marble-loaf-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on medium speed until light and fluffy, about 5 minutes. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed. Add the eggs and vanilla and beat on high speed for 1 minute. The mixture may look a bit curdled at this point\u2014that&#8217;s OK! Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. Pour the flour mixture into the wet ingredients. Turn the mixer to low speed and as the mixer runs, slowly pour in 3/4 cup + 2 Tbsp (210g/ml) of the buttermilk (reserve remaining 2 Tbsp (30g/ml)). Beat on low speed just until combined. Do not over-mix. You may need to whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no large lumps at the bottom of the bowl. The batter will be slightly thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/marble-loaf-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "You&#8217;ll have about 3\u20133.5 cups of batter. Transfer a little less than half (just eyeball it, doesn&#8217;t need to be perfect) of the batter to another bowl. Warm the reserved 2 Tablespoons of buttermilk in the microwave for 10\u201315 seconds. Stir the espresso powder into the warm buttermilk until dissolved, then pour it into the bowl that contains slightly less than half of the batter. Sprinkle the cocoa powder over the top, then stir, whisk, or beat on low speed until combined.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/marble-loaf-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread a thin layer of the plain vanilla batter in the bottom of your prepared loaf pan. Now you will layer spoonfuls of each batter on top\u2014cover bottom vanilla layer with a few spoonfuls of the chocolate batter, then a few spoonfuls of the vanilla batter, then more chocolate batter, then more vanilla batter, and so on until all of the cake batter is used. Gently shimmy the pan to level out the batters. Using a knife, make rounded horizontal zig-zags from one side of the pan to the other, and then make rounded vertical zig-zags from the top to the bottom.", "name": "Layer and swirl the batters", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/marble-loaf-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 65\u201375 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. That time is a guideline\u2014all ovens differ, so keep a close eye on the cake after 55 minutes. If the cake is browning too quickly on top before the center is fully baked, loosely tent a sheet of aluminum foil over top of the pan. (I always tent with foil after 30 minutes.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/marble-loaf-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cool the cake in the pan set on a cooling rack for 30 minutes, then remove the cake from the pan and place it directly on the rack.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/marble-loaf-cake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the chocolate and cream in a medium heat-safe bowl set over a medium saucepan of simmering water. (Or use a double boiler if you have one.) Do not let the bottom of the bowl touch the water. Stir frequently until chocolate has melted and ganache is smooth. Remove from heat and set aside at room temperature for 20 minutes or until slightly thickened.\u00a0", "name": "As the cake cools, make the ganache topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/marble-loaf-cake/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Drizzle or spread topping on cake. Cake is delicious sliced and served slightly warm. The topping sets into a fudge-like consistency after several hours.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/marble-loaf-cake/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftovers tightly and store cake (with or without topping) at room temperature for up to 3 days or in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/marble-loaf-cake/#instruction-step-10"}], "prepTime": "PT25M", "cookTime": "PT1H5M", "totalTime": "PT4H", "recipeYield": ["8", "serves 8\u201310"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "8", "ratingValue": "4.5"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Marble Loaf Cake.mov", "description": "Enjoy 2 cakes in 1 with this buttery-rich marble loaf cake!", "contentUrl": "https://content.jwplatform.com/videos/7cRphzFS.mp4", "thumbnailUrl": ["https://content.jwplatform.com/thumbs/7cRphzFS-720.jpg"], "uploadDate": "2025-09-17T09:20:47+00:00"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Elise"}, "datePublished": "2025-10-03", "reviewBody": "Perfect taste and super moist!"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Terri S"}, "datePublished": "2025-11-08", "reviewBody": "A bit disappointed that the \"old\" recipe version is in the \"new\" Sally's Baking 101 that I just purchased. Lightly grease a\u00a010-inch springform pan (NOT 9-inch) with nonstick cooking spray. In a food processor or blender, pulse the whole Oreos (cream filling and cookie) into a fine crumb. You should have about 2 cups (packed) crumbs, or 250g. Combine the Oreo crumbs and melted butter together in a medium bowl. Press tightly into the bottom and up the sides of prepared pan. Wrap aluminum foil on the bottom and tightly around the outside walls of the springform pan. This helps prevent leakage. Bake for 10 minutes. Sprinkle some of the chopped Snickers on top of the warm crust. Reserve the rest to decorate on top of the cheesecake.", "name": "Make the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/snickers-cheesecake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the cream cheese and granulated sugar together on medium speed in a large bowl, about 3 full minutes until the mixture is smooth and creamy. Add the sour cream and vanilla extract and beat until combined. On low speed, add the eggs one at a time, beating after each addition until just blended. Do not overmix the filling after you have added the eggs. Divide the batter in half. Boil a pot of water. You need 1 inch of water in your roasting pan for the water bath, so make sure you boil enough. I use an entire kettle of hot water. Place the pan inside of a large roasting pan. Carefully pour the hot water inside of the pan and place in the oven. (Or you can place the roasting pan in the oven first, then pour the hot water in.
